title: How might we inspire and enable communities to take more initiative in making their local environments better?

softening_transitionary_public_spaces_in.description: Public spaces such as bus stops are often seen as transitory spaces where people are in a hurry to arrive at/depart from. But what if we tapped on the potential of such spaces as serendipitous hubs for the local community to [briefly] connect?
softening_transitionary_public_spaces_in.creator: dd242164529142349246aacc80f70fd0

comments.text: This reminds me of a random occurrence growing up in the suburbs...  One morning out of no where we woke up to find a chaise lounge in the middle of our cul-de-sac...  My father's great sense of humor sparked a fun idea.  Add something to it and see what happens.I placed a stuffed bear on the chaise and left it over night.  We woke the next morning to find the bear had found a new pair of sunglasses and a drink in hand.  Something new was added everyday by anonymous neighbors until it finally rained at the end of the week and the fun was over.Perhaps you could encourage social engagement by having the coffee table/living room be an expression of that neighborhoods character.  Per Meena, could the design of the sitting areas involve additions from the community?

Nice one, Jason. I also especially like the disruptive and personal aspects of Julie's intervention  possibly more connecting than a formalised table installed by the local council. How might folks be encouraged to add their own mark to sterile urban environments to create a sense of local pride and engage others?

softening_transitionary_public_spaces_in.title: Softening 'transitory' public spaces into little hubs for community connections

in_town_without_mycar.description: A car-free day event running since 2000 in Europe,  where participating towns and cities reserve several public areas only for pedestrians, cyclists and public transport during the entire day.
in_town_without_mycar.creator: 017f79dd3f4a05cd7a9ccf1789ca5b1f
in_town_without_mycar.title: In Town Without MyCar!

singapore_stories.description: A digital archive which hosts a series of stories fed by citizens to share and sustain local history. This social space would host user generated content but also mediate real time action by facilitating a series of meet up's / social events.
singapore_stories.creator: c6d2ed9ca2d2c2e31841e6501f8eddf9

comments.text: Hi Jen, Great concept! I'm convinced that sharing stories and hearing other (older or younger) citizen's stories is the best way to develop a true passion for your city which will result in more engaged citizens and stronger citizen communities. I've been thinking a lot about developing a similar concept in my beloved hometown Brussels. I'll dive into my notes and will share my ideas with you if you like.I'm really glad I came across your idea. Let me know if I can be of any help, I'd love to contribute to this concept.Cheers,Pierre

Jen & Team - we're so sorry that we may have lost some of the updates to this concept over the last 72 hours - we lost the AWS server stack which included the backup and even after working through the night some updates escaped us.  We've extended the Refinement Phase to the 27th to give everyone extra time to re-upload their content and to push your concept even further - apologies again if you did lose any updates...
Happy to join the team to refine your concept. Let me know next steps as it's the first time I join the OpenIdeo process.

Thanks for joining the virtual team. This is the first time I've participated in a full challenge too. I'll explore the other concepts to see how they work together. I hoped to sketch a service design concept building upon everyones feedback. To illustrate how this concept might become a reality with consideration to building partnerships and expanding upon existing initiatives. Also, I hoped to mock up the storytelling toolkit in some format. Please let me know if you have any ideas? :-)

Jen,The simplest the better. On-line there are plenty of ideas suggested here. I think the best way is a simple form to the like of the Singapore project people can fill either from their PC or mobile phone. I think it would be usefull for the form to include the question "Has something triggered this memory?" it would help identify issues, aspirations people have and would help design initiative to respond to them.Also reading the stories on the Singapore initiative it may give more dynamic to the story reading process to first get people telling a story to add to the headline a 2-3 sentenses summary. Stories tend to be fairly long by web standards. In our world especially on-line we loose people's attention fairly rapidly if we don't hook them up in the first 2-3 sec.To be inclusive of all ages it's also important to have an off-line process to capture stories. There the Singapore initiative could be a great partner as they have planned to train story teller etc.. Maybe an additional tool could be to let such forms in places where people go often, food markets, post office. People could take the form home and write their story, enclose pictures, drawings etc and post it back to the "Story telling" website.It would play at the same time the role of spreading the word about this initiative.Have you thought of the branding/image you would like to give? You already have a quote "and I'm a Singaporean". Does it mean you want to focus your initiative on people living there?

Hi Anne-Marie, thanks so much for sharing your thoughts and reflections. I thought possibly the template could be a post card which could be free to collect via local places or downloadable?Your thoughts about a logo / brand concept are helpful too. I think focusing the imitative on local people  would be people a good place to start. I like the other suggestions about ... And that's why I love Singapore. Maybe a series / collection of postcards could be designed to prompt / facilitate storytelling?Jen :-)

Hey! Great concept there! In fact, actually there's a movement in Singapore going on at the moment called the Singapore Memory Project. It's organised by the National Library Board of SIngapore. Most of the stories they've collected are on their Facebook page https://www.facebook.com/irememberSG?fref=ts and website http://www.singaporememory.sg/clusters. I think this could be building on the Singapore Memory Project. They do occasional community events too, e.g recently they had this 'Grandest Story Told' event where they got people to come by, write what they remember most in their Singapore moments, and take a picture of it. Do check it out on their Facebook page! I think it could be good to build on what's currently existing. More 'Singapore Memory Projects' could definitely happen all around... and I see that's where your toolkit will be useful! Great job there!
Thanks so much for sharing :-) What a great project. Maybe they could be a potential partner if this concept was to emerge further?
Yea its an awesome project. I love it too! Its a great resource on defining the Singapore identity too!

Along this line of thought it would also be interesting to partner with groups that could pick up on these stories to fuel initiatives in the neighbourhood to respond to people's needs and aspirations. It could be the cultural centre of the related neighbourhood if such things exist in Singapore or the portal itself could have figures to propose and stimulate action projects inspired by and around the published stories.If people see actions taking place as a result of the story telling activity it would motivate more people to participate in the story telling activitiy.

Are your concept focused on text? written down stories?that people can read out aloud for their friends? and let the listeners remember or save them, to be able to repeat the same story at a later time, for more friends? like the nomads telling stories by the fireplace and make them wander around and spread out  ?

Hi Johan, maybe the storytelling toolkit could offer a pick and mix of different suggestions for sharing stories... such as props for facilitating interaction to enable citizens to write down or sketch stories which they can then narrate, send to a friend or even record / upload via a mobile device through social media channels. To broaden the reach I think outside interventions would need to be orchestrated beyond the toolkit offer. To facilitate interaction, provide demonstrations and identify champions to lead engagement within different localities ?

Jen, I have an idea!!!! What if we not only made it easy for people to share stories, but also incentivised this activity. What if locals and tourists could capture and share Singapore stories and be rewarded with free internet (for example)? You have to watch this video to understand the source of inspiration: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MvVuE4WooaI

Hey Vishal, That's a great suggestion and thanks for sharing the video. I have been thinking about value propositions for citizens to promote participation too. Do you think Singapore Stories could be sustained through an App? Like an instagram style service which embeds geotagging to map localism... but possibly short videos too. I think your right the concept needs to offer something back and free internet would be a great offer. I like the idea of rewards... could it be a points system for participation offering vouchers or discount codes for local services to support the local economy?

Thinking about the storytelling toolkit and expanding upon Vishal's feedback... a tag line ending with ..."and Im a Singaporean" could be used.Maybe the POD / Vox Pop "pop up" could be used alongside a campaign to promote the concept and populate a website to construct a storybank. The toolkit could be integrated to demonstrate use and application. I'll spend sometime this afternoon prototyping the storytelling toolkit. Would love any thoughts or feedback :-)

Yayy :-) Really loving how this is coming together, and quite happy to be on the virtual team! Let me know how I could add-value during the refinement phase? Happy to give feedback on the storytelling toolkit.
Found object: http://www.singaporememory.sg/
http://www.pl.sg/page/PlBrowsePhotos/BrowsePhotoMostPopular&_nfls=false

Jen, I totally believe in the power of storytelling and I really like your concept. It would be great to have stories about places and even the people - the local, unnoticed heroes.You mentioned how this could be facilitated by storytelling themes and a call for engagement. I was thinking of some ways in which this could spread and scale. The idea in essence to create some catchy campaigns, build a strong brand and make it easy for people to get involved.One way could be to give people a basic template to capture their own story, ending with something like - "And I am a Singaporean"If it's about a place, people could again write a few lines and end with... "I love Singapore".All this could be captured on a dedicated website - people can log-on, use the tools and templates available and publish (would be better if this were curated)This is what triggered the idea:I spent quite a few years in AIESEC (www.aiesec.org) and remember one of the campaigns we ran around stories of our members. It was called "I'm an AIESECer" and we made a simple template/ toolkit for members to design and tell their stories.Here's a presentation: http://www.slideshare.net/LucySymons/im-an-aiesecer-20And you'll see many of these stories of you just type in "I' an AIESECer" in Google Images.
Great builds, Vishal _ we're looking forward to where this exciting concept might evolve to!
Thanks for sharing such great insight Vishal. I like your thoughts about prompts for capturing stories. The project you shared is beautiful too :-)

I understand the necessity for people to continue to meet face-to-face and tell stories. So it is marvelous that you try to enable more of that with your concept. But I wonder what from your concept could be included in my similar concept proposal, and what details from mine could be introduced into your concept?Would you please take the time and read mine: http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/concepting/mp3-tourism/ ?And I will re-read yours and think about what could be improved!Best of luck!

Thanks Johan... Of course. I've read through your concept and will spend some more time thinking about if further. I love the mobile storytelling aspect of your concept and it prompted me to think further about how geo-tagging could be used to map & visually construct a people centred narrative Best of luck to you too! :-)

i like your concept for its connective approach, but I think some people would not enjoy too close intimate contact and interaction with complete strangers.so my concept is a bit more "safe" and portable, flexible, because you can choose to listen to all types of stories as much as you like, even if the narrator are unavailable.

Hi Johan, Thanks for your feedback. That's a good and fair critique and to support such interaction would require deep and mindful consideration. I'll take this into account when updating the concept by trying to devise a series of interactions which connects not only strangers but also peer groups of friends, even family members to explore how stories can be exchanged from one generation to the next. The themes could possibly focus on local areas, history,heritage, traditions etc.. so that people can connect to the theme as well as the individual? My intention was for the storytelling toolkit to capture stories by facilitating storytelling... therefore they would be documented online / through social media channels and be available when the narrator isn't present too. Thanks so much for your feedback :-)

Thinking about the concept further for refinement stage: I would like to expand upon the mechanisms used to capture stories from citizens. SHOWstudio an interactive fashion platform devised a street style pod within a busy fashion store shop window. This captured aprox 20,000 outputs http://tinyurl.com/c4xb6yrPeople passing by could take their own picture which was forward via a live stream to a website / gallery space. Therefore, how can user generated content be captured from the ground up? Could something similar be orchestrated in partnership with the local authority or could a POD / Vox Pop's station be assembled to emerge within a series of pop up spaces to facilitate conversation and participant interaction? It would be good to connect people within both virtual and physical spaces
Digging the story telling toolkit and additional offline component you have included here, Jen!
Thanks mena. Thinking about how to  prototype it :-)

Jen, congrats! Your concept is on the NEA Challenge Shortlist. We really liked its focus on preserving local heritage and culture. As we move into Refinement, think about partnerships that you might be able to cultivate with organisations who are already tracking history. During our Concepting Synthesis Session with NEA, we saw Singapore's National Library Board as a potential co-conspirator -- they're already responsible for a national archive. But the options are open -- think of who might be your partner in making this come to life. For more tips on how to iterate and prototype your idea during the Refinement phase, read here http://bit.ly/connect-refinetips and check this Lowdown: http://bit.ly/oi_refine

I find this idea very interesting. The future of a community is also influenced by its roots hence the story of its past. These roots will contribute to build what future may look like for a given block, suburbs that will be different from the next one.Knowing the stories of a specific area can also be used as a way to include new comers. Sharing the memory of the place and its community allows new comers to feel something in common upon arrival. It may also attract people that feel they have things in common or feel they want to join that story.

singapore_stories.title: Singapore Stories

py/tuple: How easy would it be for citizens to get involved and take initiative for this idea?
Very easy; this would rely on ground-up participation from the beginning.
Somewhat easy; there are ways for citizens to get involved, but an outside organiser may be needed to sustain and grow this concept.
This concept needs to be led and maintained by the government or private business.
Can you build this concept on top of something that already exists, like an organisation, physical space, or system?
Yes. This could fold into, or extend from, something that already exists.
This concept taps existing networks for a few things, but also needs a lot of new processes, materials, relationships, etc.
This concept requires a new system to be built to support it.
After the initial launch and support, could this concept be sustained and cared for over time by the community it's designed to serve?
Absolutely! This concept is easy to keep going.
It depends. There are opportunities for growth, but it's not yet clear how the concept would thrive after launch.
Probably not. A lot of effort would be needed to keep this concept going.
Does this concept create community?
Yes. It naturally brings people together and inspires them to take care of one another.
There is potential to create a thriving community.
No. It doesn't galvanize people to come together for a common cause or interest.
Overall, how do you feel about this concept?
It rocked my world.
I liked it but preferred others.
It didn't get me overly excited.

soccer_or_any_sport_really_creates_natio.description: When the national team wins, everyone is happy. A sense of ownership and pride arises through all the population. People celebrate and are optimistic about the future when the soccer team gets to the world cup and wins matches.
soccer_or_any_sport_really_creates_natio.creator: 71b22404fbe3c87c8b16fdf1cf5cefc7

comments.text: Great personal reflections and insight here, David. Also made me think about how sport connects communities through people playing locally (for school, work, casually and local leagues)  which is stimulated by the national level interest you describe here. Lots to feed our upcoming Concepting phase around the notion of sport!
Yeah that is true, I forgot to include that in my post. Everyone gets more involved in the sport and celebrate even more every victory of the national team. Thanks for mentioning that!

Topically, the "Olympic effect" in London has been amazing. The sense of goodwill amongst Londoners and the broader British population has been almost tangible. The challenge to Olympic legacy organisers is to sustain & grow this sense of goodwill. Of course few cities will be afforded the opportunity to host the Olympics. However, as Meena suggests, I think Singapore's (and other cities') opportunity is to energise sport at a community-level. People are fundamentally tribal and take pride in their chosen tribe's endeavours and successes; sport is a great mechanism to tap in to the positive aspects of tribalism. Community sports programmes & incentives -> Community sports competitions & events -> Community interest & support -> Community collaboration & bonding -> Sense of community pride & belonging -> Positive cross-pollination in to other aspects of the community...A sports programme is certainly something I would consider.

Eoin, that is exactly what I had in mind. Sports can be rolled out inexpensively and create a grass roots movement that can take the country by storm. Plus, local teams and national teams create a sense of belonging and unity that is hard to replicate with other mediums.

Guys  you might be interested in this local initiative form Singapore too: http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/inspiration/singapore-community-games-2012/ How might we build on this kind of thing? Looking forward to ideas in our upcoming Concepting phase!

Interesting thoughts. In the Netherlands, Football Fever takes hold of the nation at the big tournaments (Euro and World Cups), and turns the country orange, the national colour.And football is big in Singapore already, I think, albeit not so much the national league or team, but the English Premier League. I remember from my one visit to Singapore, that a game between Chelsea and Liverpool was shown live on 5 huge screens in the CHIJMES entertainment center. There were loads of people watching it in red Liverpool shirts. It was really a great atmosphere.

The atmosphere is amazing when the team is winning. Based on the last world cup, you should know more than anyone! If we can replicate that feeling with the most promising sport in Singapore, then we will be able to solve this issue :)

soccer_or_any_sport_really_creates_natio.title: Soccer (or any sport really) creates nationwide bonding.

interactive_map_plug_in_for_social_netwo.description:
More than ever people are linked with social networks.
So...what if we had an interactive plug in for Facebook or/and other social networks that would make us know what the community needs on a specific moment?
You help! + you get help if you need!
interactive_map_plug_in_for_social_netwo.creator: ef339f1741d6a544a14c1e273a29a1e9

comments.text: Joana, one way I tried to address safety in the #connectmydistrict concept is by indicating the approximate block, rather than the actual address. If the exchange reaches a mutually beneficial point, the parties involved can exchange contact info. I'm not sure but I think dating websites do this. Hope this helps!

Well, I as so into the volunteering thing (doing something good) that I almost underestimated the importance of safety. Unfortunately there are crazy people out there!Thank you Kirk. Neighbourhood / Blocks is actually better.

Brilliant concept Joana. I recently met Tong Yee from The Thought Collective (http://www.thethoughtcollective.com.sg) in Singapore. His team are working on a similar concept, except it is more focused on organising the volunteering community in Singapore. It's basically like Task Rabbit (https://www.taskrabbit.com) for volunteering.
Thank you Vishal! Thanks for sharing Task Rabbit, I had never heard of it and I absolutely L*O*V*E it!

Hey Joana, great idea! I think Kirk may have a come up with a concept that provides exactly the kind of social media platform your idea could work off, through district hash-tagging on Twitter:http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/concepting/connectmydistrict/?

Thanks, James, for connecting the dots! I will try to add both of you to my team if the platform allows. And I like this concept's intent. We are lucky to live in the times that we do. I have been thinking about how we can connect neighbors through social media channels. Twitter feeds are real time and can be updates related to the geographic area associated with the hash tag. It would also enable neighbors to discover that they live near one another (still a strange concept to me). I especially like the visual nature and the role of maps in your concept.

Excellent idea!  Check out NeedMap; a social venture still in development that visually and very specifically maps needs.  E.g. "20 vaccines needed in a hospital in Cooke Town, Bangalore, India".  Their webpage and demo is awesome:http://needmap.com/demo/As a user, you could see "needs" in several ways: 1) people in your social network (facebook, Google+), 2) people or needs that align with your interests (based off of your Likes on facebook, or tags that you identify with your profile, 3) geographic proximity, or 4) good 'old free-lance searching.

This sounds to me a lot like the +U, the App, take a look at www.openplanetideas.com and check it out! perhaps you will get more ideas from it, to your concept proposal herehttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7_jjK2dU4aM

I had never heard about U+! Really worth to check it out. I would do almost the same but linked with things that the community needs. Every single person would have the chance to post asking for help or to check who needs help!Quite difficult to make it work on my Samsung! :(

interactive_map_plug_in_for_social_netwo.title: HELP 4 U: AN INTERACTIVE MAP (PLUG IN) FOR SOCIAL NETWORKS!

community_recycling_centers.description: Community Recycling Centers in each town would be managed by the residents or Town Councils, and serve as a community space and platform where residents can come together to learn and participate in reducing, reusing and recycling waste materials.
community_recycling_centers.creator: b283fb803516b3ba03e7692991593dcf

comments.text: Eugene - we're so sorry that we may have lost some of the updates to this concept over the last 72 hours - we lost the AWS server stack which included the backup and even after working through the night some updates escaped us.  We've extended the Refinement Phase to the 27th to give everyone extra time to re-upload their content and to push your concept even further - apologies again if you did lose any updates...
good idea! :-)

Hi Eugene - James made a good point about about a concept I posted in concepting that may resonate with your great idea. If it makes sense or there are parts you like I just wanted to highlight it for you - visit it here: http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/concepting/recycling-improvement/Cheers~

Hi Eugene, Lindsay, Meena. I love the mission statement of this idea that is outlined right at the outset; the collections and workshops. No doubt that a physical building could be great for establishing a permanent drop-in culture and presence. However, I wonder if a mobile service might serve the collection and community events better?It could be like a reverse garage sale.. the bus(es) turns up with a little bit of fanfare and an all day long series of workshops/events to go with it, while people can drop in and out with their larger recyclable goods or used furniture etc..The obvious draw for residents is not having to transport their bigger/bulkier used items themselves.Perhaps the most important thing about executing this concept would be understanding the catchment area in terms of both distance and time; I can see an occasional where people bring all of their used furniture on one day as being far more of a buzz-creator than a permanently open drop-off point, but at the same time, there is a daily need to dispose of/recycle food stuffs and packaging. Striking the right balance between permanance and mobility to capture the biggest audience would give the events and workshops the best chance to flourish.
Thanks James for your comments! Would be interesting to explore mobile or pop-up CRCs too, although it might reduce the residents' ownership of the space. Definitely something worth looking into!

Hi Eugene.. thanks for your comment on Tools Library.. I think this 'Smart Bins' concept from the San Franciso brainstorming session would complement both ideas really well:http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/concepting/recycling-improvement/

Great discussion guys! Eugene  if you'd like to acknowledge the collaborative input of others in the evolution of your concept, you have the option to add them to your Virtual Team. Just hit the Update Entry button up there on the right of your post & scroll down to the Virtual Team area. We dig folks who design better, together!

Eugene love the community recycling center idea!  I thought your concept would work well with 3 others, below is my idea:After reviewing James Robertson's "Flash Sports", Eugene Tay's "Community Recycling Center", Hao Dinh's "Dish In Dish Out" and Maria Malcus "Local Night Markets", I had the below thought on connecting the 4 concepts:Have "flash night markets" (these are night markets that are scheduled to occur in specific communities during specific times) that will enable vendors, both from the community  and from other night markets, to sell their goods.  Great opportunity for community vendors to highlight their goods to their communities and allows vendors from other night markets entry to "new" customers.The entry fee to the "flash night market" is a potluck dish.  Each "flash night markets" will have a theme associated with a community issue.  Once in the market, participants will be able to meet new people, try all the potluck dishes, buy items from the vendors and most importantly, contribute to organized discussions on how to resolve the community issue.  Lastly I was thinking of having an "community recycling center" at the "flash night markets".  The center will educate people on reuse, recycle and reduce.  Additionally people will receive "market cash" for bringing in their recyclables.  The "market cash" can be used to buy products from the "flash night market".  (Checkout "Delicious Recycling" in Brazil http://www.care2.com/greenliving/brazilian-city-offers-vegetables-in-exchange-for-trash.html)What do you gals/guys think?
Thanks Hao Dinh, could be one of the weekly events organised by the CRC together with the Pasar Malam concept

Hi Eugene, I have added you to my virtual team for Pasar Malam reinvented. I think it would be great if the two concepts could somehow inspire each other (or combine). Maybe they could combine physically or just psychologically (like encouraging people to buy local/upcycled and be generally more aware). I am constantly surprised at how little people care about recycling in Singapore and over all I think there are 3 things missing: awareness, convenience and incentive. I would love to see if one or two of those aspects could somehow be incorporated into something that people really like (e.g. shopping or eating) so that people would gain the knowledge without actively looking for it or get a monetary or social incentive to recycle. Let me know if you have any thoughts on it!
Being big fans of collaboration  we're excited to see where your exchange of ideas might go!

Thanks Maria, the Pasar Malam could be one of the weekly events organised by the CRC. Also keen to include the Tool Library concept by James at http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/concepting/tool-library-for-every-district/. Maybe the CRC could be renamed as Community 3R (Reduce, Reuse, Recycle) Center.

Eugene -- good job! Your concept made it to our NEA Challenge Shortlist. We liked that your idea was inclusive of all demographics, and allows for people to help the environment in a convenient and fun way. Moving into Refinement, think about building out the ways in which we might incentive people to recycle, while bringing them together, perhaps in a venue like Pasar Malam -- Maria Malcus' concept (http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/concepting/pasar-malam-reinvented/). The notion of frequency also seems important: How might you communicate and signal a regular drumbeat of recycling happenings in a local neighbourhood? Finally: Is there an educational aspect involved? Lots of inspiring ways to grow this idea! We can't wait to see what you come up with. For more tips on how to iterate and prototype your idea during the Refinement phase, read here http://bit.ly/connect-refinetips and check this Lowdown: http://bit.ly/oi_refine
Thanks for the shortlist and the suggestions!!

Hello. Did you see my concept proposal about using old barges for recycling collection on the riverfronts and the shorelines? Please "recycle" & "reuse" any of my ideas if you wish, for this concept :)http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/concepting/floating-barges/
Thanks Johan for sharing, would be keen to include the repair component.

Eugene, I love the way you've incorporated personal, private sector, and public sector responsibilities here. And it's great to know that donated items will go on to have second lives: The vegetable oil turns into biodiesel, etc. I would love to see community champions for each recyclable materials -- people who could create awareness among restaurants, for example, about recycling used oil and the benefits for the business and the environment.

Fab thoughts Eugene  and great to have you join us from on the ground in Singapore! And interesting that you raise the notion of community champions, Lindsey. That was what triggered my thinking on this concept for a previous OpenIDEO challenge: http://www.openideo.com/open/e-waste/concepting/neighbourhood-e-waste-champion/ I wonder if there might be room within the CRC concept for a toolkit to support community champions?

Thanks Lindsey and Meena for the comments! Would definitely be good to involve the residents in the community in the CRC, and some residents could be trained by the National Environment Agency to be community champions. The idea is to bring recycling and waste minimisation down to the community level where residents can see and tackle the problem hands-on.

community_recycling_centers.title: Community Recycling Centers (updated 19 Dec)

Nice one Yin! As a potential build, I wonder whether there could be a card in the back of the book where you could fill out your name + comments on the book? This might also help folks make connections and reach out to people who's comments they read.

comments.text: I love the idea of neighborhood museums. The District 6 museum is wonderful because it connects you to the lives of the individuals who resided there through stories, pictures, and items from daily life. Its existence stems from a sad and tragic situation but I believe the core concept -- creating a museum space based on the lives of people who live in a neighborhood -- could be really interesting, and scalable. I wonder how we might make living museums that bring neighborhoods to life through the stories of its residents, past and present.
Wow, great inspiration. What a good and fitting inspiration for this challenge. I'm going to build on this in the concepting phase!
thank you. it would be a pleasure to build a concept together!

Provide citizens with a competition that asks to make their block (HDB or Condo) the most pretty in town, displaying the nationality of Singapore & the citizens living at the block.

comments.text: Annet - we're so sorry that we may have lost some of the updates to this concept over the last 72 hours - we lost the AWS server stack which included the backup and even after working through the night some updates escaped us.  We've extended the Refinement Phase to the 27th to give everyone extra time to re-upload their content and to push your concept even further - apologies again if you did lose any updates...
Also updated this one again!

Hey Annet! great to meet the other night at the Jamming, and to now see all the ideas going up online. This is a good one. Thinking about how best to present/decorate each block, I wonder if each block can be thought of as a pixelated canvas.. With each apartment acting as a pixel (or 4, 6 or 9 pixels as the movement grows in complexity). Residents could then decide on what kind of image they want to project, and how many colours to use. Once an image and colours are decided upon, a few clever people work out which flat needs to display which colour(s), and then inform the residents. Assuming not everybody has every colour, there would probably be a lot of lending and borrowing of sheets and bedclothes. These could be hung from balconies (as a temporary alternative to flags - for but but a fleeting moment lest we lose any nation pride), to form an image like this:http://www.brooklynartproject.com/photo/my-president-is-pixelated?context=userAlternatively, simpler pixelations could be created just using national flags. This whole thing may be a bit ambitious, but I love the idea of co-ordinating entire facades to present a bigger picture, more than the sporadic placement of flags.
Hey James, nice to see you also here. I like the pixel idea, I know it from the post-it pixel challenges, the inhabitants could indeed do something similarly with their bed sheets and all.

The pixel idea is a pretty smart way to go about it! Actually in Singapore, we do have a best decorated block competition on 9aug in some residents. My block is always the winner, haha. But the problem with this competition is that the residents committee leaders, RCs, end up doing the entire decorations.. which isn't very effective.That's why i think the pixel idea is great to get everyone to do it together! There's a chinese tv show here that gathers neighbours to build something together too. It was a smart way of knowing your other neighbours. Singapore needs more of this!Cheers!

Hi James & Angela,Would you like to team up and refine this concept together? I would love to do some experimenting, (maybe this weekend?) and as you both have great ideas and maybe a little bit more experience in Singapore (compared to my 5 weeks) it will be good to team up.
Sure Annet! We can discuss more to see how we can refine it better :)

Hi Annet, Angela, I think it would be great to refine this in open discussion.. could use some help on mine too! Will find out by tomorrow/weds when I am free.. have some stuff organized for the weekend but maybe saturday morning? There could be a couple of other 'virtual team' members based here in Singpapore worth inviting also..
Wohoo guys! Looking forward to hearing how things go. Tweet us a photo if you meet up!

Hee James,We are meeting at friday evening to come up with prototype ideas to implement at saturday afternoon as the morning is both not good for us. Do you want to join us either friday evening or saturday afternoon? (or both of course :) )And any others interested?! Let us know!

Hey.. afraid I have my company christmas party this eve, and then am playing a match tomorrow afternoon :( If the implementation stretch into Sunday let me know, will try and pop along! Good luck and have fun!

Annet -- another nice concept! Your idea made it to the NEA Challenge Shortlist. We liked the way you centred your concept around an already-existing holiday that inspires Singaporeans to celebrate their country. As we move into Refinement, perhaps you could prototype a scenario that makes citizens the main drivers of the competition. Secondly, what's the system around it: How might we get the word out, and where would the creative resources and supplies come from? For more tips on how to iterate and prototype your idea during the Refinement phase, read here http://bit.ly/connect-refinetips and check this Lowdown: http://bit.ly/oi_refine

Love how you've mashed up neighbourhood pride with national pride on this one, Annet! And friendly competition is a great motivator. I can imagine that the connection forged through this kind of initiative would strengthen community bonds throughout the year.

Thanks Meena, I think the community bond would indeed be strengthen throughout the year. Also it is an easy way to access this type of competition; everybody can decorate, no specific skills are needed. Kids, elderly, everybody can join.
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!
Thanks!

py/tuple: How easy would it be for citizens to get involved and take initiative for this idea?
Very easy; this would rely on ground-up participation from the beginning.
Somewhat easy; there are ways for citizens to get involved, but an outside organiser may be needed to sustain and grow this concept.
This concept needs to be led and maintained by the government or private business.
Can you build this concept on top of something that already exists, like an organisation, physical space, or system?
Yes. This could fold into, or extend from, something that already exists.
This concept taps existing networks for a few things, but also needs a lot of new processes, materials, relationships, etc.
This concept requires a new system to be built to support it.
After the initial launch and support, could this concept be sustained and cared for over time by the community it's designed to serve?
Absolutely! This concept is easy to keep going.
It depends. There are opportunities for growth, but it's not yet clear how the concept would thrive after launch.
Probably not. A lot of effort would be needed to keep this concept going.
Does this concept create community?
Yes. It naturally brings people together and inspires them to take care of one another.
There is potential to create a thriving community.
No. It doesn't galvanize people to come together for a common cause or interest.
Overall, how do you feel about this concept?
It rocked my world.
I liked it but preferred others.
It didn't get me overly excited.

tool_library_for_every_district.description: Helping individuals and small businesses reduce the cost of maintaining the places in which they live, work, and play. Tool libraries offer hundreds of hand and power tools for landscaping, home repair, and automobile maintenance.
tool_library_for_every_district.creator: 7e7dcb823cb8bac78bee007e8041492e

comments.text: This would be a great idea, especially if refurbishing a dilapidated buildng into the library was part of the effort.Including patterns and explanations for types of furniture and various other forms of information to aid in competency. Richly displayed and easily seen safety information would be a big necessity too. This seems like a great idea, I'd like to advocate for something like this in my city.

Hi Bobby, I love your angle on refurbishing dilapidated buildings; as an architectural designer this really hits the spot with me. I wonder if this can be somehow intertwined with a drive to provide more incentivized freelance work for people who find themselves unemployed. I'll try to paint a scenario:The city finds itself in possession of a number of repossessed houses or industrial buildings. At present these pieces of real estate are a liability to the public; eating taxpayer money in security and giving nothing back in rental or other income. What if the city were able to return these properties to a salable state using a profit-share scheme of voluntary labour? Business could sponsor some of the materials, perhaps feed the workers, and youths could gain apprenticeships / accreditations upon logging a certain number of hours participation.  Upon a successful sale of the property, the city shares the profits with the volunteers in a completely transparent way. I guess it would be naive to think that the kind of reward the volunteers would gain could match a proper salary, and perhaps if the scheme grew too much in could be in danger of depressing wages across the industry, so I think there would have to be entry criteria, such that it really was aimed at helping out those who need the biggest leg-up to get onto the career ladder - perhaps the young and those out of work for 6+ months.In terms of prototyping, your idea about establishing a home for the library as the very first building to be refurbished - sounds fantastic, and I love the expansion into furniture and signage, even touching on design, fantastic!Keep in touch with any implementation thoughts.. will try and get the ball rolling in some capacity here in Singapore soon! If you see my response to Gaia above though, there may be better places to start; i'd love to share thoughts with anybody having a crack at it elsewhere!Good luck!

Sorry for the delay,I have been away learning from my masters program, I think an effective way to proceed with this is to look at sponsor groups, many corporations have a capacity to commit grant money to projects like this and it is built into their philanthropy budgets, two possible corporations to consider would be Lowes and Home Depot.Local cities have plenty of dilapidated houses and businesses to choose from (I recently started working an internship at the Greater Columbia Chamber of Commerce, tomorrow I"ll approach my supervisor about the possibility of seizing an abandoned firehouse that is near my apartment), Finally , if you're in a college town, there are opportunities to partner with colleges for labor, funding and space. Colleges also bring to the table support of their community partners. (I work full time at a college) It's a long shot, but I'll spend the next few days exploring options and seeing if I can find support for this project locally, Thanks for the spur to action, I'll get back with you with the results.Thanks and good luck!

Hi Bobby, Great to hear your exciting thoughts and potential contacts above. Lowes and Home Depot make perfect sense as sponsors, but we would have to convince them of the net gain somehow, since I guess part of the overall original concept is that 'perhaps less people should havet to buy their own tools outright'! I guess if we are trying to skill-up more people and use more materials then it still might make sense for them.Colleges are a ideal fit though.. especially technical ones. An ulitmate aim of the scheme would be to integrate some form of really basic accrediation, to act as a stepping stone to achieving (or maybe shortening, reducing the cost of) more established formal accreditations.Keep me informed on it all! I have a twitter feed you PM me on with further thoughts as this develops. Over here in Singapore I believe there's going to be some kind of hack-a-thon event in mid March relating to this event, so will hope to make some huge leaps and bounds then. If you're already making headway at your end, it would be great to present some of that progress and building blocks for whatever direction we end up going in at this end!All the best,James

Hey Bobby, How's it all going with Columbia?Thought I give you an update - I am lucky enough to be sitting down with some fellow OpenIDEO-ers this weekend at a 'Make-a-thon' here in Singapore, where we are trying to move forward with some  prototyping for a variation of this concept that also relates to the Smart Grid Games concept on the same challenge. Keep an eye on the feed for some crowd-sourced collaboration, would be great to bring the virtual team online in real-time!It starts on Friday at 1330 Singapore time (GMT + 8 ... I think!) Sure OpenIDEO will be tweeting about it loads, and i'll hope to find a way for the team that is assmebled in person to be able to interact with any members of the virtual team who are still keen to be a part of it all and help push the idea along :)

I'm so glad I got to be a part of this concept, I was swamped with graduate school around the time that this happened unfortunately or I would have definitely been a part of this event. Columbia is going great, I have established connections with a number of non profits and will be teaching a service learning embedded course in the fall, though at the moment I'm in New York City for the summer working on more graduate school things.I can't wait to contribute to more of your concepts James, you're brilliant!

This idea is very attractive to disseminate volunteering and civic participation and responsibility over private and public spaces. this would be more than appropriate and desirable in Belgrade as well. However, because of the unlikeliness of reliance on public funding in Belgrade, Serbia - it would be most appropriate to devise a self-sustaining business model. I think that to begin with, local businesses could pitch in to stimulate the start-up phase; community members could volunteer according to their talents/capacities...

Hey Gaia, thanks for your thoughts. Actually I think somewhere like Belgrade (I've not been, so can't be 100% sure) might be a better place for something like this concept to grow; the difficulty (if you can call it that!) in somewhere like Singapore, is that most public space is incredibly well maintained, and the cost of hiring handymen to sort domestic problems so cheap, that there is little opportunity for the amateur DIY enthusiasts to make an impact on the community.I would suggest you take a look at the link to the Santa Rose link right at the start of the description; these guys seem to have managed largely without public finance. West Seattle Tool Library is also another existing example.Might be looking at implementing this here in the next couple of months if we can find support from the gatekeepers, so do keep in touch and share any prototyping thoughts if you decide to have a go in Belgrade!

YES, James!!!! The links are definitely fitting!!!! I am now writing a project for the development of local economies in municipalities along Danube in Serbia and I think that these kind of activities stimulate entrepreneurship and cooperation which is supposed to break the vicious circle of "stagnation"...So, I will definitely keep in touch to share upgrades :) THANKS :)

Hey Gaia.. great that you are starting something off! Having read your comments above, I'd love to suggest the same thing in Serbia as I have written in response to Bobby Cordell's comments just below here. There must be a way to engage more unemployed people in beneficial semi-paid freelance work, allowing some profit-share. I hope so anyway!

Hey Gaia.. you should check out Bobby's latest thoughts on sponsors and educational links above. You're absolutely right at targeting a break in the circle of stagnation. In the 'industrial' economy, unless we are farming or mining something, it seems like we have to wait for someone to put money into at the top of the system before it filters down. However, particuarly in the knowledge/data economy, there seems to be a real opportunity to create something from nothing....By cross-pollinating knowledge and skillsets (IT skills, languages, programming) over the internet (and in person where exisiting knowledge is present) using live projects, we can build knowledge-bases that did not previously exist, and potentially attract new micro-industries or investment, and regenerate regions. As I said to Bobby too, over here in Singapore I believe there's going to be some kind of hack-a-thon event in mid March relating to this event, so we will hope to make some huge leaps and bounds then. If you're already making headway in Serbia, it would be great to present any progress or thoughts as further building blocks for whatever direction we end up going in at this end! All the best, James
great James, thanks for adding me to your virtual team ;)...looking forward to cooperating more actively :)
Congratulations James!

I like the idea that we can have common households tools and gadgets to share. This will enable all the neighourhood to come together, to fix furniture, help maintain and upkeep the old folks household fittings like lights bulbs and toilets. 2nd hand furniture can be passed on to better homes. etc.Expensive tools like a arc-welding set can be loaned at a small price so that people can use them to do DIY work.Great idea!

James - we're so sorry that we may have lost some of the updates to this concept over the last 72 hours - we lost the AWS server stack which included the backup and even after working through the night some updates escaped us.  We've extended the Refinement Phase to the 27th to give everyone extra time to re-upload their content and to push your concept even further - apologies again if you did lose any updates...

It's quite a different concept  but there might be some aspects that you can build upon from this shortlisted idea from our Vibrant Cities Challenge: http://www.openideo.com/open/vibrant-cities/concepting/sharefair-on-and-offline-rent-swop-and-share-fair-/

Thanks Meena, that was a really rich link. Loads more threads to pursue from the comments too.I think at this point the idea needs to be distilled; plenty of great suggestions but maybe it's a touch stretched/diluted. Will be looking to resolve the following key points, please add any that you think also need clarification/development:A) SCALE - how big is the library, how big is its catchment?B) STAFFING - self run by user or in need of professional admin?C) CONTENT - Anything goes or are their measures in place to avoid being a dumping ground?D) COMMUNITY - How do the details of the concept draw people together and bind the community? Can it integrate other concepts?E) INTERFACE - What do the physical and online interfaces look and feel like.. imagine a user experience...Virtual Team please throw some opinions out there!

As an aside, I love the 'Build Upon' feature of Open IDEO, but I think there is room to improve this even further with a 'Plug-In' element. The existing collaboration map plays a similar role, but sometimes it can be suggested that one concept should either contain a few plug-ins or be contained within a larger umbrella. For instance, I would definitely see the Tool Library being a smaller part of a larger CRC as proposed by Eugene.. but then, with other Concepts, like my Smart Grid Games, I'd love to pick a handful of more specific concepts like Smart Bins from SF and Johan's projectors and street graffiti ideas, and explicitly suggest that they form part of a bigger picture.I feel the lack of hierarchy is a real strength of this whole adventure, but at the latter stages, (maybe during applause?), small eco-systems of concepts plugged into each other could bring about another leap forward in how all these ideas might successfully leverage each other.
Your 'aside' is more likely to reach the right eyeballs on our team via our Feature Suggestion forum: http://bit.ly/oi_forums ;^)
Thanks! Comments made here:https://openideo.zendesk.com/entries/22586032-plug-in-conceptshttps://openideo.zendesk.com/entries/20057623-creating-combo-concepts

James I am thinking that if you linked this with some of the platforms that share ideas and discuss projects for improvements http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/concepting/weare.sg/#c-3b9a1047feaa386016f7c2897a9e9457 and http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/concepting/dish-in-dish-out-potluck-for-a-cause/#c-5023d04ad856c9a18fdea71115e9d462you could have a good link between needs and resources. Additionally, know-how and wisdom could be exchanged effectively. for example: power drill JE2234-2012 trigger sticks a little be careful! or I have extra blue paint from paint-the-bins event.People might be able to get in touch with others who were able to get something done and learn from them. What do you think?

Hi Christine, thanks for the suggestions. I think my reply to Meena above covers most of what I'm thinking at this point. I would see the concepts that you've linked above as all being able to come under the larger umbrella of Eugene's CRC, but probably keeping their individuality rather than attempting to combine. They would certainly work well together and benefits from physical/online proximity. Thanks!

Hi James totally agree that they need their own sites. I was thinking that since they are reporting on improvements, they can also make known that tools were from the tool library which would spread the word and give more ideas. People reading about improvements may not have the tools or know-how. Likewise people who know of the tools may not know how to help out or even if they should. This is a way to close that gap. d)I also think that this can hook up with the recycling concept. There are always leftover bits and bobs from any project. Paint, nails, screws, brushes and so on. Perhaps 3R could maintain a schedule of what is available, how much there is and where and link this to the tools site. Or perhaps things that are sent to the 3R may see new life and be applied to an improvement project. These would reduce the use of material in general while reaching a wider group of people. e)i am thinking that if someone uses the tool library they pay back a little by contributing with photos and instructions of the improvements and material lists. There could be a way to draw attention to people with particular skills and they could be featured as leading lights. In this way the library can have faces from the community. have you seen this? http://www.instructables.com/

Hi James, great concept! Would be keen to include the Tool Library in the Community Recycling Centers concept at http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/concepting/community-recycling-centers/.Maybe the CRC could be renamed as Community 3R (Reduce, Reuse, Recycle) Center.

Nice one, James -- another one of your concepts made it to the NEA Challenge Shortlist. It's helpful to have an example of where an initiative like this has worked in the past, and inspiring to think of the connections that it could create in Singapore. As you start to refine your idea, think about local champions and educational resources: In addition to the start-up efforts put forth by the NEA, who would be needed from the community to keep this up and running, and how might people learn new skills and new methods that might be needed for the projects they're working on? For more tips on how to iterate and prototype your idea during the Refinement phase, read here http://bit.ly/connect-refinetips and check this Lowdown: http://bit.ly/oi_refine

Thank OpenIDEO! As ever, you're totally right about needing to identify the local champions. I am trying to get a picture in my head about who makes this happen. Perhaps learning more about various apprenticeship schemes would lead to more understanding about where existing skills area are where tools/skills are lacking.Maybe the one way to start is to lower the barriers to entry for all involved - more along the lines of a communal repository for books, furniture, kitchen utensils, strollers etc, and situate in void decks. Would need to contact HDB and find out what, if any, obstacles are in the way of occupying a couple of bays in a void deck and trying the scheme out.Will get working on a layout!

Wow.  I love the community and green aspects of this idea.  A great model for resources that may be shared within communities.  No need for everyone to have the full spectrum of tools.  Similarly, no need for everyone to have the whole spectrum of, say, cooking tools.  Perhaps a cooking tools library with individuals willing to share their niche expertise.  (I'll lend a cherry pitter and even demonstrate how to bake a clafoutis; I'd like to borrow a crock pot for my annual chili potluck...).Would be nice, too, if there were a communal library with goods for new families so that every new family didn't go out and buy another new stroller, car seat, etc.  It could also provide a way for new parents to meet other parents, for parents to share knowledge and resources about everything from time management and sleep techniques to local pediatricians, schools, etc.  In other words, these libraries can also serve as hubs from which social networks could grow.

Hi Stephanie, these are great thoughts. I was at the Open IDEO x Syinc event last night, and a similar idea took route for communal respositories situated in HDB void decks (communal areas found in public housing in Singapore).The Libraries/repositories would be open, inviting spaces, staffed by friendly volunteer uncles and aunties on a rota, who would gossip about neighbours etc. Items (which would include all sorts, beyond simply tools) could be marked in a very lo-fi way with different coloured post-it notes for length of borrowing allowed - a day, week, month, etc... We also discussed expanding the exchange beyond goods, into services and time; people could post their skills - offered and needed, and also their availability. The repository turns into an event space for coffee mornings or mahjong evenings etc.. The above is a very lo-fi idea that needn't even be digital... but I think the original concept has room for a really smartly co-ordinated online platform, professionally operated, involving sponsors, donors, categories, catalogues and user accounts etc. And the physical venues would perhaps involve some kind of all-day f+b facility, run in a co-op fashion perhaps...
Oh, the communal repositories iteration you describe above makes me smile.
sorry - posted prematurely.  I meant to add that I particularly like the social element co-generated by the participation of "uncles" and "aunties".

The West Seattle Tool Library (http://wstoollibrary.org, @WSToolLibrary) offers tools and events/classes.  They also have a mobile library (check out their blog).  To encourage volunteers, they offer credit which I think one can use on tools, classes, and maybe workshop space.

Sounds interesting! I like how the concepts broaden the literal concept of tools to looking at enabling access to knowledge as well. i.e. providing physical landscaping tools like shears can get people to take care of their local gardens and landscapes, but dispensing expert knowledge (through videos) on how to prune, take care of specific plants, etc in the neighbourhood can empower the community further.How about going a step further and providing contacts or connecting people in the neighbourhood with the actual skillsets?

Hi Seng Hong,Thanks for the feedback! You raise an interesting point about the inclusion of professinoal services. Initially at least, I would be reluctant to encourage businesses to market building/maintenance services as part of the tool library; the reason being that the primary goal is to re-capture a sense of personal connection and responsibility for our surroundings. I know the Home Improvement and DIY culture in Singapore is nowhere near as prevalent as it is in places like the US and Europe. This could be for a number of reasons - not least of which is the differing maintenance requirements of detached houses and high-rise apartments. However, I wonder if by removing the cost and storage burdens of owing the tools, we would see a greater involvement and connection between Singaporeans and their environments?

Hey James!Totally agree with you on not encouraging businesses through this. I was thinking more of it being a channel to get to know the people within the community. e.g. "I'll just got to know someone who's great at simple plumbing work just across the street".In a way, it might create even more connections between people living close together. Who knows? Maybe it might encourage a culture of reciprocity ("You did this for me free, so perhaps I should do something for you too!") or paying it forward.

Absolutely..! As well as individual reciprocal relationships, maybe small groups of friends can form too, to carry out bigger tasks. It would be neat to build little skillset icons into membership profiles, so that people can see at a glance what each other can offer.

These elements and the library would be immediately helpful in NYC and NJ right now in the aftermath of Hurricane Sandy.  Loads of volunteers seek to help, many of whom are surely skilled at construction and demolition, many of whom have tools, could utilize and contribute - even temporarily - to the library's tool and knowledge inventory.I like the idea of increasing the inventory by incorporating/permitting temporary contributions in addition to what is akin to a museum's "permanent collection."

Actually, the above idea could benefit from a combo of the tool library, Kirk's #connect my district concept (http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/concepting/connectmydistrict/#c-e3375a5d01725d61dde247563653f9b0), Joana's Help 4 U concept (http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/concepting/interactive-map-plug-in-for-social-networks/), and the need map that Ashley mentioned there (http://needmap.com/demo/ ).Individuals, districts, and various other macro and micro levels of groups and individuals could post and/or find needs in real time and contribute specifically where they want.  this individualization/personalizing of donations enables transparency, so  donors know exactly how their donations are used.  it also allows people to actively contribute, which is often more meaningful and gratifying than just writing a check, and possibly more valuable, too.
Lot's to love here, James! Am especially digging the muck-in days and thoughts around sponsorship.
And I wonder if there could be a way to trigger pride in one's district via some healthy competition for best muck-in projects, etc?

Hi Meena, yes, definitely worth thinking about ading a competitive element in order to help generate interest, pride, and spread the word. The key question would be: Where exactly does the land come from? Would the muck-in days take place on pubically owned land or could portions of privately owned land be opened up to local residents for vegetable gardens etc? Would be good to understand a little more from the NEA the nature and locations of the type of spaces they were thinking about improving when putting together this brief.

tool_library_for_every_district.title: Tool Library for Every District

py/tuple: How easy would it be for citizens to get involved and take initiative for this idea?
Very easy; this would rely on ground-up participation from the beginning.
Somewhat easy; there are ways for citizens to get involved, but an outside organiser may be needed to sustain and grow this concept.
This concept needs to be led and maintained by the government or private business.
Can you build this concept on top of something that already exists, like an organisation, physical space, or system?
Yes. This could fold into, or extend from, something that already exists.
This concept taps existing networks for a few things, but also needs a lot of new processes, materials, relationships, etc.
This concept requires a new system to be built to support it.
After the initial launch and support, could this concept be sustained and cared for over time by the community it's designed to serve?
Absolutely! This concept is easy to keep going.
It depends. There are opportunities for growth, but it's not yet clear how the concept would thrive after launch.
Probably not. A lot of effort would be needed to keep this concept going.
Does this concept create community?
Yes. It naturally brings people together and inspires them to take care of one another.
There is potential to create a thriving community.
No. It doesn't galvanize people to come together for a common cause or interest.
Overall, how do you feel about this concept?
It rocked my world.
I liked it but preferred others.
It didn't get me overly excited.

comments.text: Fun! I totally get the whole idea, but what about designing it in another way, perhaps more portable, so there are no need for stationary expensive equipment like that digital board. Perhaps the only thing required is the peoples own telephone or computer? so you are not required to go to the site of the board to check out the progress of the voting?I totally understand the inclusiveness that can be achieved, in all age groups and in all demographics. But there must be so many cheap ways to use that, and to activate them, perhaps you should watch the " +U " currently in development by OpenIDEO and Sony at OpenPlanetIdeas ?
Johan  might be helpful to provide a link for Cherise to easily check this out?
