flash_mobs_for_social_good_.description: Imagine you are walking down the avenue and suddenly a huge crowd carrying mops and brooms start mopping and sweeping the side walk, picking-up garbage from the floor, and cleaning up gardens and public spaces.
flash_mobs_for_social_good_.creator: 017f79dd3f4a05cd7a9ccf1789ca5b1f

comments.text: Congrats Pedro! I'll be waiting for my invitation to the first Mob Party!
Hi James! Thanks. You'll be on the guest list!

Great idea Pedro. I love the notion of utilizing marketing based solutions, such as Flash Mobs for the greater good. This concept has an endless amount of possibilities in addition to cleaning, such as building homes, re-building communities and planting trees. It is a perfect example of "random acts of kindness" on a larger scale.
Hi Daniel!Thanks for your comments and feedback!

Pedro & Team - we're so sorry that we may have lost some of the updates to this concept over the last 72 hours - we lost the AWS server stack which included the backup and even after working through the night some updates escaped us.  We have put in place some measures to ensure that this won't happen again.We've extended the Refinement Phase to the 27th to give everyone extra time to re-upload their content and to push your concept even further - apologies again if you did lose any updates...

I've just re-posted all the updates and refinement notes. So no major damage occurred here, only some comments were lost and the page stats have changed (applause and views). Our concept is back on track!

Pedro I think this is a great way to get things going and drawing attention in a positive and inclusive way. Some time ago there was some spontaneous dancing at a major junction in the business district in Singapore. That isn't really the kind of thing that happens here. Someone got it on their hand phone and posted it online. Many of the comments were along the lines of "where was I when this was happening?'. Perhaps it does not need to be a really large group of people? Spontaneity may be as important as the element of surprise. It could also be repeated over some time and in different locations so that it can reach more people and the activity is not seen as a spectacle or a one off event. Perhaps instead of a ribbon for the participants there could be some kind of branding on the people who were there. As if just being present means you took part. Joining by default. People would want to collect as many stickers or badges increasing the level of interest and awareness. A bit like collecting DQ points.

Hi Christine,Thanks for your comments! You've made some interesting remarks. I believe that the size of the mob, the secrecy (or not), the schedule, the place, etc., it all really depends on the theme and goals. You can do several regular small events around the city, or you can do like a monthly big event on a central place. All could work. I'm not against badges and stickers, I guess it could work in Singapore, also some kind of DQ points sounds good.
Great builds, guys! Pedro  feel free to update your post at any time to reflect the evolution of your idea via conversations here.
Hi Meena! Thanks! I'm working on it! I'll try to post an update as soon as possible (taking in consideration all the feedback and ideas).
Great stuff Pedro!

Absolutely love this concept. There are so many possibilities, so many opportunities to surprise others, and have fun while doing good! I had made the following comment on another concept (can't find the link anymore): Flash mobs for hawker centres - which I think is more fitting with your concept: "Great idea - simple yet significant. To refine or rather build on this idea - what if there were regular "good citizen flash mobs". One day could be returning trays at a hawker centre; another day could be everyone giving a flower to a senior person; or thanking the bus drivers/ cleaners/ police; and so on. The original idea is really good and this would just add variety and surprise :-)
Hi Vishal! Thanks for your comment! Great ideas for flash mobs!

Pedro, congrats! Your concept made it to the NEA Challenge Shortlist. We liked the way your idea made community fun AND visible -- and therefore likely scaleable and easy to repeat. As you start Refinement, think about how you might get the word out and gather people for these events. How would people learn of the event? How would the group agree on what to do, where to go, and where to meet? How would you make a record of what happened? For more tips on how to iterate and prototype your idea during the Refinement phase, read here http://bit.ly/connect-refinetips and check this Lowdown: http://bit.ly/oi_refine
Thank you! Also for all the great feedback! Time to refine it and hope everybody can join!

This concept is great because it mobilizes people to get together for a shared cause...  The people that you will get to volunteer for a flash mob to clean up a park and doing it for the sake of the cause.  How do you incentivize people to participate?Online badges?  +K on klout or Badges on-line.  Real world momentos or ribbons to commemorate their hard work?  I think that people whom participate in a lot of these great events should be able to wear/display their accomplishments for all to see!

Hi Joel! Thanks for your comment and ideas!I actually didn't think in how might we incentive/motivate people to participate, but I believe that people who participates in this kind of events are not looking for that kind recognition (like displaying badges or medals... well maybe in some cultures I don't know). Maybe I'm too optimistic, but the simple idea of participating and contributing for a better society or to improve your local environment should be rewarding enough. Inspiration might be the key word here.

my guess is that participating is the only reward that some would need as thank you. You just need to find the first pilot group, and that could be found in theatre school or dance classes, those like to entertain and be a part of a group that creates something together. I guess that was how New Yorks Improveverywhere.com got started, unemployed actors, playwrites and drama students
I think key is to find people who really believe in the causehttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fwLkKFn1AWg
Hi Maria,Thanks for your comment (and interesting video).I agree that finding people who really believe in the cause is key.

Hi Pedro,I love the idea, and think that in Singapore there is a mentality that supports this kind of collective grouping together and working on a common issue. The local company I work for sometimes organises weekends where volunteers go and re-paint a run down block of flats, or similar.Having read your posts below and seen that you'd like to keep faith in people's desire to seek out these kind of opportunites without reward, (and keep some level of secrecy) you may not be over the moon about what I am going to suggest (!), but it might help to grow and spread the idea...What if NEA were to act as a facilitator and seek out speficic sponsors for specific community actions on pre-arranged dates, and let these sponsors provide a cup of coffee or a sandwich or something similar? (They needn't necessarily be F+B outlets themselves but that would be a good match).To be honest there is a limit to the number of original ideas you can come up with to keep yourself entertained at the weekends here, and I can see a half day's work with a little bit of free sustenance thrown in, and the chance to meet new people, as being really appealing to most ages, but partcularly families who are concerned to engnender a sense of social responsibility in their children.The T-shirts and Badges thing could work too..for companies looking to use live events to impact their brand image this could be attractive. Apologies if this is seems like a slight coroporate hi-jack.. I guess it does take some of the romance out of the idea!

Hi James,Thanks very much for your comments and sorry for the late response.I  think the idea could work very well for companies, brands and sponsors, but I actually didn't go in that direction because of the nature of NEA. But I guess it would totally depend on them.

I like the fun factor of this concept. I also like the potential for sharing  and demonstration. Alongside the collective joining forces for a shared task this provides a stage for any kind of demonstration. I love the impromptu element of surprise too. I was once in a busy train station when everyone started dancing and it made a lot of people smile :-)
Hi Jen! Thanks for your comment!

For the technical App, you might want to look at +U, that OpenPlanetIdeas started a while back : http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/inspiration/u-2014-openplanetideas/ (it is open source code i think)
Hi Johan! Thanks for your comment. I'll check it out.

Really cool concept Pedro: but we shouldn't forget that flash mobs are attracting because of their secrecy and because of the surprise they create. You need to be careful about how to create the groups... How to join those flash mobs? Can anyone enter? The concept is very good, let's now work on the organization a bit more I would say.But love the ideas of the different themes: would be nice to be able to vote for a new theme for each mob.Can't wait to see this concept becoming tangible

basically, Paul, it depends entirely on how the flash mob is organized, choreographed and performed. See the video in my concept, on how a flash mob can be inclusive and including as many volunteers as possible to cause great party atmosphere: http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/concepting/mp3-tourism/  (please join the discussion in the comment section on my concept, to develop it further, and I will try to add some of my ideas here)

Hi Paul! Thanks!Yes the secrecy of the events in order to keep the surprise factor might be a problem, but if we think in a metropolis like Singapore where we can see on the streets thousands and thousands of people walking around every day, even if there are hundreds or thousands of people knowing about the flash mob, there will be always other thousands not knowing what is going on. And the secrecy might be secondary, if we accomplish to gather people for a common cause and if the mob gets out to clean the streets (or to make some social good), even if nobody gets surprised by it, there's always a positive outcome.And I agree that it all depends on the ways the flash mobs are organized. So how might we organize flash mobs for social good?
Lots of great elements here, Pedro! Loving the idea to engage with seniors  and maybe there could be a way of connecting them with younger mobsters (some kind of inter-generational flash mob idea?)

Hi Meena! Thanks for your comment. (And sorry for the late response.)The idea of young mobsters is great! (I only thought of schools because children always need adult supervision, which can also be solved with some kind of inter-generational flash mobs as you suggested).I think the possibilities here for different themes and ways of engaging people are awesome.

flash_mobs_for_social_good_.title: Flash Mobs for Social Good [UPDATED]

py/tuple: How easy would it be for citizens to get involved and take initiative for this idea?
Very easy; this would rely on ground-up participation from the beginning.
Somewhat easy; there are ways for citizens to get involved, but an outside organiser may be needed to sustain and grow this concept.
This concept needs to be led and maintained by the government or private business.
Can you build this concept on top of something that already exists, like an organisation, physical space, or system?
Yes. This could fold into, or extend from, something that already exists.
This concept taps existing networks for a few things, but also needs a lot of new processes, materials, relationships, etc.
This concept requires a new system to be built to support it.
After the initial launch and support, could this concept be sustained and cared for over time by the community it's designed to serve?
Absolutely! This concept is easy to keep going.
It depends. There are opportunities for growth, but it's not yet clear how the concept would thrive after launch.
Probably not. A lot of effort would be needed to keep this concept going.
Does this concept create community?
Yes. It naturally brings people together and inspires them to take care of one another.
There is potential to create a thriving community.
No. It doesn't galvanize people to come together for a common cause or interest.
Overall, how do you feel about this concept?
It rocked my world.
I liked it but preferred others.
It didn't get me overly excited.

public_exposure_helping_locals_to_fall_i.description:
Public spaces - pockets of land that are often locked away by bureaucratic red-tape. The result? Spaces in Singapore that end up underutilized and looking soulless. 

Let us rediscover and reconnect with Singapore's public spaces!
public_exposure_helping_locals_to_fall_i.creator: fe8ec0e69c561233cd675559b28e1c71

comments.text: The maximisation of public spaces for activities will help our country to be more efficient in utilising our land! This helps make public venues more accessible too. Would be great to see how this idea gets refined.

Hopefully this website will help more local Singaporeans feel connected to their country, as it showcases the different unique shops and attractions of our country. Great initiative by Sharon and her team. :)
Amazing idea! Beutifying Singapore while making Singapore more Prosperous!
Great idea! I hope this gets through, and more places would be allowed to be 'unlocked'. :D

That's great, especially if the existing residents & communities can be brought together to discover new aspects in their space. Those were the days, where we knew which long-kang we could net fishes and tadpoles, where to find the biggest/ baddest fighting spiders.
Thanks! that's a new idea..to allow the public to suggest public venues they wish to "unlock", rather than a top-down approach

Hi Sharon, Thanks for sending me the link to this. I love it! Johan put up an MP3 Tourism concept a couple of weeks ago that I think could tie in really well with the timeline element of your 'Reconnect' agenda.http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/concepting/mp3-tourism/Arjan has a concept also related to imagining uses for existing neglected spaces; he has thought quite deeply about the technicalities of his concept, and I think a lot of this info could be really useful to yours:http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/concepting/sgnal-an-app-to-involve-singaporeans/All this said, I think your concept is unique and appealing in its own way, hope it gets refined too!
And also, thanks for sharing the links to the app prototyping! Am sure they will come in very handy in the future!
happy to James! It was quite fun when I first started exploring these tools. Almost as user-friendly as using e.g. Powerpoint :)
Nice, more filming locations for film-makers
Thanks Daylon! hope this materializes

Lots of great thinking here, Sharon  and it's great that you've considered a feasible prototype to kick things off. And  wow your visualisations are amazing! I'm sure others here are keen to know whether you created them from scratch or have used a website template maker to put them together. (Folks in our community are often keen to discover new tools for sketching up web-based ideas) Looking forward to seeing on more conversations across this challenge...

thanks Meena! I created it from scratch...using Keynote on Mac :) There are tools such as www.balsamiq.com and http://invisionapp.com that others can use to make a quick prototype of websites/mobile apps
Way to go, Sharon  and thanks for the tips for our community!

In this space-crunched Singapore... The lack of a comfortable zone to manoeuvre on a packed peak-hour train; the ever-decreasing area in a unit of affordable housing. The scarcity of space forces us into physical close proximity but perhaps more distant in belonging as we resent the inability to have some private zone. Let's change things around! Originating from the motivation of bringing communities closer together through the creation of a sense of belonging, rethink this lack of space as a moment shared by Singaporeans at a certain place. Rediscover the culture and history of the place, reconnect with the people at that moment. Space-crunched Singapore is not only closer in physical proximity but also more tight-knit intangibly with this shared belonging! :)

public_exposure_helping_locals_to_fall_i.title: Public Exposure! - Helping locals to fall in ❤ with public spaces again

start_a_farmer_s_crafter_s_market.description: Weekly neighborhood markets provide a gathering place for the community, as well as introduce local farmers, artisans, and small business owners to each other and new customers. Not only do people connect more with their food, but their environment.
start_a_farmer_s_crafter_s_market.creator: 395e4483755ef6ae86d845343dd9fc07

comments.text: Welcome to OpenIDEO, Jenine! Loving your highlight that farmers' markets enhance connections with our food, environment *and* each other. Last week I visited a farmers' market while on vacation and it really helped me connect with the city I was visiting in a way that regular shopping just couldn't do. We tasted local honey, chatted to producers and the kids had a go at pressing their own apple juice. We listened to local musicians and visit a van which was collecting local oral histories. It was hard to believe that we were in a location that was recently ravaged by earthquakes.

WOW! A van collecting local oral histories!! That might just be the most amazing thing I've heard of at a farmer's market. What a neat way of broadening the scope of a market. Might you have pictures or know the name? I may just start that up here in Oakland! And thanks for the welcome!

You can read more here: http://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/news/christchurch-earthquake-2011/5401296/Quakes-many-stories-to-go-on-the-record and here's an example of one of the stories put up in written form online: http://www.quakestories.govt.nz/295/story/ I encountered the pop-up van at Lyttleton market  wish I'd taken a photo now!
The van itself was well branded and had an internal booth for recording and folks on hand to give you more information and encourage people to share their stories.
So great! Yet another reason to visit NZ... :)

This is a wonderful idea. I think it would be really cool to combine it with the ideas expressed in: "Community collaboration and skill sharing: Southwark Circle." I made a related comment there...The combination of such a market with knowledge/skill sharing would be amazing. The "oral history" van is right on target as far as what I mean...Combining learning experiences with the farmer/craft/food market experience...The addition I made when commenting on "Southwark Circle" would be to involve the community somehow in the decision of what skills/knowledge is available for exchange based on particular interests--with intergenerational outreach efforts to youth and elders in particular.

Nnenna, I love this, particularly the intergenerational outreach! I've recently been challenged with trying to connect my 99-yr old granma with younger people in her community and have had a tough time. A community market, circle, and gathering place would be ideal.

Definitely! So many communities need more intergenerational interaction. I grew up without grandparents (passed when my parents were young) and people don't realize how lucky they are to have such wisdom at their fingertips. Also, in exchange, young people can energize our elders and empower them to learn new things. Surely a win-win situation!

start_a_farmer_s_crafter_s_market.title: Start a Farmer's/ Crafter's Market

Would you mind sharing some characteristics that make this type of housing different? And how is it changing the way you interact with your community?

Reminded of an article I read recently in Monocle: http://www.monocle.com/sections/design/Magazine-Articles1/Friends-in-high-places/ about Japanese apartment developments which prioritise shared living. You can only read an intro there but I had a quick poke around and found a more info here: http://realtokyoestate.co.jp/shanghai/?p=342 "Two words are to sum up these share houses  Renovation and Community "

social_triggers.description: Bold visual disruptions to urban space, stopping strangers in the tracks of their daily routine and giving them a talking point. A dynamic set of unpredictable temporary visual triggers to stimulate social interaction.
social_triggers.creator: 0d68366e439f762c5fb44b5e266b19f3

comments.text: I like this idea. It also reminds me of another idea that had poped-up in a workshop I was involved in re. how to create interactions between people of different cultures leaving in the same neighbourhood. Evolving your idea to integrate tools to leave comment, needs, ideas etc.. could make your social triggers a tool to detect and organise community projects whithout requiring people too much of their timeHere is the link of a summary of the idea: http://mexicodesignnet.com/proyecto/post-itive-nose/Sorry it's in Spanish.

Hi Anne-Marie,Sorry its taken me so long to get back to you. Happy New Year. This idea of getting different cultures to communicate is huge. I love the fact the web-link you've posted is in Spanish. How great would it be if people could start leaving messages for each other in visual ways with no language barrier........ but also encourage each other to share and learn different languages. I also really like the idea that the triggers would not be time-consuming and that people could stumble upon a new social encounter in a serendipitous way.

You could perhaps hold inspirational meetings or workshops, where you show video and imagery from other cities, that have creative and cool innovative city installations, such as "knittups" from Seattle, and http://www.woostercollective.com/I would love to attend! :)

Like it Johan, I really think this project would have the opportunity to grow and include all sorts of initiatives. Your point about using as a mechanism to celebrate individuality of different cities is great.Woostercollective is awesome

There is also lots of well done TV documentaries, to get inspiration from, or simply to watch and enjoy other peoples creativity in public space from all around the world. There is one french "graffer" called Julian "Seth" that travel around the developing countries and meeting local "graffers" and discovering their history and art traditions. I think it is Canal+ that makes his programs.also lots of independent films available on youtube
Are there any grafitti artists, performers, sculptors with ideas to build on this?

Cheers Nathan,Yeah on the outside, they may just seem like random bits of art, but as long as new and unexpected and inspiring things keep appearing in public space there is a reason for people to start talking. Would be interesting to know what ideas other people might choose to install.
Paddy, I love this idea - it feels really doable. It reminds me of the Elephants sculptures that appeared in London last year. Complete strangers began to connect with each other

comments.text: Gotta say  when I saw the #riotwombles hashtag pop up on Twitter on the back of the London riots, I was about to go to be here in New Zealand. After curiously clicking on the hashtag I got addicted to watching the clean up effort play out via Twitter  plus the tweets of support from around the globe. Extremely moving, energetically active and deeply inspiring when it comes to our challenge topic of Connecting Communities. So folks  what else might we learn for this challenge from communitiy-centered disaster responses?

I think that except the social media impact on our behavior inside a community, there is another interesting point in this post.It's how people suddenly feel part of a certain community when they face some common tragedy / disaster.Maybe we could think of a way to trigger this strong local patriotism and feelings of responsibility and commitment without actual riots or tragedies happening.

sunday_streets_in_san_francisco.description: By closing off stretches of a neighborhood's streets on Sunday, the City of SF creates space to celebrate local flavor. Pedestrians & bicycles roam free, and nearby businesses and organizations coordinate activities along the car-free streets.

comments.text: Lindsey, I think your inspiration is really great. Nowadays lots of people feel stuck in their daily routine, with almost no chance to take a breather. And Sunday Streets gives an opportunity to escape from it. I think such ideas should be brought to life, along with the flash mobs for example :)

Lindsey, That is a great idea. In Chicago we are stuck. The city sold all of our parking meters to a 3rd party company.  Every time the City closes a street for a fair, market or repairs, they ( we) have to pay that company for each meter that was blocked. I heard some festivals cost the city $60K in meter payments.  Your idea is much needed.
i don't understand how these elements of the public space are being sold off. We're put into this weird position where we're forced to buy the space back. Bah
Great inspiration!   Sunday Streets is a great way for people to break out of their regular routine, connect with new people, and open themselves up to new possibilities.
Sunday Streets is such a fun event! Great way to connect with other neighborhoods and just see whats going on around the city.
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Inspiration!
Nice one, Lindsey. And I especially like that it not only connects folks in a particular neighbourhood but also attracts others to come and check them out.
Love this kind of events. There is something special about neighbourhood events that makes you feel so much more engaged than other events.

recycling_improvement.description: IDEO San Francisco recently hosted a brainstorm for our Connecting Communities Challenge.
recycling_improvement.creator: 38498645b598d9c164430d4beee30373

comments.text: Hi Nathan, Meena. I would love to know a little more about how this tagging system could be implemented. So would you be able to track the disposal of individual items from point of purchase to point of disposal? It's sounds a little big-brotherish but if handled correctly could maybe work..Here's a scenario.. most cities now have some kind of public transport card.. Ez-Link here in SG, Oyster in London etc.. what if those cards could be topped up at recycling points using the tags from the used containers of food and drink cartons? I like Meena's build on implementing a competitive angle, and think something along the lines of what I outlined in the concept below could work well with this idea:http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/concepting/singapore-smart-grid-games-sg-squared/The most important question would be where and at what scale to impliment the Smart Bins.. at every HBD? One set per block? Its true that SG is a little behind in recycling when compared with the EU/US, but there is real barrier to clear with rubbish chutes being so convenient to use.. Worth considering in some detail what the ideal distribution is for these bins..

Hi James - You definitely raised some good questions and points in this comment.  Thanks for it.  We discussed putting them on all bins but this is a BIG behavior change.  I love your idea of making only certain bins "smart" as a way to make it a smaller change.   I also like the idea of using existing transportation cards too.  That makes it even easier!  Great additions.You also make an interesting point about Big Brother.  It definitely could also feel like someone was watching, but that all depends on how it grows... certain networks get that perception and others don't, so I don't think it is unavoidable or something that is inherent to this idea.As far as competition goes, it is always a delicate balance between promoting competition and collaboration.  I love your idea of displaying this type of data on screens around the city.  The comments that came from it are really great to read.  Do you think our two concepts could be combined?  They seem to share a lot of similarities.

Hey Nathan, sad to see your concept not make it all the way to refinement, but I think it could be build upon by a few of the ones that did. As well as the Singapore Smart Grid Games concept that I linked above, I think this Community Recycling Centre from Eugene could benefit from a little of your Smart Bin technology:http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/concepting/community-recycling-centers/Hope you can help us all to refine!
Thanks James!  I think the spirit of the Smart Grid Games certainly captures some of what we were thinking.  I've gone ahead and posted a note to Eugene.Great job connecting!

Hey Nathan, just about ready to go for the OpenIDEO Make-a-thon here in Singapore tomrrow. The brief we've been given could make fantastic use of your Smart Bins idea. If you could point me in the direction of any useful info - including technical stuff - it would really get us off to a great start.Been thinking about a build on your recylcing leaderboard, where instead of just points, the materials recycled can be virtually smelted down and built up into armour or weapons for digitial avatar hero-figures that kids can get really into. 'Recyclops' lol. Or maybe even a series of Recyclorsaurous Rexes!Also thinking that by making it child-centric, you might get more kids doing the rounds of elderly people's flats to collect their recyclable rubbish for them, fostering a whole new wave of inter-generational interaction.Keep an eye on the twitter feeds from the event if you can, we'd love your virtual input!Cheers

Wow, that's awesome.  If I were trying a prototype I'd grab some RFID tags and an RFID scanner and set it up in an office setting, but you'd need that hardware so not sure if you can get it by tomorrow.  We'll be keeping an eye on it, definitely tweet at us to let us know what to post.

Hi! I'm a design student at CSU, Chico and I've actually been working on brainstorming similar concepts for my senior honors thesis project. Last fall, I got together with a group of other students to brainstorm ways we could improve the recycling system on campus and I'll be researching the problem more in-depth this coming semester. I'd be interested to hear more about your concept and read more about where you take it in the future. Great to see other people on the same page!

Way to go IDEO SF OpenSTORMERS! As a potential build, I'm wondering whether the trash actions of a floor or building might be tracked rather than individuals. This would still trigger healthy competition (between floors or buildings), may be more likely to enhance community conversations about ways to better manage waste and would get around the potential resistance to being individually tracked.

recycling_improvement.title: Smart Bins

Debbie - we're so sorry that we may have lost some of the updates to this concept over the last 72 hours - we lost the AWS server stack which included the backup and even after working through the night some updates escaped us.  We've extended the Refinement Phase to the 27th to give everyone extra time to re-upload their content and to push your concept even further - apologies again if you did lose any updates...

Thanks for your comments meena and johan! The music is generated like a musical box, where it requires you to turn it in order for music to be played. The only difference is probably that you need more people to turn the merry go round together in order for it to work. Wow, but its so fun if it becomes a merry jukebox where people could upload mp3 where the jukebox can be built in. Maybe we can prototype with some students from engineering school and see whether it works. Alternatively, we could even turn it into a stage for local musicians to perform on it during selected festive events. One way to integrate into people.s lifestyles is making it fun for all. So what if they could dedicate their songs and get it played? Otherwise, maybe we could have different music at different times to cater for different crowd depending on the time? Let me think further and invite my friends to join in.
Great thoughts, Debbie  looking forward to seeing your friends join in... creativity loves company!

Debbie, congrats! Your concept made it to the Shortlist of the NEA Challenge. We loved seeing the way your concept integrates space, different age groups, and a diversity of things people like to do for fun and relaxation. As we move into Refinement, think about how to even further integrate and extend the music merry-go-round into people's lifestyles: What will keep them coming back every day? How will you introduce it in a way that will keep people returning on a regular basis? I don't really see where the music comes from? But I have an idea, that maybe is not possible to applicate? What if persons with smartphones and mp3-players could walk up to this park, and transfer or "upload" one of their favorite songs from their mp3-player, into the merrygoround? And it stays their for 2-3 hours, or for the rest of that day (until it is deleted)Several persons can upload one song each in a small hard drive hidden somewhere inside. And it becomes like a public jukebox.And the mp3-files is deleted regularly to prevent being considered a copyright-piracy.Or you could invite local musicians, to install their own created and recorded music, to let them promote their music all through the playgrounds.How about those ideas? Let me know if I need to explain my thoughts further? :) best of luck!

Thank you very much for a big part of the inspiration to this concept:http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/concepting/stereopodding/If you wish to introduce this into your concept, be my guest and borrow some of it! :)

trace_dream_draw_inspire.creator: 8cf824508d1dcb9e6b824cf6f35bbf7a

comments.text: Your concept is very exciting, and harbors a lot of potential! Definitely something I would participate in if it were ever to be available where I lived. A few questions: how would you monitor these publicly drawn ideas? For example, what happens if I contribute an idea, but the city (or whoever is sponsoring) is unable to interpret the drawings, or I want to provide more details? You have proposed a website: I'm curious to know more. Will I be able to post comments and discussions about my and other's drawings? Also, how would you deal with vandalism? My fear is that the public does not hold enough self control to treat these public drawing surfaces with respect. Overall -- can't wait to see where this idea goes!

Hi Ying Ying,Thanks a lot for your input!I suggested that open drawing areas should always have some form of supervision. During an event there will be assistance, in a shop the shopkeeper or a volunteer would help out participants, and prevent vandalism.The trace-board would mostly be used in groups to brainstorm and build on each others ideas. The supervisor could then select the best proposals, take a picture, and upload it with some explanation to the website.I think we should see the window-painting and public events as temporarily, with the possibility to continue our discussion by uploading the sketches online.Online there is no problem of vandalism, as we upload images to a digital platform. There will be a possibility to flag inappropriate content, and someone will supervise the board.It would be a great idea to allow comments indeed! This way we can give feedback, applaud and discus, like we do here on openIDEO.I hope this answers your questions. Please feel free to share more thoughts!

Hi. How about walking around to cafs and restaurants and ask if they wish to designate one of their windows for this "exercise" ? (temporary instalment for their clients, or perhaps make it a permanent space, to increase traffic into their establishment?)

Hi Johan,That's a great addition! I was playing with this idea as well. These days I'm looking through windows in a different way :DYour idea makes it even better. It would be so easy to do, since almost every shop has a window. The installation can interact with it's environment, but know that there is only one point in space where the desired effect will be visible.I'll add this idea in the update, thanks so much for your input!

In my experience the shops have sometimes shelves and stacked items even in the windows, Perhaps supermarkets being the exceptions to the rule, where often there is between the cashier and the exit door some windows towards the street.thats why i simply said cafs + restaurants. Because they will most always have easy access to one window near the entrance. Diners sitting at tables with a window could sit and draw while they wait their food! bringing benefit and bonus for the business!

I like the fact this could bring in new business! We should try to think how the drawings that the first diners make, could be erased. Staff will be busy, and pretty soon the window might get full.The idea of an event, where the window is used for a 'trace workshop' would work out easily if there is supervisor.Thanks again for your input!

A little weird idea, that combines the above video with the thought of "window becoming full" : rig up a cheap camera, that makes a stop-motion / time-lapse video. and upload it to internet, those that participated in the drawing could pay a fee to receive a link to youtube or buy a DVD of it, to be able to see and share their communal art project :)That way you could find revenue that pays for a few volunteers that walk around between spots and clean the windows and do the rendering of the videos.Potential to add messages in beginning and end of the DVD, for local "green" organisations or similar PBS-announcements. even place for sponsors to print logos on the packaging of the DVD (the actual cafs or stores that have the window and camera at their sites)

I think this direction of drawing on windows is really interesting. What if it was a city-sponsored contest for local residents to make their nearest environment better? They would look out of their own windows and draw on the glass how they imagine their view could change. Maybe they want more trees outside, a 24/7 supermarket or a playground for children. Then they would shoot a photo of the drawing on their window and send it to the local municipality or other contest organizers.This way there would be no place for vandalism and all of the photos would be displayed on-line and serve as a database for future development.

Wout, your concept made it to the NEA Challenge Shortlist. Congratulations! Your concept has the potential to serve as a memory bank that would support a Singaporean identity and story -- really inspiring. Looking to Refinement, we'd love to see you address the potential complications around vandalism. Perhaps this would be "active" during specific times, or it could be used to host local artists and their re-imagining of the space before them. How might you communicate a basic set of ground rules while still maintaining a free, ad-hoc, and inspiring place to meet and create? For more tips on how to iterate and prototype your idea during the Refinement phase, read here http://bit.ly/connect-refinetips and check this Lowdown: http://bit.ly/oi_refine

Thanks a lot! I'm really excited I can refine this concept!I'm doing some tests and talked about the idea with friends. In the coming days I'll restructure the concept, and add new images that tell the whole story. I will implement the challenges on vandalism, and I love the idea to involve local artists!
Great stuff, Wout  and it's fab to to see you iterating the idea already!
Looking foward to heard about the results of the experiment. :)
Me too! I'm happy the concept made the refinement stage. I'll explore the possibilities in the coming days, rewrite the text and add new images.
your concept is very inspiring, would you thought about making a part of wider "drawing" strategy involving other tecnhologies and experiments spread all arround a city/community?

Thanks Clara! Yes indeed, I think it can be used to increase communication between different parties. Yesterday I discovered Candy Chang through Meena, she does the same, but with words. I adore her work.Although - with some guidance - we could prevent the board from becoming a scrambling board, I think there are a lot other possibilities.For example playing with pre-defined outlines that users can move on the board. Imagine two glass panes, and in-between different shapes that can be moved with a magnet. This way people can create al sorts of sketches, and because of the transparency they might interact with the projected environment spontaneously. To add more freedom it's also possible to draw on the board and on top of the shapes.I made a quick sketch to clarify my thoughts, check the other image above.Another thing that pops up in my mind is what would happen if we'd place a tracing board in front of a (slightly tilted) mirror. This makes the background you are drawing on less 'normal'. It would feel more like you're drawing on top of an image, with that image being a fragment of the space around you!The third image is a picture I made when visiting a friends house for the first time this Monday. His dad is an artist, and as a child he used to draw on windows around the house. Some drawings are still present and give an amazing effect combined with the outdoor environment.Thanks for the feedback guys. I think the idea has potential, but needs to be tested and developed further. I might set up a small experiment soon.

Great build, Wout! I wonder whether there might be a way to encourage folks to reflect on the environment as they participate (rather than the temptation for it to just turn into a scrawling board) I'm thinking of initiatives like I Wish This Was... http://www.randomspecific.com/wish-list-fills-urban-gaps Could there be a line or prompt to nudge folks on your idea?

Thanks for you feedback Meena!You are completely right, and I love that you think of a solution right away!What we could add from "I Wish This Was" is indeed a question on top of the board. For example "How do You see this area?" or "Draw your ideal neighborhood". Great link by the way.
I think that drawing might be even stronger than only writing as in the "I Wish This Was". People might get very creative.
Indeed, K!
Thanks Klementyna. I updated the image with a question at the top of the board.What also might prevent scrawling, is a permanent example already present that uses the tracing principle.
Nice one Wout  that's a great nudge!

Nice concept Wout! I actually like this simple version, where people draw with markers. It could be used by municipality or other organizations to ask people how do they imagine their environment could change. Visualizing is a very strong tool!
I really like it too, it's poetic and fun. Also it seems it could be pretty easy to prototype one in order to find out how people react to it and get involved with it.

trace_dream_draw_inspire.title: Trace: Dream - Draw - Inspire [UPDATED]

hop_in.description: A ride sharing program for commuters built on a community-driven platform, complete with personal profiles, verification systems, and user reviews. The goal is to reduce pollution while saving money, and getting to know your fellow community members.
hop_in.creator: a8a845e64668893557aced9b5db82e15

comments.text: Excellent idea. A lot of inspiration can be drawn from the success of carpooling in Europe. I really like the experiment design you've suggested to test the idea. Kudos!

Hi Colin, I love this idea. I am intrigued by the amount of thought you put into using security levels to build trust within the community.In terms of target marketing, for drivers, I was thinking you might want to target young professionals. As far as I know, many young professionals in Singapore service car loan close to 10 years, just to earn a status symbol of owning a car at a young age. They however, find ways and means to save on monthly fuel costs and car maintenance. And the good news is that young Singaporeans are also opening up to the concept of CouchSurfing.com and Airbnb.As for the riders, i see the ridesharing platform as an alternative for the riders whom are facing a taxi crunch in Singapore. And that's also why I love this idea, because it helps to ease 3 problems with one solution. 1)alternative market for commuters not able to get a taxi during peak hours 2)lesser pollution, greener environment. 3)encouraging greater community engagementI echo Johan's thoughts on distributing a written guidelines as a 'code of conduct' for both the drivers and passengers. I was born and raised in Singapore, and thought one essential element when building the community is for both drivers and passengers to be sensitive towards each others religion and culture. Such as if you are hopping on the car of a Muslim driver, you probably want to avoid bringing on board pork or lard.
Great ideas with regards to getting this to work in SG. I like it! I do remember having to compete for cabs while there, which is something I've never experienced elsewhere.

Hi Colin,The principle of lift-sharing is great to start with, and as has been noted below, it seems you're really looking deeper into socialisng the process and stepping up a level from what exists in SF and elsewhere.To give you an idea of local conditions on the ground here in Singapore, public transport (compared to anywhere else in the world, despite a local capacity to whine!) is generally very very cheap and efficient. In addition, cars are incredibly expensive (sometimes as much as 3-4 x US/EU price, after taxing). So I think the social angle really outweighs any cost or convenience issues.Bulding on this (and again what's already been said below) it would make sense to promote this app from the densely concentrated work and housing hubs, and the branding would really have to say something about the type of person you are; outgoing, environmentally consicous etc..To take a quick look at the user functionality, I think it would be great if the driver was able to use the app to send out an alert that tells his passengers he is about to leave home/work in 5 mins, and in turn they are able/required to respond back immediately confirming that they will be either on-time, running 2-3 mins late, or unable to get there soon enough.There is an existing platform that arranges taxi-sharing here. It was launched recently and would be well worth a look as a precedent also.http://www.split-it.sg/homeFinally, I reckon this idea would be well suited to the next challenge concerning health in the workplace too.. kill 2 birds with 1 stone!

so, i guess that you are saying that those that choose to buy a car and choose to drive it alone to work, have done it mostly as a conscious choice to ride alone? or as a status statement? Such persons I guess could be the type of demographic group that don't like to have strangers in their car and "personal space"? *just thinking out loud here*

Haha.. I will try and be more positive, but reading bewteen the lines, I guess I was hinting at that. I'm saying that in order to get a scheme like this off the ground, the selling point has to be the social benefits, as even the lowest ($2-3) nominal contribution to the driver would still be more expensive than public transportCars as status-symbol is a double edged-sword; while there is a negative connotation in that their drivers would be reluctant to travel any other way, there is also a positive possibility that they would be keen to open up and show-off their status symbol to other people by giving lifts. The hardest part of this equation to solve is how to persuade the individual commuter to give up their cheap daily commute (which also provides them with 30-45 mins of facetime with their ipad/tablet), and partake in conversation and meeting new people instead. It's a similar target audience as the Collaborative Commute concept put up by Shelagh, but the choics is slightly easier there as the journey is exactly the same.Perhaps there is value in Shelagh's suggestion of the theme; there really needs to be a connection over shared interests or possibilities...connecting drivers who have questions to passengers with answers etc...
*** I still think this is a great idea in most US/EU cities, but would require very particular tinkering and target marketing here in SG ***

Yeah, I realize your angle, sorry if I formulated myself too bluntly. But your elaboration made me think about the annual "borrow a librarian"-day in swedish public libraries, where you can book/schedule short appointments with a librarian, to ask questions about books or information seeking. and get personalized, customized answers and book recommendations. (i think i will add this thought also to Collab-Commute-concept) thanks for the discussion! I hope Colin can find something valuable somewhere here :)

James, that's a very good point. I was thinking of cities in general (and the commutes to them) rather than Singapore specifically. I actually lived in Singapore for 5 months a couple years back, and what you say is true: the amount of cars per citizen is likely much lower than the global average. I remember being amazed at the prices of vehicles!For Singapore, this could be marketed as an alternative to the MRT. I'm thinking it could also be targeted specifically to those locations that aren't near an MRT stop, which I realize is a small amount.

Also just found some local Singaporean options. Looks like they're both based on a company owning the fleet, and a user renting it for a length of time (short-term... i.e. an hour to a day):http://www.carclub.com.sg/http://www.whizzcar.com/index.asp
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!
Groovy! Thanks :)

Hi. you could try to establish tweet-hashtags for certain highways, for example those that will travel on "M4" into the city center between 7 and 9 on every morning have one unique hashtag. so that people with empty seats in their can contact those that tweeted about a ride request, to agree on a pickup spot before 7 in the morning.  (Just giving rough example here, all the details are up for modification)

I really like this. Ultimately I think there would need to be direct communication between a driver and rider, just for safety/comfort concerns... but as for discovering *who* is driving where, or simple updates (see the coffee comment above), I think it would make sense.Again, could be a great integration. I see the tweets popping up on the home screen of the Hop In! app now...

Great idea.  I am always sitting at my bus stop as numerous cars drive by me who are probably heading to the same place I need to go.  I also understand the issue of codes of conduct while picking people up.  In the casual carpool system in the Bay Area there is no talking in the cars, which defeats the purpose of creating community (and would also be torture for me)   It would be cool if you knew when you were getting into a car whether the drive had an appetite for conversation or just a brief hello.   The more information you can provide to driver and rider to ensure some level of understanding would be important.   SF ride share programs just got hit with $20,000 fines, I think the traditional transportation sectors understand disruption is coming and it is going to be hard to stop it.

Denny, I think the clarity on what type of person is driving the car would come in the profile details page. Maybe there would be a set of questions to fill out when creating one, that paints a bit of a picture for riders and other users. For example, knowing that a driver only listens to death metal on full volume every morning would likely narrow his/her rider pool down a little bit. Those that do ride with him/her know what they're getting into!Also I know exactly where you're coming from when you say "numerous cars drive by who are probably heading to the same place." This is such an untapped opportunity. Think of the clogged highways, and how many of those cars/people are going to the same square mile in the city.

Hi Colin, I love this, and I really like how the verification system parallels that of Couchsurfing.com. I also see a lot of opportunities for branding -- since this is verified, it is more than a cobbled together system of rides, it's an organization that people will want to identify with and tell their friends about. The app and security measures are all part of this -- it would be fun to think about the tone and images used to convey "who" Hop In! is.I wonder, as riders and drivers increase their security standings, if they could start to see real-time locations for available rides, a la Uber cab. Having information about where a driver and passenger is would incentivize the community to increase their security levels, making the whole ride-sharing community function better. In addition to government incentives, I'd love to see Hop In! partnering with workplace CSR initiatives. Maybe companies would buy their employees a tank of gas a month if they could show that they shared a ride at least 10 times in the past four weeks?
Fab thoughts on building mechanisms of trust, Colin! And loving Lindsey's builds here.

Re: branding, I'm with you. It adds an "I'm part of this community, check it out online" sort of vibe to it. Especially with the app in hand, very portable and opens opportunities up to show it off easily. If someone asks how you met your new friend, you can say "On Hop In" instead of "through this ride sharing initiative I'm part of."Re: location tracking, this is another area where people are hesitant to share the information (myself included). That said, knowing you're sharing your location with someone who has verified their ID, their address, their driving ability, and their vehicle details would minimize this.Re: CSR - great idea!

I really like that you thought a lot about different Security measures, to improve acceptance, they could be accompanied by a written "code of conduct" that drivers/car owner and passangers need to abide to.For instance to avoid arguments or awkward atmosphere: interaction is always voluntary. The driver will need to have low volume on radio and respect if some passengers wish to remain silent or listen to their own music in their own Mp3-players or even do some work on their laptopsI do not know about everybodys customs or preferences, but they could become crowdsourced on the site, so everyone locally can adapt them, and distribute these written guidelines, it will help with willingness to try HopIn!

hop_in.title: Hop In!

press_for_help_activating_local_communit.description: Imagine a community where emergency medical help is available from a neighbor you did not know was qualified, immediately on the press of a button. Now extend it to all forms of help with head, heart and hand available and delivered locally.
press_for_help_activating_local_communit.creator: fe5afb3cf734e8c171ffd962a7374f2f
press_for_help_activating_local_communit.title: Press for Help: Activating local communities to volunteer and help

the_good_hood_a_sydney_initiative_inspir.description: Sydneys "Green villages" has created a website and competition, where people can share the environmentally conscious activities or choices their making within their own homes and lives, and then it all gets shared via a map, inspiring and connecting.
the_good_hood_a_sydney_initiative_inspir.creator: a709f138b889ace119bf735f779ac4ab

comments.text: Good one, Steaphan. It really shows how you can connect people and have them share their ideas.

the_good_hood_a_sydney_initiative_inspir.title: The Good Hood - A sydney initiative inspiring a SHARED environmental consciousness

flash_sports_app_for_the_live_linking_up.description: An App/website provides a live update of which local facilities are free to be used (football, basketball, badminton, tennis etc..) and who in the area is currently looking for others which which to play games, and at what times (UPDATED).
flash_sports_app_for_the_live_linking_up.creator: 7e7dcb823cb8bac78bee007e8041492e

comments.text: Great concept James!

Congratulations, James! Your concept made it to the NEA Challenge Shortlist. We loved the way it made more efficient use of space that exists already for activities that are in-demand and healthy -- like sports! Looking to refinement, how might you think beyond the app, and encourage use of free space in offline ways as well? How would you spread the word about the new service, and what networks would need to be in place to support it? Who would be the local champions, and who would liaise with stadium caretakers? Have fun building this one out! For more tips on how to iterate and prototype your idea during the Refinement phase, read here http://bit.ly/connect-refinetips and check this Lowdown: http://bit.ly/oi_refine

Hello OpenIDEO, and thanks so much for selecting this concept for refinement!Thinking a little more about how best to launch such a service, I reckon creating a series of events that are sponsored by apparel brands could be an effective way of creating a critical mass. Nike + gained a huge bump in membership through their 'Human Race' events in 2008/9 where they staged 10k runs in about 25 cities around the globe in order to try and get 1 million people running simultaneously. I would suggest pitching the same concept with sports like 5-aside football and basketball to a big apparel giant like Nike/Reebok/Puma etc. Teams of friends enter a series of pre-arranged and marketed events; when the enter, they must register their profiles into the FlashSports Ap (open to other suggestions on names... 'GoPlay'..?...Nike Play - sounds similar to Nike +, could be an easy modification. I have little idea what the economics of such an event are, but I would imagine the lower the barrier to entry the better - not thinking of these $100 races where everybody goes home with a bag full of toiletries etc.. perhaps a lightweight bib/vest?Another way (initially offline, and free to enter) might be to have an Ice-Cream van approach (not sure this will be well understood in Singapore!) but this could involve an elusive and exciting van that turns up without warning (but with great fanfare) in neighborhoods all over singapore at various times to create pop-up tournaments/matches.. it brings temporary goalposts, scorecards and bibs etc.. kids (and adults) can make teams and play for free but they register their details first. Then they can then download the app. If pro sportsmen and role models for the young could turn up to support these events then even better!The Singapore Sports Council would have to be really engaged and incentivised from the outset for this project to work. This shouldn't be a tough sell, as although the bigger aim is gain more usage of free public space, they can still gain an increase in usage of their chargeable venues like gyms and swimming pools (and associated f+b outlets) under the same app umbrella. Integrating payment/booking of chargeable facilities would be a step for a little further down the line I guess.The area we still really need to understand remains the local champions.. what kind of a person would be evangelicise this service..? how old are they, what is their full time job..is this a full time liason job for some people or do we focus on the users and word of mouth. How would all the venues be catalogued and uploaded? By the app creators or the users? Would welcome some input from someone who understands more than I do about integrating apps into Facebook!We have a great team on board now, would love to hear more input, lets give this a real crack!

James - love this idea as I feel that sports prove a universal means to bring disparate groups of people together.  Along with seeding the concept with already organized local sports teams, organizers, etc.  Nike could create brand ambassadors (as they do in other parts of the world) that earn points for organizing events, playing in games, etc.  Very simply done - the more you organize, the more points you get that can be redeemed for Nike gear (which is another form of Nike advertising, so they are fine with that).  In addition, the idea of keeping stats on some level is great.  People love seeing where they stand among a group because it affords them the opportunity to move up and improve, proving to them that they are providing value.  However, must be careful with making this too competitive if you have some sort of "Player Card" so that you don't run into the problem where people don't want someone to play because they are terrible (based on their "Player Card").  A solve for this: Player Card is based around events organized, attended, etc.Lastly, for those who don't play sports, is there a watching element to this as an auxiliary piece?  On your site can they go through the filter of "Play" or "Watch", then the "Watch" would be organized get togethers at local pubs with a specific game on.

James & Team - we're so sorry that we may have lost some of the updates to this concept over the last 72 hours - we lost the AWS server stack which included the backup and even after working through the night some updates escaped us.  We've extended the Refinement Phase to the 27th to give everyone extra time to re-upload their content and to push your concept even further - apologies again if you did lose any updates...
Re-updated! Sh*t Happens, no worries :)

James, love it!  When I was younger it was easy to find people to play sports, e.g. neighbors, friends.  Today, not so easy : - (  A thought: add a feature to coordinate ad hoc tournaments.  For example, tweet a 3 on 3 basketball event this afternoon or a skateboarding session!  Great way to meet new people who enjoy similar sports!

Another thought: why limit to sports?  enable the process to allow people to coordinate ad hoc music concerts (local bands would love this), art festivals (a way for local artist to share their work), mandarin practice (get people together to practice speaking a language), the "flash" concept possibilities are endless....

Hi Hao Dinh, Agree totally that the ability to set up tournaments and games and record and broadcast progress live would be a fantastic functionality.In terms of spreading the 'flash' concept further, or course there is no reason why the technology could not be used to bring together musicians and artists as well. Whether they would work best under the same umbrella or with seperately branded interfaces would remain to be seen. I have gone into detail about the sports one as we can see the foundations in place with similar precedents like Nike + With Muisc, perhaps a record label or iTunes could create some buzz around an instant band practice flash app for finding jamming mates or new band-members. There must be sites existing for this kind of thing, but linking it with GPS and integrating venues to meet in may still be unchartered territory..I think Sharon's concept - linked below - (and her website) would tie in with this well too.

I continue along in Hao Dinhs train of thought: graffiti artists could team up in new constellations, fine artists that wish to initiate collaborative art projects indoors could also find new associates, for finding new influence and inspiration from other local unknown artistsI would guess an "Art supply shop" or similar would like to sponsor such a section of this concept! Manufacturers of paint could give discounts for the members joining? artists could possibly through this convince manufacturers (with a carrotmob.org-style action) to reduce amount of dangerous chemicals and waste in their production? to get more enviornmentally sound alternatives to paint with?

Hi James, happy to help you out in this e.g. in the prototyping etc :) Sadly my concept didn't get through; but think your idea is very much similar to what I had in mind but with a specific focus (which is a good thing!). In Singapore, there is a trend of a few people booking soccer fields in advance, and "subletting" it out to a network of referees. Each referees then contacts his network of captains of teams in Singapore. Very often, the soccer field is chosen only 1 day before the match. This is by far the only online booking service for sports facilities: http://www.icanbook.com.sg/icbnew/Facility/Public/UI/BasicSearch.aspx?CLR=Y

Hi Sharon, thanks so much for this, it's really a great find. Am sorry your concept didn't make it though, but I hope you can still feel part of this one!I'm really glad to hear you say that remaining specific is a good thing; there have been some suggestions to widen the net into arts and music, and while I think the technology and interface could be near enough exactly the same, given the short timeframe between now and evaluation, I think that focusing on the sports theme and understanding that particular challenge is the way to go. I think sport and the arts would have to be branded and marketed differently in the end.So, looking at the icanbook facility, it seems to have a lot of the essential functionality i'd hope for in the booking stages, but I think the Flash Sports app would have to allow for a whole new level of spontaneity, and encourage the use of free parks especially; the focus would be more on connection; connecting individuals, teams and sports, and the booking facility would be a seemless easy 1 or 2 click action. GPD locating tools would be essential, to give it a touch that FourSquare flavour.Do you happen to know if icanbook is a publically or privately funded enterprise? As in, if NEA is our 'client', would they be most likley to build on the icanbook site (an create an app) or create something totally new?

James by "local champion" I wonder if that might mean people who are involved in informal sports already?There are some spots where people meet to play sports. Perhaps engaging them might be a way to start? The Botanical gardens are teaming with Qigong and yoga groups in the morning. Might this be a spring board? ORThere are also "ring leaders" or "trend setters" (there is a special term Nike applies to the people they watch at the public basketball courts. what is it?). And people with thousands of followers on instagram and facebook. You can search by hashtag for sports or locations. If you get any of them in the fold you have an instant list because when they connect to something everyone else does too. What do you think?

Hi Christine..I think your thoughts on ring leaders, locations and their twitter/pinterest followings could be a step in the right direction. Is the word your are trying to think of - used in marketing mainly - 'Mavens'? or early adopters?Either perhaps the next step is to think in detail about how best to recruit/engage these local champions in the first place, and then perhaps how best to leverage their influence on the platform; how to broadcast their support for the concept to the appropriate target audiences etc... I will try to get some app screen prototypes up and running this week.

James, got inspiration on your "flash sports" concept.  Let me know what you think of the below concept:After reviewing James Robertson's "Flash Sports", Eugene Tay's "Community Recycling Center", Hao Dinh's "Dish In Dish Out" and Maria Malcus "Local Night Markets", I had the below thought on connecting the 4 concepts:Have "flash night markets" (these are night markets that are scheduled to occur in specific communities during specific times) that will enable vendors, both from the community  and from other night markets, to sell their goods.  Great opportunity for community vendors to highlight their goods to their communities and allows vendors from other night markets entry to "new" customers.The entry fee to the "flash night market" is a potluck dish.  Each "flash night markets" will have a theme associated with a community issue.  Once in the market, participants will be able to meet new people, try all the potluck dishes, buy items from the vendors and most importantly, contribute to organized discussions on how to resolve the community issue.  Lastly I was thinking of having an "community recycling center" at the "flash night markets".  The center will educate people on reuse, recycle and reduce.  Additionally people will receive "market cash" for bringing in their recyclables.  The "market cash" can be used to buy products from the "flash night market".  (Checkout "Delicious Recycling" in Brazil http://www.care2.com/greenliving/brazilian-city-offers-vegetables-in-exchange-for-trash.html)What do you gals/guys think?

Great initiative! Personally know of friends who comment that it is often hard to book soccer pitches during the last minute. This would help satisfy any late night sports craving happening in our lil city. May I ask if it is possible to join your virtual team? :)
Hi Sharon! Thanks, and welcome onboard! Let's hope we get the chance to carry this on further with refinement :)

Happy to! Found this after realizing it is a little similar to an idea I posted before seeing this http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/concepting/public-exposure-helping-locals-to-fall-in-2764-with-public-spaces-again/
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!

Hi James thanks for this idea. When I was a kid we used to play kick the can right on the street we lived on. The thing is we all went to the same school and were on the same bus home too. So there was a general understanding of when and where to be. I wonder if you would need a jump start to get to the point where everyone knows where and when. Just at the start. I have heard of someone who started a street soccer league before even booking the pitch. Perhaps the idea of a competition would prompt people to seek out the app and more information. It could start in a community such as a school but be open to anyone to join. The potential for the app for spontaneous joining-in could grow from there?

Hi Christine, am definitely keen to make it as inclusive as possible to spontaneus arrivals. It would be great if there was simply an understanding of when are where to go. I think that these days, perhaps because we all have (in mobile phones) the capacity to alter plans while keeping everyone informed, people tend to be a lot more fluid (flaky even) in their time-management. I hope an app could help bridge the gap - jump start as you say - and restore these local communal kick the can games!

Hi James, yup I really like the idea of an app that let's people know where there might be something happening at a court nearby. I think this does build connections and a sense of belonging. Which I think leads to care for the space. This succeeds on the strength of the network of users. Perhaps there is a way to piggy back on an existing network such as a school?

Hi James and Christine.  I like this idea - social, healthful, inclusive.  I wonder if you could/would incorporate the option of spontaneous organization?  Sometimes, people are free and energetic but don't know what to do with the available time or how to find people who might be interested in a game.  So, for example, if I found myself with free time or with a free pitch because my friends flaked out, I could post a notice of "kickball at the Sheep Meadow in Central Park now" or "ultimate frisbee today at 4 in Coney Island" (or the Singapore equivalent).

Hi Stephanie..Thanks! You really get this! That's exactly the type of functionality I had in mind. It's about removing the barriers of not knowing whether A) the facility is free, or B) there will be enough people around for a game. Hopefully this allows for more spontaneity.

Maybe we could each try this in a proto form this weekend, e.g., through Twitter?  Since I run and sometimes like to run with others for both the social and motivating aspects (it's motivating if I know someone's expecting to meet me for a run at a certain time & place), I could tweet a run at a specific time and place in Brooklyn, NY this weekend, see what happens.  You could try similar in Singapore?

Yes, please include some "scenic route"-options for runners, dogwalkers, bikers and skateboarders, to initiate more social exercise for them! and to give them more nature experience during their routes that can be boring if they just follow the same path each time
Dog-Walking! Great shout...! that could surely be an app/concept in itself! You could either go at the same time with a friend, or cover for each other when one is short of time/away.
Stephanie, love the idea of starting to try stuff! I am fairly new to this hash-tagging, so could you help me by saying what your brooklyn one would sound like?

If any game venue suddenly gets 3 teams, perhaps they can design a spontaneous miniature tournament inside this "app"?The team that is on the sidelines could meantime volunteer to pick up trash around the park, while waiting for their game time ?(or similar micro volunteering that requires no effort or equipment)

Love this idea! There is an empty field in Kembangan, somewhere in Singapore, where random residents would meet together on weekends to have a game of soccer. And these games are very spontaneous. Players differ in age, occupation and it was a superb way for the community to get to know each other better.I find your idea somewhat similar. There are many games which require partner/partners and I'm sure your initiative would not only help these people but also encourage them to find others to play. Exciting!

Thanks Angela! I think it would definitely encourage more use; I'm now trying to think more on how it might allow residents to make Singapore 'cleaner and greener', as apposed to just making the population healthier. I guess running around outside burns calories insteas of kilowatts (on the playstation!) so this is a start...

Yeah, that's a tough one. But encouraging our society to be healthy is very important and beneficial too! Esp Singapore. And everyone gets to interact, as opposed to just watching tv alone at home and munching on fat snacks. Haha

Great thoughts, James. Kind of like a looser, serendipitous more timely MeetUp with a sports focus  and I'm thinking there could be features to track favourite venues, form groups, check in a la Foursquare, post photos, etc Lot's of possibilities here!

All of the above! Thanks Meena. I will need to take a closer look at the functionality of those apps as am not as yet a user, but creating groups that could be called upon regularly to give availability and start conversations would be critical I think. Could go into a bit more depth on UI design over the coming weeks as a next step :)
Looking forward to seeing things evolve!

flash_sports_app_for_the_live_linking_up.title: Flash Sports - App for the live linking up of local sports facilities' availability with residents

py/tuple: How easy would it be for citizens to get involved and take initiative for this idea?
Very easy; this would rely on ground-up participation from the beginning.
Somewhat easy; there are ways for citizens to get involved, but an outside organiser may be needed to sustain and grow this concept.
This concept needs to be led and maintained by the government or private business.
Can you build this concept on top of something that already exists, like an organisation, physical space, or system?
Yes. This could fold into, or extend from, something that already exists.
This concept taps existing networks for a few things, but also needs a lot of new processes, materials, relationships, etc.
This concept requires a new system to be built to support it.
After the initial launch and support, could this concept be sustained and cared for over time by the community it's designed to serve?
Absolutely! This concept is easy to keep going.
It depends. There are opportunities for growth, but it's not yet clear how the concept would thrive after launch.
Probably not. A lot of effort would be needed to keep this concept going.
Does this concept create community?
Yes. It naturally brings people together and inspires them to take care of one another.
There is potential to create a thriving community.
No. It doesn't galvanize people to come together for a common cause or interest.
Overall, how do you feel about this concept?
It rocked my world.
I liked it but preferred others.
It didn't get me overly excited.
