give_your_seat_away..description: Turn passive citizens sitting in the MRT into active contributors offering their seat to people who need it more.
give_your_seat_away..creator: 44dc10596d8e5b9e5671363f7fbbfd46

comments.text: Maybe some social advertising campaign could help with this problem? Posters inside trains or buses?

There are many campaigns and posters and as many reasons that they might not be having the desired effect. FLASHMOBS!  but how about a disbursed flash mob (oxymoron?). Members could be anywhere but whenever someone doesn't give up a seat they sing a special song. This isn't meant to shame a person but to be a fun, non aggressive way to make the point. Or even better whenever someone does give up a seat the members go into a celebratory song and dance.

I like the idea of the positive flashmob song! That would be really encouraging for people to give their seat away. I would give my seat away in the hope that the flashmobbers would be in my coach :) This idea might add to the application, as a strategy to make people aware of the app & the behavior they need to change.

I love it! I can imagine a sort of "secret following" that are having a sort of secret hand signal, that they use when they climb into a carriage, just as a "check" and "salute" if others in the carriage are involved.  This could be experienced by the individuals like a very tightly knitted group community, but without actually haveing to be social or participating in meetings or close contacts with strangers if they wish to not be socialising. But just knowing and being aware that others in the subway are "just like them" :) Cool, Cool, Cool! (please let the involved choose the name and choreograph/develop the "secret" signals, for higher sense of inclusion and "ownership" of the project!)
This would be a lot of fun in the MRT :)
The positive flashmob idea is great! Nice way to 'educate' people, but also it sounds really fun for others on the train.
I wish there was a subway system in my town, I wish to start this now!
Great to have you join us with Singapore-centric issues and solutions, Annet  and we're digging your visualisations too!
Thanks :)

Great! your infographics are very good! prooves your point. How about if you could use some ideas from my concept proposal here: http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/concepting/design-new-high-five/  Letting the citizens have workshops to choreograph new hand signals/salutes/high-fives that can become signature for Singapore especially :)

Cool idea you have Johan! I think indeed that our two ideas can be mixed/used together. I find it sometimes difficult to attract attention in the MRT when I want to give my seat away. It is crowed all the time and waving/pointing does not always help or attracts the correct persons. Besides, pointing can be seen as rude.

cleaning_up_estonia_in_5_hours.description: 2 individuals in Estonia decided it wasn't the government's job to clean up Estonia, it the responsibility of citizens, so they set about making it happen.
cleaning_up_estonia_in_5_hours.creator: f2e37cc20bcb68224b419d5f74fb9243

comments.text: Indeed  great Inspiration. Was also posted earlier here: http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/inspiration/collectivism-x-cleanup/ and we can understand why it's so popular! Looking forward to what these posts will inspire from others & conversations they might spark.

i live in Latvia, and there's a similar clean up here as well (not very surprisingly, as Latvia is Estonia's southern neighbour and both countries have some similarities). Probably the origin-story of Latvia's Big Clean Up differs slightly, but the basics are the same. In a fairly short time, it has grown out to an enormous event, sponsored by big brands and many people participate. Even many companies have organised days where they bring their employees to a certain place and clean that up. What the big clean up events in the Baltic states (Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania) show is that if you can find something that speaks to the people, market it wisely and get support from press and sponsors, it can grow certainly into a big movement.

I like the idea but whether it can be sustainable amongst the busy and hectic lifestyle of people in Singapore. we rarely have time!  I guess the key to this kind of initiative is who starts it and whether it can evolve organically in Singapore.
Love this - such an incredible story.

This is so inspiring! It also seems like it could work well in the Singapore example because it's also a fairly small nation, both in terms of geography and population. Maybe this suggests that forming micro-communities could be a good approach to the problem?

superkilen_urban_park_by_big_architects.description: 'Superkilen' is a kilometer long park situated through the Nørrebro area just north of Copenhagen's city center, considered one of the most ethnically diverse and socially challenged neighbourhoods.
superkilen_urban_park_by_big_architects.creator: 8b117a937cd68c04bc2616c6e701615a

comments.text: I especially love how the surrounding nationalities of the residents were incorporated into the design of the park. They didn't just rely on typical park furniture and fixtures, but took clues from distant cultures.  What a fantastic way to create a place that reflects the local neighborhood."The people living in the immediate vicinity of the park relate to more than 50 different nationalities. Instead of using the designated city objects/furnitures used for parks and public spaces, people from the area was asked to nominate specific city objects such as benches, bins, trees, playgrounds, manhole covers and signage from other countries. These objects were chosen from a country of the inhabitants national origin or from somewhere else encountered through traveling. The objects were either produced in a 1:1 copy or bought and transported to the site."http://superflex.net/tools/superkilen
Wow, interesting approach. Is there anything known about the results/impact it had on life in the neighbourhood.
Unfortunately, I simply read this on a website, and I don't live in Copenhagen. It would be nice to get some feedback indeed.
Especially interesting to read about the suggestion box component. I wonder if there was a process by which citizens could view and discuss each others suggestions?

weekend_community_markets.description: The Salcedo Market is set up every Saturday in this neighborhood in the city of Makati, Philippines. Vendors gather together to sell their goods - bread, cakes, fresh fruits and vegetables, decorative plants, etc.
weekend_community_markets.creator: 5aca5956f65fbd3e4ebeaac463f7a4c1

comments.text: I've heard about similar events in the US where people cook up amazing dishes and then have a community 'food swap' ... food is always a great motivator for interaction :-). An unfortunate by-product can be litter left after the event, however - how does your community deal with that?

Hi Melody, thanks for raising this point. I regret that I do not have an answer to this. I have written to consult one of the vendors who might be able to shed some light. I would imagine there is a system as this is set up every Saturday. Hope to have an answer for this soon. Thank you!

This is to credit Marco Lobregat (Ministry of Mushroom) for obtaining this information from Tricia who sits in the Women of Bel Air Assc. that runs Salcedo:"Hi Marco,We pay a garbage collector to pick up the trash every Saturday. Part of your rental contribution goes toward that.You might also want to tell them that in line with our NO PLASTIC campaign, we will be purchasing more trash cans to start educating our marketgoers on trash segregation. ( We still have to identify what makes up the bulk of our trash in order to make segregation effective.) And since we require our vendors to use reusable/biodegradable packaging, we help lessen trash that goes to the landfills. Lastly, a mobile junk truck will soon be parked at the Jaime Velasquez Park every Saturday to encourage Salcedo residents to get rid of their unserviceable and bulky junk items. We are just awaiting the go signal from MACEA to start this."

weekend_community_markets.title: Weekend Community Markets

eco_market.description: Singapore's night market with an Eco-friendly twist. A space to get together for food, fun, games, music, art and friends of the community.
eco_market.creator: a802c28a27d6f1f89e2acf59c9f4c7ce

comments.text: Hi Diana, great concept! I think the point you bring up about Singapore being one of the only developed countries that doesn't encourage the use of reusable bags is a really good one. I would love to use that as a touchpoint for Ecomarket: If people bring their own bag, they get a free treat or a memento that they can display that shows they went to the Eco Market. Free marketing! And an incentive to change behavior.
In the Fairprice near my house there is a special check out for bring-your-own-bag. That queue is always much shorter which of course encourages more people to bring their own bags!

Thanks, Lindsey for your ideas. Will certainly brainstorm further along the lines of incentivizing citizens whom bring their own reusable bags.Hi Maria, I did not notice the Fairprice that I frequent has such an intiative. thanks for letting me know.  As a Singaporean, and having traveled out to other developed countries, I think Singapore has alot to catch up in terms of this aspect.

Great discussion guys! Diana  you can make edits to your idea at any time by hitting the Update Entry button up there on the right if you're keen to add ideas from collaborative comments here. Plus you can give any credit you feel is due, as your idea grows, via the Virtual Teams field. Looking forward to seeing this fab idea grow.

Hi Diana,Have you heard of the farmer's market opening up in the spring? (http://www.facebook.com/PasarBella) That will be a really good test run for your concept! If people are willing to travel to a specific location for food shopping, they would of course be willing to spend the money when the market happens right on their door step.I had this idea of utilising the existing Pasar Malam concept... overlaps a bit with yours and I think some of the ideas could be combined. http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/concepting/pasar-malam-reinvented/

Hi Maria, I think we are both conceptualizing along the same lines!  I would love to keep the concept of pasar malam, as it is a distinct Singapore identity, but with the hope of making them greener. Great to know someone whom also think it's time to reinvent the pasar malams in Singapore.I love your lend&borrow concept - adds to the concept of eco-friendliness and bringing people together. We can probably collaborate, combiningg your lend&borrow concepts, and perhaps also if you other thoughts on how we can better reinvent the pasar malams?

Glad you like this, K! Just watching the video and the little gardens made me smile, so I can imagine how joyous an experience it would be to see a real pothole garden... :)

GREAT GREAT Idea. But unfortunately in a city like Singapore, where the weather is a problem and the National Environment Agency goes about the city cleaning everything, this will become a problem to the city rather than beautifying it.

innovate_around_the_community_s_big_data.creator: c86ad7f3acf31d8f14fa371451c5f59a

comments.text: I think this is an interesting idea to work on, but the idea cannot be taken too far, otherwise people would start to feel that they have no privacy and such.

Hi, I'd suggest the feasibility of any idea stemming from this concept is dependent on the underlying (opt in) value exchange. The basic exchange would be personal information in exchange for a (personalised) service. If the service if sufficiently valuable, people will be willing to share their personal information. Hence the popularity of facebook etc.; despite privacy concerns, people deem the ability to interact with their friends and brands online a sufficiently valuable service. In today's world, there is growing number of value exchanges that are based on personal information. The future, will contain even more...  It goes without saying that a level of trust between the service provider and the individual is required; trust is the catalyst for the value exchange.I agree though; a misuse of trust / invasion of privacy could potentially have nasty consequences.

Interesting Eoin. Perhaps you might add a link directly to your post in case folks want to easily check out more? Tip: to activate links in your post, hit the Update Entry button up there on the right, then follow the instructions here: http://bit.ly/oi_link
Hi Meena, thanks. I've updated the entry with a link. I wasn't sure what the "done thing" was regards linking out of the site.

comments.text: Hey Kim, perhaps there a way to enable people to 'Check In' to whatever public transport they are taking and then join into some of group discussion board or daily activity. I love the idea of the train carriage or the back of the bus becoming a new 'water cooler' moment of the day to chat, gossip and share.
Good Idea Kim! A problem that quite prevalent here in London as well !! The tube experience would be much be better only if people would interact and connect more!!

Hello Kim!Nice idea! I have a friend who's working on a thesis project on improving Social Interaction on buses in Singapore. This is a problem we experience here in Singapore after the proliferations of smartphones. Love to hear more about this topic!

Interesting thoughts Kim  looking forward to hearing more developments on this in the upcoming Concepting phase. Make sure you post it again there too  and meanwhile you might like to check out the Feed Your Idea section here: http://bit.ly/oi_inspire Hoping to see more of you on OpenIDEO!

Beautiful work!I like the idea - but how would you keep people from becoming somewhat self-righteous about sharing all the "good" they're doing?  I could unfortunately see it becoming a competition for who's the MOST X-TREME do-gooder.  Have you thought about how to keep things from becoming too image-based, and really focus on more awareness that can lead to granting people more beneficial, positive lifestyles?

sgnal_an_app_to_involve_singaporeans.description: SgNal { ˈsignəl| } is a mobile app to engage citizens (and visitors) of Singapore with the city. It asks people to signal opportunities for improvement and interact with vacant lots and buildings.
sgnal_an_app_to_involve_singaporeans.creator: 6fed0e6f1ba44f0520bc14fceee3663d

comments.text: Made me think of this!https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MvVuE4WooaI

Great idea! Sort of "OpenSingapore"I like this more engaging update you added (chess-play), maybe it could make a place for potential volunteers? Not only signaling the opportunities but also offering help. Something like 'I think this X place could become a communal garden and I'm ready to help make it happen'.
Oh, great idea. In addition to organising a fix. Thanks for the great build!
your concept is more and more becoming like +U ! :D i mean that in a good way. And +U is open source code ;p *nudge, nudge*

Great concept! People here in Singapore are crazy about their smart phones and apps so I don't think it would be difficult to convince people to get involved. As somebody mentioned in the Inspiration phase, a lot of Singaporeans like to complain, so I think the "report a bug" function would be appreciated and could turn the complaining into something positive and constructive.

Wow, Maria, thanks for the local insights! Very useful. And the 'report a bug' function combined with the 'organise a fix' could help the people to take action. Good to hear there's potential for this one! Any other comments or local insights are welcome. Do you think there should be something additional?

There is actually not much space in Singapore which there are no plans for... the URA (Urban Redevelopment Authority) have master plans for development of Singapore years in advance and nothing is left to chance. Never the less, I think it's great if citizens can have input before something is actually built! Often signs are put up of what the new development is going to be. I was thinking, maybe the plans could be posted at the site much earlier so that citizens can voice their ideas in time. Littering is not a problem in Singapore at all so I really like your update to the meet-up! Maybe there could even be an alert function for events (such as a chess playing flash mob). There are always things going on around town, cultural and religious festivals, temporary exhibitions, food festivals etc. I think it would be great if there was a way for people to alert others when they bump into something interesting. And the app allowed you to set preferences in advance so you could be alerted if something was happening nearby, in your area of interest or whatever your preferences are. (It is moving a bit away from the original idea and maybe should be its own app, though...)

Great thoughts, Maria. The report a bug function is also to signal things that are broken (street lights, potholes, you name it). The littering was indeed something I found was not an issue when I visited Singapore.I like your idea of collaborating with the URA. It would be great if people can help inspire future plans, by interacting with the URA through earlier notices on sites or maybe even through the app with the 'Share your inspiration function'. That could turn into some sort of mini OpenIDEO by itself.As for your entertainment alerts, I like to have these alerts when it's related to fixing things, or maybe events that are related to improving the community. And you're absolutely right: an entertainment events alert app would be a great stand-alone app/concept!Thank you for adding so much valuable local insights. I've only visited Singapore once, a few years ago, and your input is absolutely valuable.

Agree with Maria that nothing much's left to chance in terms of urban planning in Singapore. Love the idea of an alert function to events! Plus lately there's been a flurry of indie events in Singapore and I'm sure many would love the chance of using an abandoned space  and dress it up in any way they like it.
Loving the way that numerous posts from our Inspiration phase have been built upon here in an app-licious way, Arjan. And the name rocks!
Thanks, Meena! I wanted to do something with the 'SG' designation, and the rest came quite quickly after that.
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!
Hurray! Thanks for that!

good one! good combination of ideas!Regarding the matchup-fixup, i was also thinking about a matchup-addon, if a person is member of a chess-club or similar (on their facebook) they could be able to mark a GPS-location+take a photo when out in the city, and simple clicks in the app to match with the chessclubs facebook-group (foursquare?) so as a suggestion for the other members of the chess-club to plan and schedule a field trip to that location and bring their boards and have an afternoon/evening at that location and play, and have open-invitation for new members to their chess-club?    (replace chess with any other type of game, sport, event that is social, inclusive and equal-opportunity)

Oh, that's an interesting idea! Maybe even so interesting it deserves it's own concept.In this one, I can see it as an additional feature. There could be someone that sees a certain vacant spot and thinks 'hey, I wish this was a chess-play area'. Then, she'd use the app to share that wish, and also to invite friends for a game at that place. Not only stating her wish, but taking action to make it reality.If her initiative is successful, it would be a good sign that the place in question is indeed ideal for a chess-play area.
I don't think it needs a separate concept or app, just design the framework as loosely and flexible as possible, the users will be able to adapt and use it if they will find a need for it :)

Well, I really liked your idea as a building block. And I think others can use it as well. Given the nature of how phases evolve on OpenIDEO, it might be easier for others to find it if it's a separate concept, in stead of hidden away in this one :)

sgnal_an_app_to_involve_singaporeans.title: SgNal - an app to involve Singaporeans

comments.text: The author Jane Jacobs once wrote a book call "The Life and Death of Great American Cities". This book explains how to build architecture, art, and culture can lead to an improved quality of life for everyone involved. The more eyes on the street the safer the street. The safer the streets the more people who will be walking around. Philadelphia has tried to do this in the Philadelphia Mural Arts Program, one of the biggest city wide mural programs in the world. I really suggest anyone interested in this read Jane Jacobs revolutionary book.

Thanks for the suggestion, I will most definitely check it out... It does make me think about pop culture and how it has influenced our society, values, etc. But I do agree that arts can act as great motivator for pride.
Great thoughts about what might inspire city pride, Nabil!

Hi, glad that you like it. When you do a search on 'green graffiti', you quickly find an other option for ecofriendly mural art. It is called 'reverse graffiti' and   is offerend commercially. The idea is basically to clean images into the dirt with high pressure water. The method is pretty cool, but having commercial messages everywhere, even in the dirt is less so, I think Still, it might be worth to have a look at it for inspiration, for example here: http://greengraffiti.com/
Really cool concept  ! It's unusual way to express yourself by natural organic things. I hope that "Moss Graffiti" will replace typical spray graffiti which harms the environment.
Florian, love this post!  Ecofriendly way to express your "art"!  A possible good option to "moss up" singapore as a way to communicate our challenge?
Looking forward to what you all might come up for the Concepting phase on this!

stereopodding.description:
Have you ever been curious about what the other commuters listen to in their earphones?
Curious enough to ask them if you can eavesdrop?
stereopodding.creator: 656863f55543ea22d1dbce290f237277

comments.text: I think this idea is great because it enables other commuters to interact and gain the social aspect in which has been lost. Great thinking!

Hi, thanks for the comment. Would you be able to test it in your city commute? You basically only need 2 extension chords, with the standard earphone-plugs. Colour code the ends, perhaps with plastic tape, as guide line, to prevent any hassle.

I glanced at a couple other concepts that revolve around the commute (the "Collaborative Commute" and the "Silent Clubbing in MRT Trains")...the idea of redefining the commute into an opportunity to connect is potentially powerful. Just to throw another idea into the mix (non-music related), each train car could have a theme. One could be for readers, another for socializers, another for green enthusiasts, another for entrepreneurs / business oriented people, and perhaps some surprising ones (clubbing or singles) that represent Singapore's diverse demographics. Each car would be clearly labeled. It is a way for commuters to find connections or a reason to strike up a conversation with fellow passengers. Or, sometimes, simply a place for introspection (to zone out or nap)...

Hi Johan, I really value the physical connection one can have with strangers by physically sharing music, although my first thought was that this connecting would happen through an online service. From when I was in Singapore this summer I observed that nearly everyone has a smartphone and a dataplan, so it might seem like the obvious route. But on the otherhand the physical devices do represent the existence of the service, while a cloud service would be invisible. The thing that would hold me back from participating in such a service is that I am often ashamed of the kind of music I listen to and would be reluctant to share, and there must be others that feel the same way. But how might we break down this barrier or creative incentives for using the service? I would love to listen to other people's music though because for me the incentive is that I want to learn about new to me artists and music. It could also be a great way for upcoming artists to promote themselves. Just some of my thoughts.

You are not allowed to share copyrighted music online, that is theft = piracy. But playing up the music that you got on your own mp3 to them is legal and not a piracy act.Thank you so much for the input and thoughts. I appreciate it a lot, will keep it in the back of my head for possible improvements.Really like the thoughs about a "shame-playlist"! I heard that "online-player Spotify" lets you have one "shame-playlist" that is secret, but you can share how many other playlists that you like with your facebook- and twitter-friends.Perhaps you could prepare one playlist on Spotify or Pandora or similar music service, write the address down on back of your business card, and if someone you ride with asks what music you listen to, you could give them that business card, and keep your "shame-songs" privately???Do a lot of people in Singapore use Spotify or Pandora? or is it mostly in Europe and USA those services exist?

I like the thinking behind this concept :-) I often end up sitting next to another commuter who plays their music really loud but often appears to be oblivious that others can hear. By curiosity - I think do the know others can hear this? It's also interesting when you can hear their choice of music - would I have associated them with that genre of music? I think we often become locked into our own little bubble while travelling and positioned in close proximity of strangers and like the playful interaction this concept proposes. Bringing people out of their own little bubble or enabling them to share their bubble with others.

How would you consider the "question" or "proposition" that commuters could, perhaps with a hand signal, display their request of "eavesdropping" onto a fellow travellers music? I mean, if I am sitting, listening to music, I would not be able to be contacted with a question. Curious person would need to show me, with a hand, that they wish to listen?See my other concept, of Letting people choreograph new "high-fives". and think what is possible to to with this music-concept?

stereopodding.title: Stereopodding

flash_mobs_for_hawker_centres.description: A positive and inclusive way to create a new standard. A mob all over a hawker centre returns their trays all at once.
flash_mobs_for_hawker_centres.creator: 0a4b80cd7f54c8d0c401308a71160ece

comments.text: Nice one Christine  and I'm digging the local insights on this. Music would really make this shine!

Hi Christine. I'm looking into what's going on here. Given our team is globally dispersed, things always take a little longer than expected ;^) Meanwhile  thanks for being so understanding and participating so generously in Refinement  with the great energy and positivity you've shown across the challenge. I'll get back to you as soon as I know more.

Great idea Christine - simple yet significant. To refine or rather build on this idea - what if there were regular "good citizen flash mobs". One day could be returning trays at a hawker centre; another day could be everyone giving a flower to a senior person; or thanking the bus drivers/ cleaners/ police; and so on. The original idea is really good and this would just add variety and surprise :-)

Thanks Vishal. The bigger objective, in a way, is to plant the idea that each of us can get things done. We don't need to be told we like clean tables.  Engaging in a group may foster more trust. People may be reluctant to be the only ones doing something. There may be a sense the effort of the individual will make little difference.The tipping point can be beyond the hawker centres. It can be a sense of personal empowerment for the good of the whole community. It has to start somewhere. So all-together-now!

dish_in_dish_out_potluck_for_a_cause.description: Food/Eating is important for Singaporeans.  Thus let’s encourage “potluck” meals [Dish In] in the community that will bring people together to discuss and implement ideas that will make their environment better [Dish Out].
dish_in_dish_out_potluck_for_a_cause.creator: b25ffa68ad761f8578cc61700c0140ed

comments.text: Thank you everyone for your contributions!  We were selected as a WINNING CONCEPT!

Hao, Great job! I think a program where communities can begin interacting face to face is key to solving issues. As much as I love technology, nothing beats true human contact to gain a better understanding and solving social problems/issues/concerns.

True true Ketu. People actually talking to one another even if not to solve an issue. The coffee shop used to be a larger part of our communities. You just plodded along to your local, not unlike on tv, only more colourful and possibly louder. You knew the people and they knew you. That this has faded somewhat is the way of modern life i suppose, the tech gizmos don't help, but it's great to read so many people interested and willing to take part in this idea.  And it's because of the tech that this has happened right? so an opportunity created from an obstacle.

I love this idea! Would there be availability for door-to-door flyers as not everyone has access to internet or would know where to begin? Potlucks always bring people together and food makes people happy. Happy people are more open to discussions that could enable community action on the "topic of the night". Great job!
Fantastic  Hao Dinh! Thanks for putting it all together.

Hey Hao- Do you think some marketing materials would be helpful too? Maybe some DI/DO notepads/pens with the website address on them to bring to the event for participants to use. The pens can also be distributed at area restaurants to spread the word.
I like!  Will add to the marketing section of DI-DO.  Thanks!
Thank you everyone for your assistance and great ideas!  DI-DO looks great!
Outstanding slides. It really brings your the overall concept together! Good Luck!
This is great idea. What if you got a famous or great chef in every community and they donated the food they make to the community.
Priyank, interesting idea on how to nudge people to organize and/or attend a DI-DO event.  Can you brainstorm with Team Ketu to determine more ideas on this topic?  Thanks again!
Priyank and Team Ketu, thanks for the suggestions on how to get people to attend the first DI-DO events.  Added your recommendations to the overall concept description.
Thanks! We really enjoyed working with you on this very fruitful endeavor.

I like how this potluck creates an atmosphere for idea creation and the ability to bring people together, through a warm setting, to share different thoughts and solutions to help with problems specifically affecting the community that the potluck is held in.
Dipti, a common feedback theme is how potlucks will create, as you mention, an open environment for creative discussions on topics!

This seems like a great idea. There are always people out there that have good ideas that would help the community but don't have an outlet and/or the motivation to get out and voice their opinion and this is the perfect way for them to do so. The atmosphere created from this potluck will allow them to share their thoughts and get ideas flowing.

Thanks Chetna for the comments.  The advantages of DI-DO is truly getting people together to enjoy a meal & mingle, which should get people (shy ones too!) in the mood to discuss topics on how to better the community!

Hao & Team - we're so sorry that we may have lost some of the updates to this concept over the last 72 hours - we lost the AWS server stack which included the backup and even after working through the night some updates escaped us.  We've extended the Refinement Phase to the 27th to give everyone extra time to re-upload their content and to push your concept even further - apologies again if you did lose any updates...
All, working on a document listing tips on a successful potluck.  See attached "Potluck Success Tips".  Its a working draft thus let me know if you tips!  Thanks!

All, developing a document highlighting the reasons why people don't like or do not attend potlucks and solutions on how to resolve those concerns.  See attached file "Potluck Challenges".  Its a working draft but please let me know of any challenges and solutions you can think of.  Thxs

This concept is awesome! I think the toolkits kinda seal the deal on 'teaching' and 'guiding' people on how to plan, strategise, discuss and move things forward. As it is, community topics are already being discussed in the neighbourhood or in the grapevine, but with the tools /platform set up to facilitate, I can see it growing and developing in a more structured manner! And the more likely for issues to be resolved / new initiatives to be borne!

Here's a good example of a toolkit that Frog has actually created to help groups solve issues/think of new ideas etc. from the ground up. http://www.frogdesign.com/pdf/.private/frog_collective_action_toolkit.pdf You can refer to some of the templates here as you develop the concept.
Tan Yan Ling,Thanks for the frog framework, using some of the templates to further develop the concept!
Rocking collaboration, guys!
Potluck + Art in NYC!  Love the pics from the potlucks...will add that feature to Dish In - Dish Out http://network.slideluckpotshow.com/
"Potluck in the Park" in Portland, OR since 1991!  http://www.potluckinthepark.org/how-to-prepare/

Hi Hao, I love the simplicity of your concept!I have added you to my virtual team for Pasar Malam reinvented. Do you think there could be a way to make the 2 concepts benefit from each other? The potluck could benefit from having a designated time and space and the Pasar Malam would have it's food section all set! If you want to eat, you have to socialise and contribute to the discussion :)Let me know if you have any thoughts on it!

Maria, love your idea on "if you want to eat, you have to socialise and contribute to the discussion"!  After reviewing James Robertson's "Flash Sports", Eugene Tay's "Community Recycling Center" and your "Local Night Markets", I had the below thought on connecting the 4 concepts:Have "flash night markets" (these are night markets that are scheduled to occur in specific communities during specific times) that will enable vendors, both from the community  and from other night markets, to sell their goods.  Great opportunity for community vendors to highlight their goods to their communities and allows vendors from other night markets entry to "new" customers.The entry fee to the "flash night market" is a potluck dish.  Each "flash night markets" will have a theme associated with a community issue.  Once in the market, participants will be able to meet new people, try all the potluck dishes, buy items from the vendors and most importantly, contribute to organized discussions on how to resolve the community issue.  Lastly I was thinking of having an "community recycling center" at the "flash night markets".  The center will educate people on reuse, recycle and reduce.  Additionally people will receive "market cash" for bringing in their recyclables.  The "market cash" can be used to buy products from the "flash night market".  (Checkout "Delicious Recycling" in Brazil http://www.care2.com/greenliving/brazilian-city-offers-vegetables-in-exchange-for-trash.html)What do you gals/guys think?

Hi Hao Dinh,Great that these concepts are beginning to support one another. Reading your thoughts on 'Flash Night Markets' above, I think there is perhaps more in common with the Singapore Smart Grid Games concept I entered earlier,http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/concepting/singapore-smart-grid-games-sg-squared/and it could also work perfectly with the 'Unvoid Decks' concept posted by Karl:http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/concepting/unvoid-decks/Regarding recyclables and rewards, there was a fantastic concept called Smart Bins from the San Francisco brainstorming crew which I'd love to have seen get taken further, and could hopefully be built upon with the concepts that did make it to refinement:http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/concepting/recycling-improvement/
Oh wow  great mash-up thoughts, guys!
Agree! Great to bring all three of these concepts under one venue to support local community businesses while communicating on local issues within those communities!

Great comments and ideas here. Starting small is actually the way to go, sometimes better than big parties.So I was wondering though, how might we nudge the 'first' person to initiate or start the ball rolling to organise the pot lucks for neighbours? The website is good to maintain conversations and include more people to join over time. Love it. In addition, what kind of ground rules should be put in place so we can all enjoy the usage of common spaces that holds these pot lucks?

Hi Hao I linked your idea with http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/concepting/weare.sg/#c-3b9a1047feaa386016f7c2897a9e9457. This could be a way to get even more ideas exchanged, resources shared and awareness raised.

Nice work, Hao! Your concept made it to the NEA Challenge Shortlist. Your idea was beautifully simple and easy to participate in: Prepare and share food, and make space for change to happen. Now, for Refinement: Think about space, and where Dish In - Dish Out might take place. Along those lines, we could see your concept hooking into a couple of others on the Shortlist: Community Recycling Centers (http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/concepting/dish-in-dish-out-potluck-for-a-cause/) and Pasar Malam reinvented (http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/concepting/pasar-malam-reinvented/). Maybe the three of you could get together if you're so inspired? Have fun! For more tips on how to iterate and prototype your idea during the Refinement phase, read here http://bit.ly/connect-refinetips and check this Lowdown: http://bit.ly/oi_refine
Love this concept!!! bring people together through food!!!! We should do more of that
Thanks Nabil....food and friends together to tackle an issue...what more can you ask for!
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!

Hao I totally dig potlucks. Great way to start conversations and break the ice. I wonder if this can be done without the government? One of my colleagues posted invitations to a pot luck on neighbours doors in her block and they started that way. Over time it grew to include more people in the block. Perhaps government involvement could be to host a site where people can post images of their own events and this could lead to the spreading of the idea to others. It also gives the sense of what is possible. I suspect that people may sometimes worry about negative consequences so this could be a way to assuage that.

Fab idea and great additional thoughts Christine. I wonder if the site could feature a toolkit on how to set up a Dish In  Dish Out potluck, with ideas on the kinds of topics which might be covered. Lots of deliciousness brewing on this idea!

A tool kit great idea Meena. 1) downloadable invites and responses;2) checklist/to-do list for the event;3) downloadable name tags;4) hints for planning the next event;5) recipe book template;6) place for positive images of community events. Maybe over time there might be collective resources available for a neighbourhood. http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/concepting/neighborhood-dining-halls/
wonderful concept!

py/tuple: How easy would it be for citizens to get involved and take initiative for this idea?
Very easy; this would rely on ground-up participation from the beginning.
Somewhat easy; there are ways for citizens to get involved, but an outside organiser may be needed to sustain and grow this concept.
This concept needs to be led and maintained by the government or private business.
Can you build this concept on top of something that already exists, like an organisation, physical space, or system?
Yes. This could fold into, or extend from, something that already exists.
This concept taps existing networks for a few things, but also needs a lot of new processes, materials, relationships, etc.
This concept requires a new system to be built to support it.
After the initial launch and support, could this concept be sustained and cared for over time by the community it's designed to serve?
Absolutely! This concept is easy to keep going.
It depends. There are opportunities for growth, but it's not yet clear how the concept would thrive after launch.
Probably not. A lot of effort would be needed to keep this concept going.
Does this concept create community?
Yes. It naturally brings people together and inspires them to take care of one another.
There is potential to create a thriving community.
No. It doesn't galvanize people to come together for a common cause or interest.
Overall, how do you feel about this concept?
It rocked my world.
I liked it but preferred others.
It didn't get me overly excited.

dance_at_fuxing_park.description: Every morning in Fuxing Park, Shanghai, people gather to dance, a form of exercise and enjoyment, where strangers become friends and passers-by become willing audience. There are many types of activities available: chess, cards, singing, debates.
dance_at_fuxing_park.creator: 9407549f5bf1f725829ce6e27b17c93b

comments.text: Cool, social gathering nights have been frequently organized by community clubs (something like town halls of the area) for things like cooking, dancing, bingo, sports, recreational, feedback sessions and the like. It's not new in Singapore, only that it attracts mostly the older retired folks, who I believe is because have much more time on their hands. To attract younger folks, only the proper activity is needed. For example, inter-neighbourhood DotA championships.

Bolstering an active park with infrastructure that will make the space a  viable venue for daytime or nighttime activity including lighting, speakers, safety lighting and more could encourage regular programming that keeps the space active, safe and engaging.

dance_at_fuxing_park.title: Dance at Fuxing Park

turn_parking_spots_into_mini_parks.description: Pavement To Parks program in San Francisco allows residents and business to turn parking spaces and into mini-parks--reclaiming the streets for people and providing a sense of community.
turn_parking_spots_into_mini_parks.creator: 141be6e79ccdd175d7f5586261fb78ff

comments.text: We have a similar program in Philadelphia called Park(ing) Day, it's great!  Local businesses and individuals create really creative public spaces all over the city: http://www.parkingdayphila.org/photos-media-coverage
Supernice!! I actually saw something similar in Munich around one month ago. There was a "mini-park" in the middle of the Fraunhoferstrae and the shop in front even served tea for free!
Loving this as it unties participation and local pride!

turn_parking_spots_into_mini_parks.title: Turn parking spots into mini-parks

participatory_budgeting_.description: Giving ordinary residents a role in deciding how to allocate part of municipal or public budgets
participatory_budgeting_.creator: 0ebfe65ca16ea82675e4294e27747639

comments.text: What a great idea!

I love this idea!  I interviewed the first project in the US, a Chicago alderman who used this process and just can't say how much I believe people need to experiment with this idea more.  Great submission.
Intriguing idea - interested to learn what impact this has had in the communities who have embraced participatory budgeting?

More info on the Porto Alegre example here: http://siteresources.worldbank.org/INTEMPOWERMENT/Resources/14657_Partic-Budg-Brazil-web.pdf There are many global examples of participatory budgeting these days. You'd need to seek out specific examples and see if there's been some kind of impact reporting to know more about each one.

Agree that participatory budgeting offers citizens an actionable way of participation that not only supports increased cooperation between community members and between residents and policymakers, but it also gets projects funded! In New York City and Chicago, several policymakers have taken up the idea in their districts for active participation of citizens in the spending of discretionary funds - the results seem to be positive and the practice is growing. Check our NYC Councilman Brad Lander's page for an example of how this played out in one Brooklyn district:http://bradlander.com/PB

This way to structure budgeting is remarkable! I think it could also be linked to environmental concerns, as well. In the U.S., for example, a certain segment of the population adopted "Drill, baby, drill" as a motto to encourage more drilling for oil and job opportunities that could come with it....however, if citizens were presented with the ultimate environmental costs, they may feel that money could be better spent elsewhere once they see the long-term consequences of addressing their immediate needs with that solution. Would a community rather spend money to increase jobs in the oil industry with xx amount of pollution down the road, or invest in greener job opportunities with less clean-up cost to the next generation?

I love this! This immediately brings to mind the many conversations that inevitably come up around tax time where me and my friends and family ask each other, "where is all our money going?".  It would definitely ease the mind to know exactly where your money was going and it's even better to actually have a say in it!  I would also be curious to find out what the priorities for spending were with the other members of my community and what's important to them.

participatory_budgeting_.title: Participatory Budgeting

mp3_tourism.description: Crowdsource "audio books" in a library for enhanced reality! Volunteers upload their stories/soundscapes. Geo-tag the starting point of each story to GPS-coordinates. Listeners download the Mp3 at home, travel to the starting point and press play!
mp3_tourism.creator: 656863f55543ea22d1dbce290f237277

comments.text: Johan & Arjan - we're so sorry that we may have lost some of the updates to this concept over the last 72 hours - we lost the AWS server stack which included the backup and even after working through the night some updates escaped us.  We've extended the Refinement Phase to the 27th to give everyone extra time to re-upload their content and to push your concept even further - apologies again if you did lose any updates...
No problem. All of the updates exists somewhere in the comment section. I hope that evaluators and the jury can understand the concept proposal. If anyone got questions, just ask.
hi Johan, sorry was away for quite a while, will have a look at the project as soon as I get back in London next tuesday... Is it finished already? Can't wait to see all the improvements :)

I have thougt a lot about perhaps including "gamifying" into the concept proposal, as "templates" or "guidelines" for users to experiment their own customization from out of. What do you think? Will it benefit the project, or will it become "obstacle" for freethinkers, early adapters or those that wish to experiment without rules; "Anarchy-techies"?

"Their own customization." Along these lines, it may be worth considering ways to integrate social media (Facebook, LinkedIn, etc.) in a manner that makes the information personalized, and highly relevant. I suppose that in, say, Central Park, there would be hundreds, or even thousands, of stories. This mechanism would allow the platform to organize large amounts of data. It would enable you to, for example, listen to a geo-specific stories by people that you have a connection with. Perhaps most importantly, it preserves memories and enables people to share them with anyone. Brilliant idea, Johan!

I found one existing project, http://www.singaporememory.sg/contents/SMA-a09b870a-3019-4259-b094-a2e5ac7426b5but don't really get their idea, concept or vision.Cannot really browse or find audio, cannot find a searchable map or work out if the site could be improved.But I would like it if the Singapore Public Libraries could partner up with my concept.

I wondered if you could expand upon the metaphor of the postcard? Could people take one key image and caption it to accompany their MP3 audio? If there was an archive this visual representation might attract people to each download?

I am not sure what is technically possible with images. But I do know that when I have put a CD into my computer and play it in my Itunes, I see a jpg of the CD-cover image on each of the tracks in the playlist.There is also potential for content creators to upload a photo to the library along with their recorded soundfile.There is of course also a couple of potential "backdoor"-versions, GPS-coordinates can be used to display a zoomed-in section of maps.google.com and enable the view of which photos is taken in that location and uploaded to www.panoramio.com : see my example from my "sculptural-documentation-project" : http://www.panoramio.com/map/?user=4282146I don't know which rules maps.google have, but it would be a dream if the sound files could be attached "Piggybacking" in their database-system, for all internet users to see and listen to. (sadly it would perhaps loose most of the revenue-models that I wish to include to bring donations and paying a small fee to each content creator)

For browsing in the library I am brainstorming different options:1. Geographical (map)2. Dewey system, just like library shelves3a. Chronological (historical timeline,3b. Calendar (in order to do annual "anniversary trips" or specific seasonal descriptions, horror stories after midnight etc)4. Subject tags (twitter/instagram hashtags)5. ? can you come up with more ideas on how to search/find content ?

Hi Johan. I love this concept - lots of great suggestions for enabling people to share personal experiences. With or without travelling through accessing your concept.It's a great approach for enabling people to share personal experiences from all ages and backgrounds. Like the comments before, tuning into a personal account / shared experience while visiting a beautiful place would give me goosebumps too.
Ciao Johan, try to have a look to www.tripnotes.coit is a social travelling application. I don't know if the audio part is ready, but I know it was planned. Maybe can be useful to your concept.
Thanks for the tip, but I cannot come in and check it out. "Invitation only"-demo, but seems a bit promising.

Johan, well done -- your idea has made it to the NEA Challenge Shortlist. Your video drew us into the concept and how it could work. You have a lot of great ideas about how this could play out, and the models that could surround it. As we move into the refinement phase, we wonder how you might choose a path to bring it to its final expression, considering the evaluation criteria. Focus on ease, and using existing resources -- these will make your idea easier to implement. Finally, hone in on how you might share the notion of the idea and get people to start using it and contributing. For more tips on how to iterate and prototype your idea during the Refinement phase, read here http://bit.ly/connect-refinetips and check this Lowdown: http://bit.ly/oi_refine

Simply amazing... I would love to travel that way. Not just guided audio tours in the touristic parts of the city, but everywhere you go, from the countryside to slums, stories would emerge.I imagine walking on a hill after a two hour climb. I'm alone. I sit down to take a breath, open my smartphone, and I see that on this exact same spot a story was told by someone that was here 25 years ago. That would give me goosebumps.The fact that all sorts of organisations can use this tool for different purposes makes this concept extremely strong.

Wow, this is so cool! I would totally use this. Right now I depend on apps like Foursquare and Yelp. What you are suggesting would let me wander through new places while listening to the stories and observing things I would have otherwise missed.I remember taking visitors around Mumbai and Brussels and sharing so many interesting stories. I would love to capture those on this application. The free version could just have one MP3 option. The premium version could have multiple - imagine I am ready to explore Singapore - I can choose to see it from the shoes of an artist, an environmentalist, a student, a businessman, a cyclist, a kid, someone who is visually impaired etc.So many possibilities. Very very exciting!
Another important thing to consider would be to eventually make it available in multiple languages, starting with the popular ones based on tourism statistics.

Hello! thank you! if this is built, there is a simple way to "create language sections" but start primarily with English, Chinese, SpanishIf this project is not built, take a look at www.broadcastr.com and start to practice recording your stories!!!I guess people not wealthy enough to travel could also with this discover exotic cities, sitting at home in Sweden and listening to a story from Mumbai, or even enjoying during the daily boring commute and listen to sounds recorded on board the Transsiberian Express :)
Sounds awesome. The possibility to travel without leaving. But maybe would work better with geo-location functionalities?

This is a fabulous idea and a lovely film. I saw something similar at the Festival of Ideas (Lower East Side, NYC, May 2011). http://www.broadcastr.com. I'm not sure if they are still in business, and you've taken it much further in this concept, but it might be worth checking out. Great idea!  Possible names: TalkWalk or ftSTEPS.

I know about broadcastr, but it seems they haven't become trendy with the old design, and they lacked some functionality, that I wish that I could implement in the actual sound files, combined. But who knows when they will release their future version?Thanks for the suggested names!

Wonderful idea, Johan. I have often thought of something like this. Especially when I wander around the city I live in now, there are many stories I think are interesting for tourists, or just in general. I think a good combination of audio and video would be great.Have you seen the talk to the dogs inspiration? http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/inspiration/talk-to-the-dogs-creating-community-from-the-ground-up/ - something like that would be an awesome addition, too, because you get a very different perspective.
video could become slightly hazardous to traffic, if the listener bikes, or drives a car. But of course for a bus ride, or just sitting still at a caf, you could perhaps combine with video or images

Your concept reminds me of one of my friends who did a similar project for the Swedish town Nordsj. Go to the last slide and watch the video. I swear it is worth it. http://designtalks.dh.umu.se/12/projects/projects/ixd/i-was-here.aspxIt is a really catchy idea. I can see how if I for instance were waiting for a bus, that it would be cool to see the stories that have happened around me. Somehow a location is enough to feel connected with strangers.

Thank you for that! It was almost exactly what I had imagined, but I don't want to produce a new product/player. I wish to let people use their existing mp3-players/ipods/ipads/phonesyou could also sit on the bus, and be able to see on a map all the stories that begin near the next bus stop, if you see an interesting story, you could jump off the bus (at an earlier stop than you originally intended to ride to) and take a walk the rest of the way, when you listened to the mp3-s in that street corners.

I really like this idea too Johan: I knew a similar videohttp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZG7F9G4AEakBut I feel like there should be different kinds of flash mobs as Pedro developed in his concept (http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/concepting/flash-mobs-for-social-good-/).it would really be great to have some kind of MP3 tourism network where:- for some you would have smaller groups with specific themes (vote for theme etc...)- for others you would have those very large events like on your video.

thanks, I think that those that create/record content for this library should have free hands, and use the system any way they like. But of course for ease of use, there should be plenty of categories to choose from: team-events, games, and also literary or "narratives" for single persons that wish to go walking in solitude on exploration/immersing themselves totally in the tour.

I know your concept is about free sharing of content, but I think it could be interesting to consider a freemium model. Why not think of how you can have also some ways of having this fund itself, and give some incentives to content creators, too. The iTunes model also comes to mind: if people pay, a certain percentage goes to the creator.

Yes, revenue sharing with the content creators of course!!!but I have been thinking hard about business models for some days now. Thanks for reminding me, that I need to add something about it in the concept proposal.Lets try one of the ideas: by submitting content, you get X minutes of free space! when you have uploaded 1 hour, you will be asked to pay donation of 1$ to be able to upload another hour of content? and if you got 2 hours in your library, you will be asked to pay donation of 2$ ? how does it feel like a model?I think borrowing should be as free and open as possible, but you could ask for donations at the end of the sound file, to make it a voluntary decision, and there could be a short list of environment-project proposals in the digital library, so happy listeners could choose between those, and donate any amount to any of them, or all of them, if they feel satisfied with the borrowed sound files.Your thoughts Arjan? Bob? Meena? other creative people? feel free to drop any idea, anywhere in the comment section

Hmm, interesting idea to ask content creators to invest by buying space to upload. Maybe you can turn it around a bit. Content creators could then buy space for premium uploads: files that they have put huge effort in to create, and they want to ask a token price for when they're downloaded (no more than 1 Euro in value?). Of that, maybe 75% can go to the creator, or something like that.Also, I like the donation ideas. You could also say: you can download 1 hour per month for free, and donate if you liked it, and if you want more, you need to pay a small fee. This revenue can then be divided. Say 25% goes to the organisation, 75% to creators, based on number of downloads.I think combining factors would be best. And if some content becomes really popular, you could create themed tourist guides and sell them for a small fee to affluent tourists. I like the free idea, especially for people who need to travel on a tight budget, but there are also people that have a bit of money to spend, and don't mind doing that for something so cool. In fact, you could also see that as the ones that are more able to pay subsidising those who are less able to pay.
Oh, wait. Do you know the Caff Sospeso principle? That could also be nice: buy one for yourself, and one for someone else. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Caff_sospeso

What about posting to a hashtag like #whatsthestory that's location-based (i.e., #whatsthestorySF)? I really like the idea of a gift economy-based approach. I did a quick search and found this article (http://bit.ly/SMKIsv) about flattr.com developing a way to use twitter for micro payments.

When I speak about geo-location and GPS-coordinates, I talk in detail a street corner, at a bus station, at a statue in a park. One hashtag for an entire city is too wide and not precise enough to describe a starting point for a story.On a related note, you could read my concept proposal for "train-ride-edu-tainment" that I won 3rd price for in OpenPlanetIdeas 2,5 years ago, see page 68-69: http://www.openplanetideas.com/static/PDF/OPI_Book.pdfThere you could talk about defining hashtags, i.e. #TrainRideNYC->Washington

The jury is still out on Flattr.com. I am not sure if it will ever catch on, it is many years since they launched, and not much progress so far, as I can see. probably closer to reality to see what will happen with iZettle
Have you checked out http://tiptheweb.org? On another note, could QR codes be used as a starting point? Maybe even just on a temp basis so what a user discovers is constantly changing and evolving.

I have been thinking about QR-codes on other concepts, But cannot really figure out how to apply it to this concept, what was your idea? to print decals and place on lamp posts, corner of a house? ( my guess is that singapores local legislation will lead to them becoming torn down and scratched away, since it could be considered littering or illegal graffiti?) Or where you thinking about something completely different method?   (thanks for the tiptheweb, i will go and check it out now)

Well, they could be guerrilla/popup codes that you anticipate being removed so that people are on the look out (maybe a bit of a hunt). Do you find it before it's gone? Do you form relationships with other "hunter"? These would be designed for easy removal/no damage. Maybe the poster even goes back and takes them down after a day or two (but you could catalog on a website so people could go back later).Another way that could create connections is for the poster to seek permission that creates some sort of symbiotic relationship with the property owner.Maybe post on public bulletin boards (cafes?) that would give a nearby location.

what if the Mp3-library will be lasting 5-10 years? and someone listens to a story even after that? probably whole shops or even buildings cold be gone and replaced by then?Maps on the phones can show street-location, Perhaps you would not need QR-codes at all to find the way?But perhaps you got an entirely different environmentally-friendly concept somewhere with QR codes?

One day I was wandering my neighborhood and came across a piece of paper with a QR code for a scavenger hunt. The code took me to a Facebook event. I think you could use both GPS maps, QR codes and word of mouth as a way to get people interested. The QR's would disappear and maybe even shops and buildings too over time. A lack of permanence creates a bit of mystery. Tweets (or other social) could fill in the blanks and give people a way to participate/add to without creating a whole episode.I don't think you NEED QR codes but they could be one of many ways of entering. For example, while exploring the city, you come across a small poster with a code and "What's the Story Here? #wts [or the author's @handle which you could @tiptheweb if you wanted to]" If you're curious, you scan and go from there. Maybe teams of locals create episodes/hunts and post codes for friends and family that tourists could also join in on.I scanned the scavenger hunt QR but didn't go. I was curious enough, though, to check it out. Not really sure how to solve the cleanup element. Maybe post a teardown date?It seems like QR codes might end up with greater use now that Apple is using them in Passbook. Integration?

I love this concept! I would totally use it. A bit like living someone else's life for a day. It reminds me of "literature travels", for example when I visited Moscow I went to a square where most famous scene from Bulgakov's "Master and Margarita" took place.It could be fun to have celebrity walks - to wander around Singapore in footsteps of some famous writer or artist.

Yes, I know about such tourism. I know it is on the rise, people come here to sweden and look for Pippi Longstocking and Lisbet Salander and so on This service will have a literature section, and you are the first that are invited to record your literary walks :)Do you have thougths on details of the functions or technology?(don't worry about the content just yet, because I wish to keep that part open to users to develop, and keep open bar for all types of stuff that can be recorded and put in a mp3-player)
I like this idea. Perhaps it could also include some stories of other critters that share our communities that would diversify and broaden connections.
thanks for your idea, but "Critters"? are you thinking about pets, or rodents?

"Wild" life, non-human. Community, to me, is about connections between individuals that need and depend on each other. We seem to have forgotten that we are part of and depend on a much larger whole. Telling stories that help us reconnect with each other and life as a whole has a lot of potential to help us remember and come together to improve local environments.
I remember from my visit the monkeys roaming freely on Sentosa. There's a story in them, for sure.

OK, now I get it, of course there must be people writing and telling the stories about the "critters", of course! but producers of content could also record "soundscapes" & "field recordings" of the animals natural sounds "in action", so to use in the background of the narrated stories :)Thanks Bob, and Arjan, Now i understand you perfectly!Animals are used brilliantly in surreal childrens fairy tales = "Fables". Would become a designated section, in this library of MP3:s for all of the old Fables from yesteryear, and also potential to inspire new authors to create new modern Fables

Great thoughts, Johan. Wonder if the folks from: http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/inspiration/reminding-ourselves-the-beauty-of-singapore might have some learnings to share to help build this out?

py/tuple: How easy would it be for citizens to get involved and take initiative for this idea?
Very easy; this would rely on ground-up participation from the beginning.
Somewhat easy; there are ways for citizens to get involved, but an outside organiser may be needed to sustain and grow this concept.
This concept needs to be led and maintained by the government or private business.
Can you build this concept on top of something that already exists, like an organisation, physical space, or system?
Yes. This could fold into, or extend from, something that already exists.
This concept taps existing networks for a few things, but also needs a lot of new processes, materials, relationships, etc.
This concept requires a new system to be built to support it.
After the initial launch and support, could this concept be sustained and cared for over time by the community it's designed to serve?
Absolutely! This concept is easy to keep going.
It depends. There are opportunities for growth, but it's not yet clear how the concept would thrive after launch.
Probably not. A lot of effort would be needed to keep this concept going.
Does this concept create community?
Yes. It naturally brings people together and inspires them to take care of one another.
There is potential to create a thriving community.
No. It doesn't galvanize people to come together for a common cause or interest.
Overall, how do you feel about this concept?
It rocked my world.
I liked it but preferred others.
It didn't get me overly excited.

comments.text: Hi Niklas,I really love the amphitheatre Karaoke! Actually, I wanted to post it myself and was just checking if somebody else did but here we go, all the better! There are a few things that I want to add or emphasise about this project which I make it truely great: it is completely self-organised by a guy with a bike (Joe Hatchiban) he built a mobile soundsystem on his bike to use infrastructure of the city that was already there, the amphitheatre in this case, but which was practically unused before it is free and open for everybody the usual border between audience and performer does not exist here he managed to establish a tradition for people to go there on Sundays, at the same time creating a sense of belonging / identity for the neigbourhood it goes well together with a nearby fleemarket, and other microbusiness, selling food and drinks around the event-> all organised bottom-up, thats the beauty of it. At some point earlier this year, he had some trouble with the city and the license he needs to do this, but in the end, the city was supportive. -> Cities should be as supportive as possible to foster such initiatives that are free and open for all. There is always the danger of too much red tape but this is a story where the city, after some hesitation, understood the positive impact it can have.  Here is the official website of the project:http://www.bearpitkaraoke.com

Despite the events popularity, i have heard the local council have made it harder for Joe, limiting the days he can hold the event in the Mauerpark, blocking his usual days and trying to decrease its regularity.

Hi Steve, you are right, the counci intervened because of, as they argued, to much trash, not enough toilets and because Joe Hitchiban was not preventing hawkers from selling beverages But the city revoked their intervention because of the popularity of the event. Everything back to normal as for now. Here is an article about that, unfortunately only in German:http://www.tagesspiegel.de/berlin/prenzlauer-berg-mauerpark-karaoke-wieder-jeden-sonntag/6717772.html
Good to know. It did seem counter intuitive, but German bureaucracy does tend to defy common sense.

Oh, and by the way, for the concept phase, this would go very well together with the Open Mic Night Inspiration posted by Michel Offerman. Karaoke would give people a voice but at the same time a positive framing:http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/inspiration/open-mic-night/

comments.text: Good one, Karin. I remember a student's job I had in one vacation with a Dutch institution called 'Thuiszorg' (homecare). They provide care services at home for people who are handicapped or elderly. Services range from cleaning to medical assistance. For the cleaning job (or some gardening services), students were hired. I did that, and spent some great afternoons with elderly and handicapped people. Or, in once case, the son of an elderly woman to clean up her house before she came back from hospitalization. In some cases, it was clear that the people preferred me to chat to them, more than doing actual cleaning work (although I did do some hard working, too!). I really enjoyed it, because it gave me a lot of insights and stories I would otherwise not have come across.
Young are eager to take initiatives. We have to support them in all ways.

comments.text: Great idea. I love this.A challenge I see is getting people to do it in the first place. It's a little like hitchhiking. People can be hesitant and just not bother since it's easy to be lazy and not do it (i.e. just drive yourself to work instead). Not everyone of course, but many. Lindsey mentioned an honor system. That's a great way to ease this worry. In fact, I'm thinking the exact same system that CouchSurfing uses could be implemented. Drivers could build up some positive reputation.So...1) As a driver/rider you would create a profile online, and other users vouch for you by rating/reviewing you. At first these would likely be friends, but then users could review you once you start doing some commutes with them (either as a driver or passenger). An actual picture of yourself on your profile clearly helps ease worries.2) Other drivers/riders see this and know you're a good person (obviously, the more reviews the better). RideNow could verify users by having them make a $1 donation online if they want an added measure of security, which helps identify it's really them (the name on the card). Their real name would not be shared through this action. A real name as a username would obviously help though, like the picture. I can see people using an alias name online, and then sharing their real names when actually driving/riding with someone. Easy enough for the new connection to ask for their alias and review them using that.3) CouchSurfing sends a postcard to the address the host claims they live (where the guest would be sleeping in this case), and the host then inserts the unique code on the postcard into a verification system - ensuring they do in fact live there. I'm thinking this could be transferred to license plates instead of addresses. This would verify the driver is in fact driving the car they say they are. Alternatively, a driver could post a picture of the car they drive. Riders could then view this on their phone (of course there's an app!) as the driver pulls up.Again, this is basically how www.couchsurfing.com does their optional verification. I think it could transfer over well.

Great example on aligning incentives, Lindsey. Oh  and links don't appear as live in the Summary section, only in the Description section. I've used my Community Manager super powers to move it for you :^)
Thank you, Meena! Aligning incentives -- that's a great way to characterize the fact that both parties are benefitting.

Such a simple, solid solution to avoid the perpetual nightmare of the MacArthur Maze...I'd love to see more casual commute pick-up spots added, as well as increased visibility. It's amazing how many people have made friends this way too--documenting and sharing those experiences could be a fun collective storytelling project!

I love the idea of documenting the experiences of connection! Currently, the Casual Carpool website only documents drivers to avoid and unruly passengers (which are both very, very infrequent occurences, especially given the volume of riders).I would love to see more ride reporting in genreal, too: Maybe a badge system for commuters that shows they're "verified", or even a visual cue that helps those who share the car know if they're a morning person and love to talk or if they'd rather just enjoy the view.

This is a great idea, you are just not interacting with people, also you are saving money and time and actually helping the planet. Everything at the same time.  Wow! that would really work in my city, so much traffic everyday

comments.text: Thank you very much for a big part of the inspiration to this concept:http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/concepting/stereopodding/If you wish to introduce this into your concept, be my guest and borrow some of it! :)

I wonder if you have seen Improveverywhere.com and their small innovative performances on subway of newyork? "Ride to work without pants-day" could perhaps be too much over the top, but watch, and maybe you get ideas for small implementation in this collab-commute-project!

Hi Johan, Thanks for sharing the inspiration. I have heard about improve everywhere and participated in the Vancouver Freeze one year. I think the idea of it being something spontaneous and out of the blue captivates people and creates a connection between strangers as they have a uniting cause. This is a great finding to try to incorporate. Improve everywhere somehow puts a smile on peoples faces, both participants and spectators. I think there's something valuable in that.

Perhaps you can look at some of my concept proposals, and perhaps link your concept with any of mine that you like, or pick whatever details from mine that you might need to improve in your concept. You can click on my name, and see the list of ideas. And also you could look at http://www.randomactsofkindness.org/ and facebook.com/SmallActofGoodness for a more basic approach, low-budget, more spontaneous without planning and more suitable for people that are a bit shy, but still wish to spread smiles around

Maybe you could also seek some inspiration from the concept proposal that suggest placing bulletin board inside lifts ? http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/concepting/singapore-hdb-living-kampung-style/and perhaps this concept : http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/concepting/community-vote./ ?

Thanks Johan for your many suggestions, inspirations and ideas. Your game diy concept really stood out to me as a great way to connect with people, by having an activity to do together. That might be a great way to get people talking and interacting.

thanks, there are lots of different games that can be well adapted to a commute on a train (perhaps card games, or quiz, or bingo, sudoku, puzzles that can be printed and distributed on a single sheet of paper)(there are also lots of novelty games that you play without any equipment, just orally call out, at libraries and book shops there are a couple of books that collect simple and easy low-tech, and interactive games)

Yay! Thank you. Hoping more people will contribute their suggestions on how people might connect with each other on the collaborative commute?

Fab idea, Shelagh! Looking forward to seeing it evolve through discussion here.
