Loving your thoughts that this might be done visually)
Also thought there might be learnings from Conflict Kitchen around promoting community conversation: http://www.randomspecific.com/conflict-kitchen

Thanks for the feedback Meena, and a really nice link about the Conflic Kitchen. There appears to be something pivotal about creating something most people can relate to (food is a great example of that) as a means of starting a dialog between people and building a community.

An idea came to me during a discussion with James (on the HopIn!-concept) perhaps it would be valuable for you to think about in this concept:There's an annual "borrow a librarian"-day in swedish public libraries, where visitors can book/schedule short appointments with a librarian, to ask questions about books or information seeking. and get personalized, customized answers and book recommendations.Something along these lines could perhaps be introduced into collective transport, since I guess that librarians also travel to work with collective transport?Other city servants from other parts of public sectors, that also use this train to work, could perhaps volunteer some days?Information sharing, reaching out with public service announcements? maybe more?

Hi Shelagh,I have seen a few ideas about 'talking carriages' or 'date-buses' in the past, but what I love about your idea is that it is slightly more goal-orientated, and has a catchy name!In order to facilitate the dialogue, perhaps NEA as the client could sponsor a conductor (an employee?) who encourages and records the discussions that take place on the carriage.Striking a balance between feedback on previous themes and gathering new inputs would be great to. Screens that explain the existing and past work of the NEA etc.. Perhaps one month live and one month feedback, alternating.I look forward to seeing where this goes!

I love the collaborative commute. Could it be something much more simple with no challenge inside the carriage necessary - Encourage people to use the same carriage every day so that they get to know each other over time. Start building commuter communities. My life would be better if I didn't have to shuffle alongside complete strangers every morning with headphones on to block out the boredom of the daily grind : )

Hi James and Paddy, These are some great ideas. I was struggling with what the exact purpose of coming together in this collaborative space could be, and a way to encourage dialogue is something I am interested in exploring further. Your ideas of including a facilitator or building a community in carriages over time are excellent suggestions. I also agree with you Paddy, I feel like it is hard to strike up a conversation with people I commute with, even if I nearly everyday see them on the same bus or train as me. Although one of my friends did meet her longterm boyfriend because they frequently took the same bus and decided to say hi one day.

I find this very interesting, San! I previously attended the What Design Can Do conference in Amsterdam, which also revolves around the impact of design but in a different way. It's a two-day conference in which speakers from different disciplines present their work on a certain theme (this year the theme was exploring the positive and negative sides of a connected world, and the role of designers in this) in combination with discussions, ideation sessions, and workshops. It shares the goals of DCD by reflecting with fellow designers and other professionals on 'what design can do'. The outcome is published in a book compiled on the spot and then available on the website (http://www.whatdesigncando.nl/archive/downloads/WDCD12_book_web_yellow.pdf).

Wow. Thank you so much for the comment. Sounds really interesting. I guess it's more of a speaker and small workshop, while DCD is more of a intense Hackathon types of event. I'd love to take a look at the book later. Thank you!

comments.text: I love this idea Nathan, I think it could be a great way to promote local identity and potentially local craftmanship. Of course, the trick is then to find the great recycling idea that is sustainable environmentally, socially and economically. There is one success story that comes to my mind when I read about your concept. (http://www.lerelais.org/aussi.php?page=metisse)Mtisse is a house insulating material that is made out of old clothes that are too damaged to be re-sold. This company is also a social enterprise which aims to create jobs for people in great difficulty. I know people often have misconceptions about products made out of recycled materials but I think if the recycling process is well designed, it can lead to stunning results. Any idea anyone of what could be done in Singapore specifically?

Hey Florie - thanks for the story about Metisse, what an inspiring example!  That's exactly what we're talking about.  For Singapore specifically, we didn't have an example in mind although we did discuss that there seems to be a large opportunity to create the feeling of freedom given how much rules are used to enforce things.  This would lead me to think about using recyclables to create art, but that isn't necessarily a viable business opportunity.  Did you have any ideas?

comments.text: Interesting inspiration. I love how they collect memories and stories to share them. Also: the events are an important factor to not just make this an online initiative. I like it when they use a 'full approach'.It also plays nicely into a concept I'm brooding on...

In order to scale this sentiment, why not consider a supporting mobile application to help Singaporeans (and others) appreciate the city's "personalised history"? A geo-service similar to the Museum of London's Streetmuseum augmented reality app would add greater depth to the stories and help highlight how the city has evolved over the years.

Another interesting fact: the coffee shop where they are hosting the event is in an old 3 storey building. It's new and stylish but rather than taking a new name, they have kept the name of the original business in order to honor the heritage of the site and the businesses that you used to find all around the area.

Great local highlights, Maria! And indeed  memories play a significant role in creating a sense of belonging. I also found this Singaporean initiative inspiring: http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/inspiration/connecting-the-dead-with-the-living/

civic_shift_creates_social_structures_fo.description: Civic Shift (CS) teams & communities of practice enable citizens to build, share & apply ideas that make their cities flourish. External, top-down solutions don't work or don't last. CS residents & stakeholders collaborate for breakthrough results.
civic_shift_creates_social_structures_fo.creator: fd820a2b4461bddd116c1518bc4b0f77

comments.text: Meena,The main Civic Shift challenge is: How do we organize, at the city level, so leaders of civic initiatives--in various neighborhoods, on various topics (health, education, etc.)--can share ideas, skills, methodologies, access to influential organizations, etc.?Most will agree that we would all do better by collaborating with peers working on similar initiatives (as evidenced by this IDEO collaboration platform!), but getting people to _do it_ is really difficult.  We have 1000's of non-profits here in the Boston area (there are over one million in the U.S.), but getting related organizations to collaborate on shared goals--say to increase cancer-screening rates, or enhance parental involvement in kids education--is uncommon.There is a terrific sample of ideas here that communities could apply related to improve their environments.  If each community had well-trained "civic stewardship teams" who had skills in help local people generate, adapt, and implement ideas such as these, they would be much more likely to succeed. And if these neighborhood teams were collaborating with peers in other neighborhoods--and by working together, could compel institutions to engage--initiatives in any community would be much more likely to succeed.But, by nature, this idea is a bit abstract--it's about helping people organize; it's not about a concrete solution to a specific problem--such as a community garden to provide healthy food, or a creative way to call attention to urban design opportunities.  I would like to work with others on how to integrate a social-system strategy that helps implement more concrete design-technology-oriented solutions.  (I'll start looking at others' ideas on this site and suggest opportunities to do this.)Thanks Meena!

Sounds interesting, William During our OpenIDEO Concepting phase we hope that our community will collaborate to strengthen and build ideas, together. Do you have any challenges or areas of opportunity for Civic Shift that you'd like to share to help folks understand where they might join the conversation?

civic_shift_creates_social_structures_fo.title: Civic Shift for societal wellbeing by organizing within & across neighborhoods & cities

comments.text: Cool, let's work it out! How do I join the Virtual Team?Something that we might need to know is, how does the culture of collaboration manifests in Singapore? (Meena, by any chance do you know about a study or someone's inspiration that talks about this?)Then, one issue we must solve is how are we going to rally people to go to the workshops, what would motivate them to go.I ask this two questions because sometimes finding a cultural aspect makes projects succeed or fail. For example, Muhammad Yunnus'es Micro Finance Project succeeded in India because within the Indian culture to save face is a must. There, people do not like to be seen as someone that doesn't meet his or her commitments, to do so is their "social death". That is why they made all what was in them to pay the loan that was granted to them and since this loan came by being referenced by a friend, they could not let the good name of their friend be at risk with the community. Peer pressure is what made micro finance successful in India.One other thing, entertainment-edutainment-edugaming is the key to the success of our solution, the more engaging and fun is the workshop the better. We must need to define the following:- Theme (we do need a main premise that will give us the theme of our workshop)- Plot (what would there be needing to be solved and that will act as our learning "vehicle")- Should we think of prices? What kind of gift do the people that achieve the goal of reaching the end of the workshop successfully could receive that could help even more reinforce the goal of our challenge? (an idea that pops in my mind right now: something like carboncredits)These are my comments, please receive them as my will to collaborate, because sometimes I tend to be inquisitive or be perceived as I want to impose my self. Non of that, please see beyond this and just see it as my contribution because I want to collaborate.I'll wait for your comments.
Great thoughts, Clara! I'm digging the action-oriented aspects here  plus the combination of face-to-face and online elements.
Thanks.. maybe you share some of your ideas for a better composition of the concept.
You might like to consider posting a sketch or two of the process, Clara? Sketching often stimulates our thinking and helps others engage with our ideas.
I will try something! thanks!

You describe these workshops perfectly, and in fact it is similar to the "education and skill exchanges" that I thought could be included in my concept of workshops: http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/concepting/upcycling/   Please read through it if you can, and please comment and give me feedback, so we could learn from each other and possibly make our respective concepts even little bit better.

comments.text: This is a great concept. The potential of it expanding into multiple smaller entities (with those specific locations in the name) that perform community acts that are derived from necessities in those regions is a great way to truly make a difference and a "chain of communities" that support one another worldwide. I also think that Durham is a great place to start and use as a prototype. It has its issues but is also on the rise physically and intellectually. There is already a lot of motivated individuals and groups that have the necessary mindset to enable these type of efforts successfully. Durham is a very unique town that is developing its own culture and something like this would make a great addition and most importantly unite all the efforts and everyone. The question is how do you get people motivated about something like this and get them to be involved?

I really like your concept, Burgess. I'd love to use elements of it to build upon the concept I posted on Neighborhood Dining Halls: http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/concepting/neighborhood-dining-halls/While the two concepts differ in some ways, they both use food to bring people together and create a platform for activism. It would be great to get your input on how to refine Neighborhood Dining Halls!

removing_obstacles_to_creating_a_better_.description: Communities emerge with their own natural rules and norms, but over time infrastructure gets created that sometimes prevents the natural order of things. What can we remove to allow some of that natural order to flourish?
removing_obstacles_to_creating_a_better_.creator: d7d03fc4ed767b64ad78b2fdbcd6324c

comments.text: This reminded me of a study by Donald Appleyard, whose research demonstrated that "residents of [a] street with low car traffic volume had three times more friends than those living on the street with high car traffic" (Wikipedia). Another study by Dutch engineer Hans Monderman, under the Shared Space concept, showed that (counterintuitively) removing curbs induces drivers to behave more cautiously. I think you're on to something here!

What if we could engage people why they were at red lights?  Think how much time we spend over a day, a month, a year waiting for the green light.  What if you could display public service announcements or have some sort of game?  Just display a simple fact about the community or a little tidbit that gets people to think.

Great insight and analogy Nathan. I remember when I learnt to drive a scooter on Indian roads a few years back while on assignment there  at first I was quite freaked out by the seeming lack of rules. Coming from New Zealand I was used to something quite different. Soon I came to see it as a deeply connecting experience due to the more direct interaction with other commuters & pedestrians... with nods of heads, clicks of tongues and a variety of gestures  folks paid much deeper respect towards each other than most of us in more rule-driven systems do. And from within this seemingly chaotic self-governing approach  much more cooperation arose.

removing_obstacles_to_creating_a_better_.title: Removing obstacles to creating a better community

comments.text: Love this idea especially being a dance music lover, but perhaps there could be options to switch between music genre, as non-rave/clubbing goers may not be into dance music. Music should be curated to suit the crowd so as to make it work. The concept could pioneer multiple identities, where one night, you could find world music, and on another night, for alternative and industrial music. On Saturday night, it could start with hip-hop music, and then transform into house and techno music until midnight, when the train service stops.What might make this concept successful is the DJs understand the crowd for each concept- knowing what music to mix and when.

I love the parallel between clubbing and riding the MRT: to similar, yet vastly different experiences. A lot of people carry their own headphones, and you might be able to streamline the experience by installing headphone jacks in certain places on the train -- a great place to meet new people!

Great, you could also do the model of improveverywhere.com wherein deejays record Mp3-file in advance, so that citizens can download a few days before each event, onto their own mp3-player or phone. and they all collectively start simultaneously at a given point.see my concepts, there are something similar there, that your concept could perhaps find ideas for, or connect with mine, if you wish. :)Rock on! :)
Yeah that definitely came up too during our brainstorming on Tuesday, the inspiration being the mp3 flash mob!

Sharing also helps get people together and once there's some kind of strong community, people start to make more positive changes to their lives and others' lives.

allotments.description: An allotment is an area of land leased for the use of growing your own food. The idea of sourcing your food (or something essential) from the same shared space, while also having an enjoyable time doing so makes for a strong community.
allotments.creator: 9407549f5bf1f725829ce6e27b17c93b

comments.text: Nice. I have heard of a couple of examples of housing complexes that have a similar system for residents - where residents have the option of having an allotment (sometimes given by lottery, waiting list, etc).  One example that I like in San Francisco places the laundry room next to the roof terrace where the allotment planters are:http://asla.org/awards/2007/07winners/images/largescale/049-13.jpgThat seems like a potentially good strategy for community gardens (or other community centers, etc) in general - by siting them near other essential and more mundane services (like laundry), you give people the chance to participate more frequently than they otherwise might have.

Nice one, Alice. And I can heartily recommend the British comedy, Grow Your Own  set on an allotment in Liverpool http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grow_Your_Own_(film)  brilliantly highlighting community connections!

allotments.title: Allotments

the_chat_pole.description:
Some of the most amazing collaborations were started with people meeting on trains. Such as Mick Jagger and Keith Richards.
Let''s have designated poles in subway trains to encourage people to gather around and start conversations with strangers.
the_chat_pole.creator: 86d2b8ddeed8a2d0486edca71e020d97

comments.text: Simple, direct and easy to execute! the blue pole creates a casual excuse for strangers to start conversations! The idea is further enhanced with the bluetooth technology! A simple idea with a great potential to expand and create more meaningful journey for commuters!

Hi Raymond, interesting post! Any chance you could find an image to go along with it? Images help grab attention and tell a story with higher impact. You should be able to use the 'Update entry' button on the right of your post and follow the instructions to add images from there. We know occasionally people have issues uploading images so let us know by hitting the Support tab on the left hand side of most pages of our site if you face any problems. Looking forward to seeing more of your inspiring insights on OpenIDEO.

Hi Raymond, were you at the Open IDEO x Syinc event last night? I remember something like this coming up and thinking it was a great idea.. re-writing the rules for the use of space.. there was another issue that it might help with that was also mentioned.. how do you get people to move down inside the carriage? If you were to place the blue poles near the door, perhaps an unintended beneficial consequence could be that those of a shy disposition do their best to get as far away from the pole as possible, thus freeing up the space near the door and creating room for the talkers!There was another great concept called Collaborative Commute with a similar premise, posted recently by Shelagh:http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/concepting/collaborative-commute-/These two concepts could really compliment each other well!

thanks for this, wasn't at the event, i am actually a singaporean based in shanghai :) But yep, sounds great. I've added Shelagh as an inspiration, saw her concept after i posted haha. I think it is all about adding a simple extra layer for people to connect and be communal, on top of their daily habits.

the_chat_pole.title: The Chat Pole

free_micro_community_social_forum.description: Encourage community building by connecting through a free online community forum of people in the same neighborhood, block, or building.  Share concerns, excitement, houseplants, find lost pets, start up groups, everything!
free_micro_community_social_forum.creator: e7bf30df69d588db89f3e54d1eb74086

comments.text: Awesome, Nicole! I was very excited to click through and see that my home town has a FPF! I particularly like that there is a weekly email, as it allows people to not have to try and seek out local information, and instead have it delivered to them - very convenient!Any idea how many people participate in a FPF, and how word typically spreads about signing up? Getting people to be involved is key to this success. I wonder if some groups also print off their weekly "newsletter" to give to others who may not be able to access it through email or online (the elderly, those who don't want to use a computer, etc.).

Yes, one of the things I think is unique and wonderful about FPF is that it gets delivered to your inbox every week, as opposed to a forum like craigslist where you're already looking for something specific and would miss cool and unexpected things that might just catch your eye.I'm not sure how many folks are currently on FPF but it has definitely caught on like wildfire in town centers and urban areas here in Vermont.  From their website "more than half of Burlington households subscribe to FPF now..." and their list of service towns is too many to count easily (some of which are broken up into neighborhoods), just since 2006.I'm trying to remember how I first heard about it, and it must be word of mouth.  I do think that printing the weekly issue and sharing the kinds of ideas on it would help garner support.  Maybe even flyers to get it started. If one or two large institutions (maybe town governments or large employers) committed to posting information or opportunities of value and advertised it as the format it might catch on quickly.

free_micro_community_social_forum.title: Free Micro-community Social Forum

rooftop_gardens_city_farming.description: Using the fact that 80% of Singaporeans live in flats, why not create extra living space on top of them? Such is the situation in New York where rooftops are converted into living spaces through the creation of gardens/greenhouses. City farming ftw!
rooftop_gardens_city_farming.creator: 96927817c762eb0a96c1eff02b0e99d2

comments.text: Roofscapes could be an amazing way to engage buildings, especially apartment buildings to engage with each other and learn more about your neighbors/community.  The challenge is that not everyone loves gardening or climbing to the top floor of a building.  Creating shared spaces including but not limited to movie screening spaces, classroom style seating and venues for people to gather may inspire neighbors up to the roof.

Yea! I love the idea of green roofs, and it's currently being explored as a way of passive cooling of buildings so this just takes things one step furthur and one level down to the community. The idea of opening up more spaces in the air doesn't just apply to gardens of course, but image open patios or public spaces where people can meet, greet and have social gatherings! I agree with you on the part about accessibility. The older buildings in Singapore have only a little ladder to get to the roof, and there's the issue of the amount of load it can handle as well. But I think if the idea sticks then these things could be worked out along the way:)

Cherise, did some additional research on the benefits of rooftop gardens: - Produce oxygen- Convert CO2 emissions- Absorb & Transform Sunlight- Reduce Ambient Temperature- Reduce the Heat of Buildings- Create Large Catchment Areas- Capture and Harvest Rainwater- Reduce Stormwater Runoff & discharge- Reduce Energy Costs- Create Habitat for Wildlifehttp://www.atlantiscorp.com.au/roof-garden-benefits  http://www.wisegeek.com/what-are-the-advantages-of-rooftop-gardening.htm  http://www.servicemagic.com/article.show.Stunning-Roof-Gardens-Also-Have-Beautiful-Advantages.13550.html
Wow! Cherise, thanks for sharing.  Next time I am in NYC, I'm going to check out some rooftops!

Nice one, Cherise! As we switch to the Concepting phase next week, we look forward to hearing some savvy, fresh ideas about urban farming  especially around how to motivate folks to get involved and participate. Catch you on more conversations across the challenge...

rooftop_gardens_city_farming.title: Rooftop Gardens & City Farming!

day_off_to_do_volunteer_work.creator: c4ffbf683062d009b2a0fc7b4e9187b4

comments.text: It's amazing to read such insights from folks who have spent time living in Singapore!

I think it's important to get the Singaporean community involved.  After all, it is all about getting them to connect with their community!I don't want to be negative, but a lot of the other suggestions obviously come from people who have no idea what Singapore is like!  I wonder if Open Ideo can attract more input from Singaporean locals.  They are the ones who need to buy into the "campaign" for it to succeed. Singapore is a small place geographically, I imagine marketing in the heavy traffic areas, like Orchard Rd, Raffles Place, MRT stations etc can get you a lot of bang for buck. Or even on social media, they are all very connected digitally.I actually re-posted this brief on Facebook to my Singaporean friends, but only one made a comment.  I don't know whether it's apathy or fear (they have different laws around freedom of speech and also Asians have a "face-saving" culture which probably encourages you to not try rather take a risk and possibly fail) or a lack of ownership.  During Singapore's short history as an independent nation (since around 1965 I think), the government has taken a huge involvement in nearly every aspect of life there, which has probably been a huge part of its "success", but in turn, the citizens now sit back and expect the government to come up with the answers for everything.  They grumble and complain but no-one steps forward with ideas or solutions.
Yep  we're working on it and super appreciate you reaching out to your own networks too!

talk_to_the_dogs_creating_community_from.description: If you could ask city dogs what it's like to live in the concrete jungle, what would they say? Inspired by the diversity of people and dogs in my Brooklyn park, I began asking strangers to adopt their dog's perspective and tell me about their lives.
talk_to_the_dogs_creating_community_from.creator: 395e4483755ef6ae86d845343dd9fc07

comments.text: Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Inspiration!
So great! I'd love to see people building off of this and doing interviews in their own neighborhoods!
Simple and brilliant! Like all good ideas!
Thanks Fernanda! Please feel free to add your own interviews!
Hi Jenine,Nice communicating with you. Im a newbie here, so Im still learning how to participate. What kind of interviews would be useful to the project?

Hi Fernanda, as a little side-note: it seems you are doing great for a newbie :). If you have any questions, feel free to check out the special section for new users on the USers Forum: http://bit.ly/NmFnGX

Agreed, great new newbie! No pressure to record anything new, Fernanda. But if you're out and about with recording equipment (like your phone!), I'd personally be interested to hear about your city through any special people/dogs you come across. http://soundcloud.com/ is a great, free platform for sharing audio and interviews.

This is such a great project. As a dog owner, I might be slightly biased, but using people and their pets to connect is a great idea. I've lived in several places and countries now, and what is always the case (in Amsterdam, Paris, and Riga at least), is that it is super easy to connect with people when I'm walking my dog. Especially, of course, with other dog owners. There's this immediate bond. And using the dogs as 'first person' is also a great (and maybe obvious) idea. Almost always I know the names and ages of others dogs long before I know anything about their owners, even if we meet daily.Oh, and you have a new fan of the doggycorps project.

Biased? No way!! :) Thanks Arjan--I'm totally right there with you. I've long wanted to take the project outside of the US and explore countries with different relationships with dogs. I would LOVE to hear any stories--or interviews--you may be inspired to do out walking!
Oh, that is so great. I'm not very good at interviews, but I'll see what I can come up with. There won't be these cool animations like you have, though.

I like how you found a touchpoint for creativity through asking people to speak about their dogs' perspectives. People feel deeply for their dogs and I believe emotional attachments like that bring out the good stuff.
Thanks Lindsey! Right there with you on the emotional side of things--it's always neat when we can connect with new people on that level.
Awesome perspective-building project, Jenine!
Thanks Meena!

talk_to_the_dogs_creating_community_from.title: Talk to the Dogs--Creating Community From the Ground Up

comments.text: Good idea! I started a company in Chicago called Fooda that connects local restaurants with residential high rises for dinner.  Once or twice a week a local restaurant "pops-up" in the high rise lobby with a set menu of some of their most popular dishes.  The restaurants love it because they get exposure and extra revenue and the residents enjoy the convenience as well as the opportunity to interact with their neighbors. Bringing the residents together is a key starting point for taking action in the community, great job!
Thanks Jim! Would love to visit your company in chicago one day!
Hey Karl, Congrats! I would love to have a look at combining this concept with the Tool Library in the hope of getting something realised. Let me know what you think!
Thanks James, would love to explore more with you

Karl & Team - we're so sorry that we may have lost some of the updates to this concept over the last 72 hours - we lost the AWS server stack which included the backup and even after working through the night some updates escaped us.  We have put in place some measures to ensure that this won't happen again.We've extended the Refinement Phase to the 27th to give everyone extra time to re-upload their content and to push your concept even further - apologies again if you did lose any updates...
Hi guys, I just noticed the black out on the site. I managed to recover some of the stuff, hope people will still be contributing!
Hi Karl,Don't mean to promote my own ideas! But thought this might be an inspiration... http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/concepting/neighbourhood-art/
Great idea! To further refine the idea, I am wondering if we can approach the Residents' Committee to start something? Best Curry competition? Table tennis tournament? CNY Spring Cleaning sale?

Are there always "residents committes" in each high rise? I wonder if their participation is easier if you do not decide an activity for them, but just let them vote on what they wish to have happening there. And make a schedule, so that all of the popular ideas can be created together with them. It will survive and catch on much better, if you give residents a better sense of inclusiveness, and ownership of the project. (see my concept proposal of http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/concepting/let-citizens-design-name-brand/ )

I think there is a Residents' Committee for every neighborhood, maybe every dozen or so HDB flats. Great to have the residents vote for what they want. The RC also manages the bulletin boards at the void deck of every HDB block. Maybe there can be some things that allow people to vote there too.
Quite like this inspiration. Might be relevant?http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/inspiration/i-like-_____-on-this-street

I share the same sentiments. Our void decks could do much better with just being as it is now. In fact, we might even encourage residents to own the place. So I had an earlier idea about getting people to adopt the deck. What do you think? http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/inspiration/adopt-a-deck-for-hdb-flats-maybe/Also, thought there is another group that suggested possible ideas on activities that could be held at the void decks. here is the link. http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/concepting/dish-in-dish-out-potluck-for-a-cause#c-0a02b2b73a1c072b8b3be7454f6555d6How might want build a deeper sense of ownership by people who live there and have their stories build over time?

Karl, nice one -- your concept made it to the NEA Challenge Shortlist. We liked how your idea made use of an untapped resource to create a sense of ownership and make residents feel proud of where they live. Now that we're in Refinement, think about which people or organisations might be needed to get this off the ground, and what might take place in the space once welcoming signs take the place of negative messages.  For more tips on how to iterate and prototype your idea during the Refinement phase, read here http://bit.ly/connect-refinetips and check this Lowdown: http://bit.ly/oi_refine
Completely agree! In a city like Singapore where space is scarce, the void decks are (or should be) an amazing asset!
Thanks Maria!

Great, you could take a look at a concept proposal of Mr. Arjan Tupan "Pop-up-museums" and also : http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/inspiration/open-mic-night/ and a couple of my concepts that need venues, like "movie-nights" and art exhibitions
Thanks Johan!

Great leverage of existing space for community connections, Karl! And I can imagine it teaming up with concepts like: http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/concepting/dish-in-dish-out-potluck-for-a-cause/ well Look forward to seeing you on further conversations across this challenge.
Thanks Meena!

unvoid_decks.title: Community decks - The "Unvoided decks" (UPDATED ON 25/12/12 CHRISTMAS DAY!)

py/tuple: How easy would it be for citizens to get involved and take initiative for this idea?
Very easy; this would rely on ground-up participation from the beginning.
Somewhat easy; there are ways for citizens to get involved, but an outside organiser may be needed to sustain and grow this concept.
This concept needs to be led and maintained by the government or private business.
Can you build this concept on top of something that already exists, like an organisation, physical space, or system?
Yes. This could fold into, or extend from, something that already exists.
This concept taps existing networks for a few things, but also needs a lot of new processes, materials, relationships, etc.
This concept requires a new system to be built to support it.
After the initial launch and support, could this concept be sustained and cared for over time by the community it's designed to serve?
Absolutely! This concept is easy to keep going.
It depends. There are opportunities for growth, but it's not yet clear how the concept would thrive after launch.
Probably not. A lot of effort would be needed to keep this concept going.
Does this concept create community?
Yes. It naturally brings people together and inspires them to take care of one another.
There is potential to create a thriving community.
No. It doesn't galvanize people to come together for a common cause or interest.
Overall, how do you feel about this concept?
It rocked my world.
I liked it but preferred others.
It didn't get me overly excited.

community_gardens.description: Use various other groups of the communities to build events around the community garden. Moss-graffiti is used as advertisement as part of the garden's environment.  To incorporate a kampung-style feeling, encouraging cottage-style industries.
community_gardens.creator: 540ad0e22264b2438f7045bbba0c3bca

comments.text: Hi Jackson, An inspiration you might draw on is the greenschool in Bali http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/inspiration/the-greenschool-where-students-build-their-own-playground-and-grow-their-own-food./Here kids build their own gardens to produce some of the food which they are served for lunch. Perhaps a way to get a garden started and funded is to bridge these community gardens with the school curriculum or kindergartens.

Community gardens are key and they drive education and sustenance.With that said, I think that it can be very hard for a lot of people, especially those that don't have green thumbs may not be attracted to this central area...Incorporating Class Rooms, Event Spaces and Outdoor Movie Screens may add a social and cool factor that intrigues guests to learn more about the community garden without getting their hands dirty!  :-)
I agree- outdoor movies and musical performances always attract spontaneous interest... and a garden setting could only make it more enchanting!

well, why don't you take a look at some of my concept proposals, I could use some feedback and additional ideas for improvement and refinement of my ideas: http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/concepting/portable-projector/

Hi Jackson,This is great and highlights the importance of history and place. It would be great to see children incorporated into the community garden concept. Take a look at the Edible Schoolyard Inspiration - http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/inspiration/food-building-healthy-communities/I'd like to echo Meena's suggestion to connect to the other inspirations and concepts to have community gardens as the central node.

Hi Jackson-Are these community gardens planted and maintained by the community? These have been popping up all over Austin, Texas and they have been very successful. Some of the gardens have a fee for the plot that you plant in. I also know of others where you donate a certain % of what your grow to the community. I think this is a great way to bring the community together.

Great thoughts, Jackson! Tip: If you hit the Update button on the right of your post you could go in and add relevant posts to your Build Upon feature. This helps others connect the dots between various Inspirations and lines of thought.

This is an instance of where you wish you had the opportunity to experience a place before you give advice on how you think it could be better.  The idea of a river-based economy is pretty cool.   Wondering what the river system is like there.  Might be cool to use barges for gardens and community spaces as they require less land.  They could also be moved if need be or shared with other communities.

community_gardens.title: Community Gardens

community_gardens_create_ownership_a_sen.description: Community gardens provide green space, community ownership, local landmarks and create a communal space for people to share, and beauty as well as food!
community_gardens_create_ownership_a_sen.creator: 1a4cf499f7bed372be887cb77b09991c

comments.text: Nice idea!  They tried it out in Singapore too, under a programme called "Communities in Bloom".  The key driver was having the local council tell residents that it was "ok" for them to use pockets of spaces for planting shrubs, plants, etc. It took off quite well, as it was just giving legitamacy to something people had been wanting to do already.  You can read about it at this URL - http://www.nparks.gov.sg/cms/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=62&Itemid=85

Thanks Leon, that's good to know it also worked in Singapore. And that makes sense since Singapore prides itself on being verdant and green. Has the government done any follow-up research to see if this did in fact create more of a community feel in addition to more greenery?

Sorry i took so long to reply !!  There was an update about the number of gardens increasing every year..."Community in Bloom Awards 2010 saw a 45% increase in the number of participating gardens this year compared to the previous year." Read more at  -http://www.nparks.gov.sg/cms/index.php?option=com_news&task=view&id=213&Itemid=50
Thanks Leon.

I think there's something about the challenge of cooperation and participation that makes these successful for building community.  The garders have to cooperate to make them work - either by working out what the social contract is going to be (in the beginning when the place is being created), or by agreeing to abide by that contract as newcomers.  For example, community gardens with separate plots have to figure out an equitable system for assigning them, and plot-holders have to abide by the rules of the site - an example is not to create shade on others' plots by planting trees.
Great stuff, Beth! Visiting community gardens here in New Zealand, I've been impressed by the diversity of locals involved  in terms of age, expertise and cultural background.
Thanks Meena! I agree, community gardens are able to combine a range of different gardening experiences and expertise. :)

community_gardens_create_ownership_a_sen.title: Community gardens create ownership, a sense of place, and shared goals

community_input_suggestion_website_with_.description: Create a website that everyone can join and allows the people to input/post their ideas. Community members vote on ideas and points are awarded based on interest and support. Ideas with the most points are put forward to the gov't and for action.
community_input_suggestion_website_with_.creator: 5c721798c073cb92d98511271e5e6327

comments.text: Great concept. It's almost like Open IDEO but customized for community initiatives in Singapore. I wonder what inspiration can be drawn from OpenIDEO when designing this new website? There can be the inspiration phase where citizens suggest things that are working locally (in smaller areas in Singapore) or globally... moving on to Concepting and so on. The Govt. can be the challenge sponsor.

Thanks Vishal; taking the ideas through phases of refinement would be able to generate stronger and more tangible ideas. This can even be incorporated into the point system, for example: the further your idea makes it through the phases the more weight it's points receive.

Nice one, Brian. I wonder if we could further inspire voters' buy-in by appointing a citizen liaison for each project, or by giving more weight to the votes of the people who have helped the government and private sector see past projects through to completion. One idea: If you commit at least 4 hours per month to volunteering for an initiative you voted for, your voice carries more weight on the site. Just a thought! Thanks for the inspiration :)

That would be a great addition Lindsey. Achieving voter buy-in would be the most challenging aspect of for the idea to work and appointing a local champion for the suggested project would certainly help. Having someone tangible that the voter is familiar with has the potential to inspire further action. Your idea for additional ways to get points is really good because it has the secondary effect of creating action. Thanks for your comment!

Fab build, Lindsey. Brian  you can make edits to your idea at any time by hitting the Update Entry button up there on the right if you're keen to add ideas from collaborative comments here. Plus you can give any credit you feel is due, as your idea grows, via the Virtual Teams field. Great to see you multi-taksing across 2 challenges!

comments.text: I love PechaKucha nights!In fact, we've actually had a couple of them in Singapore already. Check it out: http://www.pecha-kucha.org/night/singapore/
I love the democratic nature of the PechaKunga nights, how any one can present about anything and the 20x20 format.  Brilliant!

And so much inspiring content on all of the ones I've attended! It's also possible for local organisers to select a theme for an event  imagine if you had one specifically on Connecting Communities. Excited to see what Pecha Kucha nights might inspire for our upcoming Concepting phase...

foster_green_facades.description: In dense areas such as Singapore or London, there is a lot of opportunity for green facades and hanging gardens. Like in this example, the Hotel Athenaeum, right in the centre of London.
foster_green_facades.creator: e49891fc1e51d004a85f60c500c0cb70

comments.text: Great stuff, Florian. And perhaps there might be lessons from this initiative in Singapore: http://www.npr.org/blogs/thesalt/2012/11/06/164428031/sky-high-vegetables-vertical-farming-sprouts-in-singapore

Thanks for the insightful link, Meena. Interesting, that it concludes with Singapore probably being the only place in the world, where growing vegetables vertically is an economically viable option. A usefull insight for the further course of this challenge, I guess. The great thing about roof-gardens as an alternative is, that people can actually spent time together and wonder around in the green environment. So that would also better answer the community demands of the brief

Vertical walls on the outside of our buildings in Singapore may not be very practical because of our weather here. When it is hot and sunny, the outside temperature can be about 38 degrees. When it is wet, it pours until we can have flash floods. Perhaps buildings with green facades, can have rain water collection pools and these pools can feed the water back after the rain.

comments.text: Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Inspiration!

Ah, I first saw the inspiration that was posted later about this same topic. And as I commented there, it's a big thing also in neighbouring Latvia (although the story of origin will slightly differ). It's a national day in which people get together to clean up, often with their colleagues organised by their employers. It has become a movement (I believe also in the third Baltic state Lithuania) that in a short time has become ingrained in society.

open_mic_night.description: I am a student at Washington University in St. Louis.  Last year, our school hosted an open mic during lunch in our University Center.  People could go up to the mic and say whatever they wanted.
open_mic_night.creator: b3989819ef426f3f292d7f48a1ead4e7

comments.text: Hi Michael, great idea. I think many of your questions have been answered by this inspiration:http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/inspiration/bearpit-karaoke-in-a-stone-amphitheatre-in-berlin-on-sunday-afternoonsThough, I also like, that in your example, people are free to use the mic for various things. So probably, a combination of both ideas would be great. Maybe different days or hours for different funtions of the open mic:  poetry slam karaoke speakers corner stand up comedy... it could also use the same mobile setup as in the Karaoke example, the sound-system on the bike, and move to different locations in the city, so the speakers corner would happen at a different time and place - e.g. during the day in front of the mayors office -  while the stand-up comedy would happen later in the evening, and in a park

I think an outdoor mic would be a really interesting experiment.  I think some toying around and rapid prototyping/validation with how to present it (appearance, context, signage, instructions, etc.) would be needed to ensure it had a positive effect, but it could be an amazing platform.
Great to hear of your enthusiasm for a local community-connecting initiative, Michael!
Great sharing of experience, and a wonderful conversation starter. I like how you start the debate by asking some well directed questions. Food for thought for the concepting phase.

seeclickfix.description: SeeClickFix is an app and website that lets community members to report potholes or other potential repairs to government.
seeclickfix.creator: 6fd5025c7938f2273a7b01f50ebae697

comments.text: It definitely has some ties to the "Hire A Tech Czar Inspiration" and I certainly feel that technology is only a tool and we have to dig down to find the deeper stimuli it activates.  In this case, it empowered individuals and gave them feedback and allowed them to follow their suggestions as opposed to dropping them in the black hole of government never to be seen again.  Just like when OpenIDEO was started people wanted to follow their concepts after the challenge was over because this is such a powerful platform that people care about what happens afterwards which is great.  What if you could track an idea through government like you would a package?  Perhaps it could offer suggestions to help push it through to the next stage to empower citizens to overcome the stereotypical bureaucracy and backlog by allowing passionate supporters to share in the workload.

Great share Marshall! And reminds me of the Snowmageddon initiative we had on a previous challenge: http://www.openideo.com/open/vibrant-cities/inspiration/technology-helps-communities-collaborate-/ Looking forward to what this might inspire in the upcoming Concepting phase. And seems to relate to this discussion also: http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/inspiration/hire-a-tech-czar/

I think you touch upon an important point, when you say that it acted as a catalyst. If tools like this are combined with something that happen 'in real life', it can become a very powerful concept for this challenge.
Thanks Marshall - This really works works well in the simple mode of one person reporting one problem.  It will be great to see how it can be broadened to be more of a way to connect people together.

abettersing.org_recognition_reward_and_f.description: Who doesn’t like a good pat on the back or a reward for a job well done?  Also friendly competition adds fun and excitement to any task.  Thus let’s develop a process to recognize & reward people for taking action and to enable friendly competition.
abettersing.org_recognition_reward_and_f.creator: b25ffa68ad761f8578cc61700c0140ed

comments.text: This concept can actually work. I have seem similar ideas implemented in other areas specially women's fashion. Do Good and Shop!

Great thoughts about recognition and rewards, Hao! I wonder if the sponsors + rewards might be more centered on local Singaporean businesses? Do you have thoughts on what they could be? Could there be potential to pick from a range of rewards from MRT vouchers to coffee perks at places like Pigeon Hole cafe? Would these only be for top scorers  or could it be more like if you get 100 points you can get a free coffee, etc to motivate participation across the board? Looking forward to seeing this idea evolve with collaborative conversation from others here...

Meena, I like the "free coffee for all who gets 100 points", definitely more inclusive.  Localizing the rewards makes sense, particularly MRT or cab vouchers since most Singaporeans use both types of transport.  Per an inspiration, Singapores like shopping, eating and surfing the net (http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/singaporelocalnews/view/1173530/1/.html) thus would be good idea for the rewards to relate to those areas.

Indeed Hao  but perhaps there's an opportunity to nudge towards things within that list which speak to aspirations for this challenge like community and the environment? I'm sure there are local companies making great food and products which could be used as rewards which are aligned with those aspirations. Here's hoping some of your fellow Singaporeans chime in here with ideas too :^)

Anne, your concept made it to the NEA Challenge Shortlist. Congratulations! We liked the reduce-reuse-recycle mentality, combined with sport and community-building. Moving into refinement, we'd love to see more details about how you would make the Dragon Boat Challenge come to life: Who would run it? How would you educate people about boat-building if they had never done it before? Where would it be held and how would boats be transported there? How would you get the word out? For more tips on how to iterate and prototype your idea during the Refinement phase, read here http://bit.ly/connect-refinetips and check this Lowdown: http://bit.ly/oi_refine
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!

It reminds me of a polish recycle-design festival "Przetwory" http://www.przetworydesign.com/en/film/Designers and artists for two days make objects out of all sorts of rubbish and old stuff. There were some really great projects there and the festival became extremely popular, now it's the 7th edition.

Anne, I love this idea - it's great the way that you've thought about combining the competitive element to encourage collective action and improve the environment at the same time!
Thanks Nathan!

py/tuple: How easy would it be for citizens to get involved and take initiative for this idea?
Very easy; this would rely on ground-up participation from the beginning.
Somewhat easy; there are ways for citizens to get involved, but an outside organiser may be needed to sustain and grow this concept.
This concept needs to be led and maintained by the government or private business.
Can you build this concept on top of something that already exists, like an organisation, physical space, or system?
Yes. This could fold into, or extend from, something that already exists.
This concept taps existing networks for a few things, but also needs a lot of new processes, materials, relationships, etc.
This concept requires a new system to be built to support it.
After the initial launch and support, could this concept be sustained and cared for over time by the community it's designed to serve?
Absolutely! This concept is easy to keep going.
It depends. There are opportunities for growth, but it's not yet clear how the concept would thrive after launch.
Probably not. A lot of effort would be needed to keep this concept going.
Does this concept create community?
Yes. It naturally brings people together and inspires them to take care of one another.
There is potential to create a thriving community.
No. It doesn't galvanize people to come together for a common cause or interest.
Overall, how do you feel about this concept?
It rocked my world.
I liked it but preferred others.
It didn't get me overly excited.

wingpost.creator: 44dc10596d8e5b9e5671363f7fbbfd46

comments.text: Annet & Team - we're so sorry that we may have lost some of the updates to this concept over the last 72 hours - we lost the AWS server stack which included the backup and even after working through the night some updates escaped us.  We've extended the Refinement Phase to the 27th to give everyone extra time to re-upload their content and to push your concept even further - apologies again if you did lose any updates...
I have updated it again!

I remember suggesting asking questions at the top of the postbox. And changing these questions say, every week or so.Johan had the idea to write directly on the boxes, instead of using stickers.I hope you guys upload the updated images again.
yes, something like that, and I also had idea to buy sheets of sticker labels, to make people sketch, paint and cut out their own stickers
the idea to write directly on the surface was related to if you could find whiteboard pens that don't leave permanent marks. (anyone could redesign their letterbox each week or as often as they like)

There is likely to be a barrier to kick-start such an initiative precisely because often in an appartment building people don't know each other. Posting habilities or needs when you don't know who will ring you up even if it's to help you may scare certain people off. Maybe combining this iniative with monthly neighbors happy hour/lunch etc for people to know each other would help resolve this issue.

Hello Anne-Marie, on "barrier to kickstart"; we had this exact challenge; as an outsider it is often possible to find 2-3 enthousiasts in the building, but to get other people involve is 'only' possible if they realize themselves things should happen for the better.   For this we developed "Streekt/block Wearther & Forecast". The few enthousiasts first ask door to door a simple question if the like the block/street and if in 1 year they feel it will be better-same-worse. This breaks the ice, before offering solutions/activities. This can also be helpful for this concept.http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/concepting/ring-10-doorbells-with-1-question-streetbarometer-singapore

Hi Paul, Cool concept (or should I say product :) )you have!  I think this would be a great start for Wingpost, I like the fact that your solution is also low-tech; that fits with the Wingpost concept. @Anne-Marie, I indeed think a start is needed. I would think of gathering/evening meetings where this concept is explained and where people can start. I think that Wingpost should be kept as simple as possible, avoiding barriers. I think that posting a note in someones letterbox is easy and does not scare people much. Wingpost should first introduce neighbors to each other (by setting up dates) before they should exchange needs/actions etc.

Thanks, it's a concept with trial runs which seem to work. The simplicity to seed is key. Simply announcing on a poster in the building or a note in the mailbox some people might ring your doorbell with the purpose to ask if they like the street/block and if they think in one year it will be worse-same-better is all. If this is done with 6 multiple choice questions you have data for a graph to give back to people on a 'date/meeting'. People will be curious to results and come. Power of seeding sense of belonging, and a neighbor wants to know if his/her feeling is shared with the street/block. Or not. People who can identify with the result, and if negative, it empowers to get involved... way beyond the question shall we take action yes or no. Happy if I can help, just put me in the team if you like.

Thanks Paul! I think that's quite a smart way to kick start this initiative.. i.e. to get people interested in change to come together to help! This can be done very easily by posting small notes into other mail boxes, which is common in Singapore. Great! Team: We should try to implement something soon! :)

Agree with the rest that there needs to be a starting group first, and it could just be low-fi things like organising a community enthusiast user group meetup. These people also act as 'enthusiastic ambassadors' of the community which are spread throughout the block to encourage participation in community events too!

Congratulations, Annet! Your concept made it to the NEA Challenge Shortlist. We thought your concept had great potential to "break the block of ice" that sometimes exists between neighbors. As we move into Refinement, and to further thaw those relations through your concept, think about how you might scale up the level of interactions. Before someone is comfortable leaving their children with a neighbour, they may need to get to know them better, perhaps through an interaction on an elevator. What might the small steps be that people can take to get to know one another naturally, on the way to being a bigger presence in one another's lives? For more tips on how to iterate and prototype your idea during the Refinement phase, read here http://bit.ly/connect-refinetips and check this Lowdown: http://bit.ly/oi_refine

This is a cool idea especially in apartment buildings where a lot of people seem to feel that no ones lives in the building because they never see anyone. Which is the case in my building. But my question is about where would the talents be shown for others to see?? I see te first picture with all the mailboxes, but I don't see the space where the information could be displayed and shared.
I agree, It shows that people are living there :) The intention is to use the small space at every personal letterbox. It is indeed not shown in the picture, but the drawing shows it.
Way to go Singapore OpenSTORMERS!

games.description: Design different types of games together with different groups and teams. The fundamentals and mechanics of the games should be to inform lots of small bits of educational knowledge and fun, around environmental issues, energy, ecology…
games.creator: 656863f55543ea22d1dbce290f237277

comments.text: So many ideas within one concept, awesome! The thing that stood out the most to me is the idea about a game that makes you physically interact with the environment, people or city. Although Singapore is very hot and humid, it could be a way of exploring the city and meet other people who are participating in the game. It could also be a part of the collaborative commute in that sense. hehe. Another thing that is great about this concept is that it has a purpose of bringing people together to work on something together with an end result that they can envision. Sometimes these open ended questions of "how might we make our environment better is too much to handle in one bite" and your game ideas make it bitable, but also makes it something desirable to be a part of.

One popular game (that doesn't require any material or paraphernalia) is the "yellow car"-games. One version is that if you see a yellow car in a street, you scream "yellow car" and you are allowed to punch your friend on the shoulder, if you where the first to call it out.Then there are another "Car-versions", where each participant choose a car colour: "Silver", "Red", "Yellow". And each person counts the numbers of cars that they see with that colour, for a boring bus ride or if just sitting in a caf and watching traffic, the one that sees the most in one hour is the winner, or when the ride is ended, or keep the competition carrying on a whole week, or even set a limit of 100, and the first one to see 100 cars of "their colour" wins.
I heard that in USA the same game exists, but it is called "Punch-buggy-blue", everytime you see a blue buggy "VwBeetle" you can punch the person closest to you on their arm.

I really like the educational aspect of this idea. It seems as though when it comes to recycling, energy efficiency, carbon footprint, emissions most problems stem from a severe lack of education. Maybe the answer in addition to these events you mention would be to require  these topics to be included within public school curriculum, as part of a "green education".

Thanks, I have no knowledge at all about school curriculums, but I know that in Swedish schools it exists a lot of basic knowledge about recycling and ecology and renewable energy, to prepare students for choosing career paths within sustainable industries. there's also engineer colleges focused onto wind power industry :)

And people can know why they should recycle, it is mostly a matter of adapting new habits. And if you play games, that influence the connections of the habits and the benefits of why it is good to recycle and cycle, you instill those habits faster in people, at least in the younger ones, that are quick to catch on new trends, and influence their parents

games.title: Games — workshops DIY design

democratic_air_conditioning.creator: 7e7dcb823cb8bac78bee007e8041492e

comments.text: Sounds a lot like the Climate Right application I've been making since the UP Singapore World Citites Summit event in July. We used that graphic in our presentation too. https://mobile.twitter.com/markcleverley/status/219617921255739394http://m.stjobs.sg/career-resources/workplace-success/too-cold-or-hot-in-the-office-tell-climate-app/a/71975
I actually think it is identical to our Climate Right app

Hi Desmond, Animesh,Fantastic that you are already creating an app to address this issue! I guess it shouldn't really come as a surprise, as it's an irritation to almost every office worker in Singapore and many other places. I'll update the concept to reference the App you already have in production if you're ok with that? I've had a look at the links Desmond provided, and agree that the intitial collection of mobile data using GPS is exactly what I had in mind too. However, I think there is so much room to build onto what you are proposing, with the addition of gamification and forum elements in order to create a real buzz and critical mass for widespread adoption. It would really need to permeate social media; this I why I tried to come up with a catchy/cheesy slogan, like DC/AC. I think that term could be a blanket reference to both your ClimateRight app and Johan's lo-fi suggestion added below. I see the article was from July, I guess you've moved on a long way from there and have considered all these things.I have no idea whether contributing to this thread futher would be in conflict with your ongoing business interest, but if not, then obviously I'd be over the moon to hear your further thoughts on how this could be tailored to NEA's brief!
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!
Thanks! :)

You wouldn't need an App or anything high-tech for each office, how about a whiteboard or bulletin board. Each staff can write what temp they wish to have for today. you could perhaps show what the daily outside temp is on that board. And when enough staff members written their requested work temp, you calculate a medium value.Perhaps it is possible to create "zones" in the office, with those that prefer cooler temp can rearrange and move closer to the AC, and those that prefer some degrees slightly warmer work temperature can move farthest away from the AC outlets(But to spread the info around a whole city/country you need some kind of viral campaign on social forums and magazine ads.)

I hear that AC-units can cause staff to catch cold easily, if it is on too cool or if the filters are not cleaned, so you could perhaps calculate how many sick days per year each company have due to this? And by regulating the temp a bit closer to outdoors temperature you could perhaps drastically reduce the number of sick days of the staff, and improve procutivity ?
I like the idea of a lo-fi prototype that doesn't require any new technology other than a whiteboard, good addition Johan!

Lo-fi option is a good shout. Wondering how best to build in the sponsor/client's role into this... Perhaps they could supply small branded whiteboards to each office with an inviting, cartoonish personalized (to each office) touch.The reason I like the online approach is that I hope the live collection and regurgitation of data from the offices participating would gamify the concept, and encourage competition and greater savings. I guess you could still have a competitive element if he whiteboard version collects and publishes the data form its energy supply point regularly though.

Great idea, James. Over air-conditioning of offices, shops, restaurants, cinemas etc drove me nuts when I lived in Hong Kong. It almost seemed like a form of status how cool you could make a space compared to outside :^) I didn't think there was a lot of thought given to actual comfort nor resulting pollution. Loving the way your idea connects people over this issue!

Agreed. I always hated that in the US. Strangely, in the UK we often don't have airconditioning in smaller offices. However, in the winter all of the shops keep their doors open. It has gotten so i think stores are closed when their doors are shut, but I shudder to think what this does to the environment. I read once about an initiative in Japan to encourage men not to wear ties to the office in the summer, and they "warmed up" the buildings by 1 degree. What other signals could we send in offices or shops to encourage people to get behind a change in AC or heat? In London, we could simply have signs made up for shop doors to say they're open but keeping the doors shut for the environment.

Nice one  could be a campaign around promoting "Yes, we're open  & conserving energy"  with the implication that others with their doors open aren't ;^) Actually a few years ago New York passed a law on this: http://ny.racked.com/tags/this-store-blows but given a lot of non-compliance I think there could be cleverer ways of getting businesses to jump on the aspirational band-wagon of conserving energy around air cooling and heating.

Hi Amy, Meena, thanks so much for the stories! I left London 3 years ago so know nothing about this open door travesty! How about a slogan like 'Open Minds: Closed Doors'.. or 'Open Thinking: Closed Doors'. I find it crazy that a situation like this could actually be legally allowable when the building regulations are so focused on negating heat loss through strict codes and the calculation of 'U-Values'. The flip side is that there has to be a certain amount of air change and circulation every hour so there are pros and cons.I think the Japanese example became succesful overnight when the Prime Minister was seen publically endorsing it; as soon as the country's most public figure was seen in public without a tie, suddenly it was ok for everyone else to dress down. Here in SG, fortunately ties have never been mandatory! But persuading a figure-head business to impliment aircon limitations (whilst maintaining comfort) might put an end to the AC 'arms race' as described by Meena.

democratic_air_conditioning.title: Democratic Air-Conditioning (Update: 'DC/AC'...!)

portable_projector.description: Enables a frequently scheduled, reoccuring & circulating "multi-media- screenings" out in public places, you will just need a white wall or portable-film screen and a power outlet (can be supplied with extension cord, through a window from a shop)
portable_projector.creator: 656863f55543ea22d1dbce290f237277

comments.text: Related venture but whole different context: Check out what one Salim Baba is doing with his projector to connect/commune with folks in North Kolkata  http://youtu.be/92bJd-_mpRU. Inspiring stuff.

Screenings are definitely a fun way to gather folks and are already popular in many communities, especially in the summer months. They may be sponsored by businesses, community centers, schools, etc., and they are hosted in a diversity of outdoor venuesfrom university lawns to shopping center parking lots. Sometimes screenings are stand-alone events; sometimes they are a part of a larger community-wide gathering, such as art walks or kids' fair.So on the surface, the idea isn't novel. My question then is: What differentiates your concept from what's already out there?

Of course the basic idea is not new. But someone would need to type it, to suggest it for this challenge :)I think what is new is to collect the citizens own films (crowdsourced, open source and Creative Cmmons) and make a rotating schedule, so you show the same videos in all the neighbourhoods, travel around frequently, show one evening after another continuously. And update the "library" with new videos that citizens create after becoming inspired from the videos that they saw, on these screenings.
Aha, I like this idea of sourcing CC content.

Hi Johan, Good idea, loads of potential uses... a question for development: what kind of content best draws communities closer? It may not be popular with everybody, but sceening live sport outdoors usually draws big crowds, old and young. In Singapore the EPL (English Premier League, soccer) is by far and away the most popular sport in terms of followers, so negotiating some kind of special screening rights with the broadcaster to enable these gatherings in communities, rather than just outside bars, would perhaps be necessary.Perhaps EPL is not the best avenue.. what about live screening (or replays, once its' dark!) of children's local school sports matches, so that the less mobile members of the communities (grandparents) can share their passion and support their grandchildren without having to travel to and from the pitches.

Well, I would be extremely hesitant to purchase screening rights for such events, since it could drain totally the budget and the other content that can be locally created.And why screen childrens sports, that would take away crowd from the actual sports field? Let the sports team create promotional video clips, as "commercials" with time and date of when their next matches will occur on the nearest sports field! To bring increased audience to next matches!

Agree it would not be a good use of funds to screen EPL games. The only instance I could see this working in would be if the broadcaster (usually SingTel or StarHub in Singapore) were to provide the service free of charge. This could be incentivised by allowing them to stage a product roadshow in the adjacent space (reference to Arjan's Pop-Up Museum). This would probably be in relation to mobile phone sales and contracts. There is a kind of Faustian pact in this sort of arrangement, but it could be one way in which for-profit businesses can help bind communities together.I guess in my mind I was trying to imagine content that would stimulate conversation between strangers and make a deep connections; for this they would need to stay seated and watch for a good few minutes. I agree it would not be great if offering a video replay meant less people attended live events, but can you imagine the possibility of kid who's father or mother works long hours, being able to sit down with his extended family and friends (and their families) and watch a replay of the game (or school play) together in the evening...

In the neighborhood I live in, we have monthly outdoor movie nights hosted by local businesses. The businesses rotate who provides food (hotdogs, popcorn, etc), and a family friendly movie is played. Some chairs are already set up, but most people bring their own, and you can bring your own food and drinks. It is a great way to get people out and about, and encourages you to connect with your neighbors. I have really enjoyed it and have gotten to know more people. What this also does is builds on the community connection. As residents spend more time in their community and with their community, they begin to develop a bond and sense of pride. This leads to desires to improve or maintain the community.
Forgot to mention: this is also a great way for local businesses to get their name out.

Yes, yes, and yes! I was thinking that also school projects could be like: bring a video camera to a business owner, for example bicycle repair shop, and let school children interview about maintenance advice, what type of tires and helmets and other safety equipment are good and recommended. (transform this model for all other types of local businesses) Goodwill for the business, teaching media skills to school kids, instilling pride in the community and so on :)

portable_projector.title: Portable projector (show citizens visual content in large scale)

pasar_malam_reinvented.description: Local night markets are still common in Singapore. Let's make them truly local by having citizens contribute to what's on offer.
