neighborhood_dining_halls.description: Transform restaurants into weekly dining halls with meal plans for local residents. Over regular meals, neighbors will build community at themed Social Tables and  collaboratively address issues at Challenge Tables.
neighborhood_dining_halls.creator: 01de726d5109212c1e7bead21f7e5a0a

comments.text: Hopefully, this comment isn't too late! When I read this concept I was reminded of a documentary, called Happy that I saw on Netflix. If you have an account or get get your hands on the film, watch the segment that starts at about 38:40. It covers cohousing communities in Denmark, a country rated one of the happiest on earth. In these communities, all families share responsibilities and benefits. A key aspect where this is seen is in the community meals. Each community member cooks one or two times a month and also shares clean up chores. Plus, families eat together in a large dining hall.

I love this idea!  In particular, I love how it's ripe for organically fostering community ownership and spread across communities.  After you pilot/seed the concept in a few communities, you could package the concept in a way that a variety of actors in any community - restaurants, nonprofit organizations, schools, citizens - could run with the idea.  This neighborhood dining hall "toolkit" could include things like a playbook on how to recruit people in your community, sample marketing collateral, etc.  I also think this creates a nice offline forum that could compliment a lot of neighborhood driven online tools (e.g., neighborland, nextdoor).And a random business model idea, what if local organizations, people, companies could sponsor table topics?  You'd have to do this carefully to avoid "selling out" the community conversation, but I suspect it could be done.

I love this idea Ashley! I also read that NY Times article and upon reflection I think it's very true. Communities are isolated by their individual walls and food is something that could serve to bring people together regularly. The social tables seem the most viable to me, as something like "advice for new parents" seems really easy and relatable  -people will be willing to discuss and draw from their own experiences.I'm wondering about the differences between a "challenge table" and a "social table". It seems like people coming together to discuss a community problems will be focused on problems of a social nature. So is the difference between a challenge and social table just that challenge tables are more high level, abstract problems? And social tables are for dispensing personal, family-focused advice?

Ashley, this is coming along really nicely. I love the scenario you've set out, and I think the idea could translate well to Singapore, where food centres lined with restaurants are present in almost every neighbourhood. They each have a common eating area that could be a perfect setting for a dining hall evening. I'm wondering who your initial champions might be. Who, or what group of people, might find the venue, get in touch with the restaurant, etc.? I would love to understand more about the team that will shepherd this from start to finish. Would they be incentivised for their time and effort? Is there a group that might already be intrinsically motivated to take this on? Can't wait to see how this continues to evolve!

I think my response to your question was lost, Lindsey. Just wanted to say I really appreciated your question and I refined the concept to address it. I wrote above:The relationship could be initiated and mediated by a local non-profit organization, such as City Harvest Community Services Organization (CHCSA): http://www.chcsa.org.sg/2012/index.htm

Could I play "devils advocate" just a little while? your concept is about eating food, like in a restaurant, but with questions? what is your unique selling point? what do you imagine people will experience/produce/learn/achive from it? What is different from going to a restaurant?

Im glad you asked, Johan. The selling point is that the dining halls would provide a forum for getting to know your neighbors and creating a sense of community. The features that distinguish it from restaurants would help to accomplish this. They include:1)  Meal plans that encourage you to keep going back to the same restaurant week after week. You dont have to coordinate times to see your neighbors; you just run into them at the neighborhood dining hall each week.2)  Group norms that encourage rather than discourage mixing. At normal restaurants, its rare to sit down with a stranger and strike up a conversation. The promotional materials for the dining halls will explain the mission so that the people who opt in will be people who want to make new connections.  3)  Table topics that break the ice. Since Challenge Tables require collaboration, neighbors will come away feeling like theyre part of the same team.Does that address your question? Thanks for commenting!

Ashley - we're so sorry that we may have lost some of the updates to this concept over the last 72 hours - we lost the AWS server stack which included the backup and even after working through the night some updates escaped us.  We've extended the Refinement Phase to the 27th to give everyone extra time to re-upload their content and to push your concept even further - apologies again if you did lose any updates...

Hey Ashley! Great concept! I'm a big fan of bringing in local restaurants. I had posted a comment-lost with the server issue-about how I think the challenge and topic tables would be good at keeping interactions new. I do wonder if there are ways to encourage ongoing new interactions at the open tables. Perhaps a "meet someone new" reward for a discounted meal. Perhaps a vote system about who created the most new interactions during an event to encourage networkers to bring people together.

The simplicity of providing a platform to have engaging conversations while eating delicious food is fantastic -- I especially like the idea of creating a virtual community in order to plan for subsequent events.  With the 'challenges' table -- I think it'd be fun to encourage members to submit news or opinion articles to help kickstart a discussion -- and let a more general/theoretical question emerge from there.

Hi Ashley,The concept is great.  I have thought about this a lot and have some psychological insights on how to really structure it.One huge problem I see with typical town hall meetings is with how boring they can be when discussion is circling an issue you don't care about too much.  If there were som eway to solve this, it could be critical.For instance, if certain tables had specific themes, with "inspirations" on it (newspaper articles and other media), then perhaps you could attract like-minded people to work together on specific issues they care about without having to sit through everything else.There's a lot here, but I think taking a really informed approach, using ideas from the study of human social behaviour and attention/engagement, could make this thing ACTUALLY work (as opposed to being an idea which looks attractive on paper but doesn't persuade the average person to actually engage).Another potential direction could be to couple the program with musical performers, mixed media virtuosos, and other local artists.

Thanks so much for this suggestion, Jay. Fantastic idea about tables with "inspirations" like newspaper articles. I adapted that idea into "Challenge Tables" and "Social Tables" in the description above (in italics). The Challenge Tables could be like an in-person OpenIDEO experience! Or they could be less structured if the community prefers. Do you think the updated concept successfully addresses your concerns about people getting stuck in discussions they're not interested in?
I think it's great work Ashley.  Please let me know if you want my input on any other directions forward!  Glad to see my Inspiration came in useful somewhere.  Cheers :)

Wohoo  exciting updates, Ashley! Do you imagine a format for discussion / interaction over the course of the evening  or some kind of nudges that would move things beyond meeting & eating? I went to a dinner path recently in which people were asked to change seats between each course  certainly fuelled interaction. I wonder what other kinds of things might get people mixing & support onwards community organisation. With 11 days left for Refinement, we're excited about conversations which might grow on your post, leading to even more iteration...

Thanks, Meena! You're absolutely right that this concept was in need of a format for interaction. I built a format off of some of the ideas that others have posted here. (See "Challenge Tables" and "Social Tables" in italics above.) I'd love to hear what you think!
Wow  how awesome are you?! Exciting builds indeed.
I love this idea! I don't know any of my neighbors and would love to get to know some of them. I never see anyone in my building ever!

One small detail to encourage interaction among participants: Table Topics. Just put a thought provoking question and people can discuss their views around the topic. You pick whch table to sit at based on o topic you are interested in. :)
Love the Table Topics idea. I updated the concept to include it. Thanks!!!

I really like the idea: proximity, repeated and unplanned interactions and food!!! nice, really nice! I woud prefer the option of the weekly or monthly fees instead of the volunteering because in this way there is the opportunity to create some vacancies for unemployed persons.

I see your point, Samuele. I agree that it would be good to create jobs, but I also think it would be a trade-off with some of the benefits of the dining halls. Volunteer shifts could bring together members who don't know each other yet, give them a common goal, and foster friendship through teamwork. It could also help youth who participate to become more responsible and appreciative of the effort that goes into making the dining halls work. (See Nabil's concept about engaging youth in improving their communities: http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/concepting/youth-as-channels-to-drive-social-activity-in-their-neighborhoods/)The Park Slope Food Coop in Brooklyn has used the member-volunteer model to great success (except when members ask their nannies to cover their work shifts!): http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Park_Slope_Food_CoopI'd be interested in hearing what others think about this question. Thanks, Samuele, for bringing it up!

Ciao Ashley, I read the Nabil's concept, and you are right that the volunteering dimension would help the communities to boost more on social leverage. when I wrote about the monthly fee inspired this concepthttp://www.openideo.com/open/well-work/inspiration/the-amazings.Maybe  the "social business model" can be a parameter to adjust looking at the environment background  [unemployment rate, rate of young people out of the total, richness of the community and so on...]where you are implementing/scaling the concept

Samuele, I'm thinking you may be right that volunteering isn't the right fit for this model, at least for certain tasks. If you're going to sign up to eat there twice a week, seems like it's worth paying cooks rather than depending on your neighbors' dubious cooking skills! I definitely agree with your idea of adjusting the social business model for each context.
Positively brilliant!  Some sort of launch event would go a long way toward gaining a critical mass/buy in from the community, especially in young areas where crowds can be fickle.

Thanks for this excellent idea, Mathias! I integrated it into the concept. It's a great way to introduce people to the concept and let them see what one dinner is like before committing to any of the meal plans. Good thinking!

Ashley, congratulations on making the NEA Challenge Shortlist! We liked how you translated the university experience to another communal setting that isn't yet as dynamic as the relationships you might make in school. As we move into Refinement, think about ways to spread the word about the dining hall evenings, and specific responsibilities and resources that might be needed to sustain the programme. For more tips on how to iterate and prototype your idea during the Refinement phase, read here http://bit.ly/connect-refinetips and check this Lowdown: http://bit.ly/oi_refine
I love this idea and I think people come together at meals, and it then that we can start sharing our stories, lives and really create communities....

py/tuple: How easy would it be for citizens to get involved and take initiative for this idea?
Very easy; this would rely on ground-up participation from the beginning.
Somewhat easy; there are ways for citizens to get involved, but an outside organiser may be needed to sustain and grow this concept.
This concept needs to be led and maintained by the government or private business.
Can you build this concept on top of something that already exists, like an organisation, physical space, or system?
Yes. This could fold into, or extend from, something that already exists.
This concept taps existing networks for a few things, but also needs a lot of new processes, materials, relationships, etc.
This concept requires a new system to be built to support it.
After the initial launch and support, could this concept be sustained and cared for over time by the community it's designed to serve?
Absolutely! This concept is easy to keep going.
It depends. There are opportunities for growth, but it's not yet clear how the concept would thrive after launch.
Probably not. A lot of effort would be needed to keep this concept going.
Does this concept create community?
Yes. It naturally brings people together and inspires them to take care of one another.
There is potential to create a thriving community.
No. It doesn't galvanize people to come together for a common cause or interest.
Overall, how do you feel about this concept?
It rocked my world.
I liked it but preferred others.
It didn't get me overly excited.

photo_marathon_2014_competition.creator: 656863f55543ea22d1dbce290f237277

comments.text: Really love this idea! As I mentioned in the Inspiration phase, this has a total possibility of taking off! There was something similar in Singapore not too long ago; but it was more like a scavenger hunt. For National Day this year, there was also a photo competition going on, where people take photos according to themes like 'My favourite Singaporean places'. From what I knew, the competition seems limited to a certain group only though. For this idea, I think the unique point is opening it up as a community activity. I am especially interested in neighbourhood themes where people have to take pics in their neighbourhoods etc. These pictures can then be collated and displayed in the neighbourhood for people to learn more about the place they live in. Take me for example: I live in this neighbourhood called Toa Payoh, but am always found in another neighbourhood called Tiong Bahru because of the rich indie activity going on there as well as the rich history of Tiong Bahru (I can basically introduce Tiong Bahru's history to another foreigner). Recently I met some heritage enthusiasts and they told me so much more about Toa Payoh too (things which I didn't know). Would be great to learn more about my neighbourhood through activities like the photo marathon!

Hi, if the framework of the competition is in place, and scheduled regularly, you could allow for participants to reshape the theme for each event: Scavenger hunt (not bringing with the items to the finish, but just taking pictures of all the items on the list, so you could let participants send in the ideas of very rare or strange, heavy objects to "hunt" for)You should make participants send in theme words in the weeks before the start, and sometimes you could ask for "abstract" words / "clues" to make photographs think hard about, like a few of the themes could be "Homestead" or "Heritage" or "relaxing" Lets the playingfield be both themed, and loosely open to individuals interpretation and participation, and also discussions afterwards at the exhibition and open online voting process.I find that the times that I have had camera in hand, on my own street, I start to watch all the millions of details much closer, and wonder a lot more about them and about the neighbours

Love it, Johan. Great idea! I'm a big fan of the #FriFotos meme on Twitter. Every Friday, travel enthusiasts from all over the world share photos. The FriFotos hosts set a theme each week (announced on Tuesday), and when Friday starts, it kicks off.I like to take a lot of snapshots when I travel, or even just walk around town. I noticed that by sharing these on social networks, it made me look harder for 'shareable' things to photograph. And that made me more aware of and interested in my surroundings. It could really be useful.
PS: I have a board on Pinterest on which I share some FriFotos contributions, from myself and others. It could be a good way of presenting the photos:http://pinterest.com/arjantupan/frifotos/

Hi Johan, interesting post! Any chance you could find an image to go along with it? Images help grab attention and tell a story with higher impact. You should be able to use the 'Update entry' button on the right of your post and follow the instructions to add images from there. We know occasionally people have issues uploading images so let us know by hitting the Support tab on the left hand side of most pages of our site if you face any problems. Looking forward to seeing more of your inspiring ideas on OpenIDEO.

youth_as_channels_to_drive_social_activi.description: Use kids around the neighborhood to plan and give them the power to design, coordinate, and execute different programs for the neighborhood
youth_as_channels_to_drive_social_activi.creator: 5ff98888616232200642089ec0387e84

comments.text: This is a great idea. Not only would the community benefit, but the youth themselves would get a lot out of it. Research shows that youth clubs strengthen self-image and social skills through relationships with staff members, positive reinforcement for good behavior, and a sense of belonging. Kids who participate in youth clubs are less likely to have problems with drugs and alcohol, join gangs, and fail classes. In this case, they could also gain experience that could help them figure out what they want to do with their careers.

Fab thoughts, Nabil! Perhaps others here might chime in with potential names for your youth programs? And what other specifics can folks come up with together to grow this idea? (You can update your post at any time by hitting the Update Entry button up there on the right) Looking forward to some collaborative youth-focused builds!

youth_as_channels_to_drive_social_activi.title: Youth as channels to drive Social Activity in their  neighborhoods

comments.text: Wow  how cool are those Sherpas?! Great build for our challenge, Johan. And I wonder whether there might be learnings for this to be drawn from Caine's Arcade / Imagination Foundation: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ul9c-4dX4Hk

let_the_people_build.description:
Collect ideas from the local community. Support and fund the build of their favourite concept - Watch them use it with their friends and look after the surrounding space.
Allow them to own part of their local environment.
let_the_people_build.creator: 0d68366e439f762c5fb44b5e266b19f3

comments.text: Great thoughts & great sketch, Paddy!
Thanks Meena,What kind of projects do you think people might vote for and be ale to build in their local communities? Would be great to have your thoughts and builds : )

Might be some build ideas here http://www.openideo.com/open/vibrant-cities/winners-announced/decode-the-codes/ + here http://www.openideo.com/open/vibrant-cities/winners-announced/opencity-bringing-open-source-princi/ ?

I really like this idea, especially having the local authority provide the building materials.  I think the concept could leverage the digital space more to its advantage, however.  For example, after a project gets enough community votes, voters could be given the option to post the result to their facebook/twitter accounts in order to spread the word.Additionally, once an idea gets voted to action, a second round asking for volunteers to sign-up could be initiated.  The project will only take place if a critical number of community members agree to help (similar to Kickstarter billing you only after the minimum funding level is pledged by the community).  Once the milestone is reached, all members could be notified via the website.  This would avoid the problem of 2 people showing up for a task intended for 20 and ensure that the project really is a community effort.

Great builds Jonathan,I definitely think Twitter and Facebook should be leveraged within the process. Anything that helps spread the news quickly is valuable.My thinking was that local government or sponsorship money could be used but I suppose there's also no reason to stop local making individual donations if they really feel compelled to back a project. Community kickstarter? See the result of your vote happen on your doorstep!

The kickstarter analogy was not intended to be a financial one - more of a critical mass one.   The idea was to ensure that there are enough volunteers for the community project.  People may be reluctant to sign up on the build day if they are concerned it would be just them.  For example, the website could require that 10 people need to volunteer on the specific day otherwise the event is cancelled.  Once a minimum of 10 people have pledged their time (whereas for Kickstarter people pledge their $$) then an official announcement could go out telling everyone it's on.  If only 9 people signed up for an activity requiring 10, then the event would be postponed until the minimum # of community members volunteer.  This way people don't have to fear being the only person out there and more people would be willing to volunteer their time for the event, bringing the community closer together.
OK cool, yes I like it. And of course the time and number of people add much of the value in their own right. Ensuring a turn out is a big deal. Thanks

let_the_people_build.title: Let The People Build

comments.text: Could you explain further? Because it sounds to me like a sort of slave labour, or paying other people (cheapest possible labor force) to pay for what you should take care of yourself. ? I don't know, but would like to learn more
The Corithian government payed the poor to work. Therefore bringing the poor out of poverty and repairing the city itself.

Hmm, it sounds like the same principle that is used for the homeless papers like The Big Issue: giving those in need a meaningful way to earn a living, lifting their income and sense of achievement at the same time; with the aim of bringing them (back) into the middle class. Let's see if we can get this bus rollin' :)

comments.text: I just got this urge to add an idea for you, use it if you like it, or forget about it, if you think it is a stupid idea.What about pairing together one of the richest and one of the poorest (perhaps one homeless) in the city, perhaps lessons could go both ways, I mean in daily life, street-smartness, work ethics and so on perhaps it could be valuable to document as a film or TV series... compare with british TV series : "Undercover Boss" "Secret Millionaire" (there exists clips and parts of episodes on youtube, if you wish to see samples)
or pair together one official servant from city council with a street vendor/street-food-hawker, and walk around the city areas and discuss planning and maintenance needs and so on

I like that one better.  The first one I wouldn't add it, because homeless makes it more complex, due to its not seldom relation with consumption of drugs or alcohol.  Pairing together someone from the city council with street vendors would be great, so both understand their positions and then both legislation and informal economy could find paths together!Thank you Johan!

(thats a bit of a prejudice? no? I guess it could depend on what country you live in, but there are lots of homeless persons that got no problem with alcohol or drugs, and only lost their home and money because of natural disasters or divorce or other traumatic incidents, such could lead to drug abuse, but not for everybody that becomes homeless)

I agree,it is a bit a prejudice.  But as you said, there is a trauma behind it, and maybe every case is different.  With the idea I try to group a whole community that has access to media, are gathered and whose difficulties could be acknowledged with a different effort.

adopt_a_millionaire.title: Adopt a Millionaire

comments.text: Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Inspiration!
Do I win a job at IDEO!   yes please.  :
Creative, hard-charger, whose energy will power your building.  (very sustainable)  Have a great weekend.

Way to go, Denny! Perhaps you might add a link directly to your post in case folks want to easily check out more? Tip: to activate links in your post, hit the Update Entry button up there on the right, then follow the instructions here: http://bit.ly/oi_link

I adore this inspiration and signed up to try it out.  I think neighbor-based organizing will be very powerful. I wonder if someone will combine this sort of platform with something like foursquare (a location based app for mobile phones) to make it easier to connect and collaborate with neighbors. Thanks!

Sounds interesting, especially if you can combine it with a 'brick-and-mortar/real-life' approach. It's good to be connected online, but also to stop on the street, talk to that nice neighbour and introduce yourself to get to know his or her name. I think a social network like this can really add to that.

Agreed. Thanks for posting, Denny! I love the concept and I'm really curious to see how it scales in low-income vs affluent communities too. There's a high level of crime in my neighborhood, for instance, but not all of my neighbors have internet or even a computer. Interestingly, I feel a stronger sense of street-community than any other neighborhood I've lived in. It's a cool challenge to design and test this system with a bunch of different test demos!
Would be great as an addition to an existing social network. Does anyone really want to have an extra one to check?

I logged on the first time today.  Heard about crime in my hood, a neighbor selling a couch, and meet some people that I don't care to have on my Facebook.  At some point breaking away from one site that owns all of your data whose goals is to monetize it does not seem like a bad idea.  Also, I think they have different touch points for a reason.

Suzie, one of the important parts of the inspiration phase is that all ideas are good ideas.   The co-creative process works much better when all ideas are considered valid.  If we negate ideas during the inspiration phase we could miss out on some interesting options because the thread of ideation stops.   While an add to an existing idea maybe a great idea to put forth in the Concepting phase.  2 cents.
Hi Denny, apologies! I think it its a great idea! Was just saying here could be more to it.
No need to apologize, just trying to sound brainy.  Design course from Wharton starts tomorrow.   https://www.coursera.org/course/design   its free.

become_a_urban_wildlife_watcher.description: Raising city dweller’s interest and excitement about local nature by providing them an online platform where they can report and share the wildlife observations made in their cities.Could this lead to a better commitment towards environmental issues?
become_a_urban_wildlife_watcher.creator: 1b2a0be717b5628e8415c497792fe28f

comments.text: i'll be an urban widelife watcher
Very good idea

Great idea! I think it could give rise to real passions about wildlife. And it's easy accessible, right in your neighbourhood!Another positif thing I like: The transmission of knowledge and sense of observation between generations.
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!

Bon Jour, Florie! How about adding another perspective to your lovely idea of "discoveries"  : http://www.openideo.com/open/vibrant-cities/concepting/sidewalk-science/Owners of telescopes could volunteer at certain evenings and weekends to meet in a place and watch the sky, the moonOwners of birdwatching-binoculars could do similar, and owners of laboratory microscopes for watching very small collected details of moss, leaves, larvae?or even dig up a little piece of asphalt and turn it downside up and analyse what is living under it.Go Science!

If you combine efforts in same day, owners of telescopes could borrow a microscope for a while. and vice versa. to let these educate eachothers, about the smallest perspective vs the largest perspective of science, nature, space.

Great suggestion Johan. I like the idea of organizing gatherings along the online platform where people can share knowledge. I think it could be a great way to get people motivated and create a sense of community.

thanks. If you offer random citizens a chance of watching through a telescope or microscope, to see themselves and their home region in a new perspective and in a different scale, you could end up inspiring to them coming with new innovations, or new environmental services or amazing things. I can imagine there could be lots of spin-offs, like small informal or formalized discussion groups that invent and redesign and influence politicians :)

Great stuff, Florie! And I'm especially loving the scenario you've added to help folks grasp your idea. As a keen fan of local flora and fauna  I'm digging this in many ways. I'd expect the biggest challenge would be getting folks to join and participate. I wonder whether things like weekly competitions might help stimulate involvement? eg. fall leaves, nesting birds, etc. Platforms like Instagram seem to do very well out of this kind of thing  without even having to offer prizes. Another way to get potential users excited could be through featuring photos + actions from a local celebrity on the platform. Offline outreach to schools might be a good way to get youth engaged? Keen to hear from others here about ways to attract participation  especially some of our collaborators on the ground in Singapore.

I agree Meena: there are very different natures of motivations and therefore several levers on which one can act to get people participating in this project:-       the most classical one  reward through money  may not be the main one since people who tend to be interested in the environment are not primarily driven by money-        this does not mean that we cannot use the prize option to reward the good contributions. But these prizes could take other forms as money, e.g.: win a visit of a bird center or of a natural reserve somewhere-       sense of fulfilment: do everything to enhance the feeling of proudness people have with the contributions they make; e.g.: highlight in the home page the best photograph of the week or the best action or the best scientific contribution-       social motivation: meet interesting people like scientists one can ask questions to or other people in the city we live in who share the same interests or even other contributors in foreign citiesthus the internet site could become a real nice communityI hope this helps

Thanks a lot for your suggestions Meena and Pierre: it makes me think further . I think youre totally right about the biggest challenge of such a concept: get people joining and participating  (especially the ones that are not already fans of local wildlife).I think another good element to add to the mix of prizes and social recognition could be the scientific or environmental motivations: highlight the importance of each users action for helping science and/or the environment.

become_a_urban_wildlife_watcher.title: Become an Urban Wildlife Watcher

Microvolunteering surely does have the potential to change communities at large. The initiative I run called Help From Home, http://helpfromhome.org/ is aspiring to do this. If anybody wants to help us to achieve this, then please contact me via the 'Contact Us' page on our website.

tedactive_lunches_force_social_interacti.description: TEDActive conference organizers encouraged a large group of strangers to interact by handing out picnic baskets with 5 full lunches in them.  What type of urban elements could similarly inspire social interaction in our cities?
tedactive_lunches_force_social_interacti.creator: f92cd9612ad5db7f2072da94282c3214

comments.text: Really interesting inspiration, Jay! I'd love to use elements of it to build upon the concept I posted on Neighborhood Dining Halls: http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/concepting/neighborhood-dining-halls/   It's now in the refinement phase.It would be great to get your input on how to refine Neighborhood Dining Halls!

Great inspiration. It always amazes me how people can open up when they're out of their comfort zone. It's always easy to hide in a group your familiar with, but you miss out on some fantastic conversations.
Thanks for your comment Arjan.  Any ideas how we can bring this into an urban environment?

Jay, thanks for the awesome post.  You've inspired me.  When I travel alone for business I usually "keep to myself".  Today I took off my headphones and personally interacted with people nearby.  I forgot how wonderful it is to talk to peeps from new places.  Many thanks for the inspiration to be human again!

Wow - thanks for your comment Hao.  I'm glad to have made such a direct impact with this inspiration.  I think your action today shows how important it might be to design something to encourage this type of behaviour in public spaces.

Jay, I'm really appreciating the way you're thinking about this and the questions you're asking...I feel like identifying areas where strangers gather but rarely speak would be awesome places to deploy such an experiment: bus stops, train platforms, at the DMV, outside libraries, at the gas station even! Let's do it!

Thank Jenine.  I totally agree, those are some great places where this could happen.  I love the TEDActive example because it doesn't use any kind of digital device or mobile app... it's a simple analog way to bring people together through design.I'm thinking of how to frame this into a concept for the next phase in 2 weeks... let's keep brainstorming !
Great inspiration Jay! I love restaurants that have a communal tables that in a way encourage people to sit together rather than alone.

Thanks annie - yeah that's exactly the idea.  I love stuff like that too, that's why the TEDactive lunches stuck with me... an inspired idea.  Also: we met this year at DIS right?  Nice to e-see you! :)

Provocative thoughts, Jay! Looking forward to what they might inspire on our upcoming Concepting phase. And you also inspired me to check out Sherry's TED talk  if others want to have a look: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MtLVCpZIiNs
Yes!  It's quite a moving talk, thanks for including the link.  :)

singfarm.creator: fc0f76e102a8dedc09ced82bde274b5f

comments.text: I loved playing SimFarm as a kid, and I think the aspect your concept points out very well by connecting it to a game is that crops are something that ripen at a specific time. One would want to trade it or sell it while it is still fresh, and the game would be a great way to notify people that your tomatoes are ready to be harvested in 1 day. It would be great to encourage people to also cook with these fresh and local ingredients and maybe the game SingFarm could suggest where one could get all the local ingredients to make a certain dish. Thinking forward one might also consider about how a communal kitchen / garden could be included in new HDB developments.
Fab idea, Maria & great builds, Shelagh!

singfarm.title: SingFarm

starting_young.description: Children of today's Singapore spend a lot of time either studying or playing computer games. Parents prioritise studies above all. How about introducing a new subject in the national school curriculum?
starting_young.creator: fc0f76e102a8dedc09ced82bde274b5f

comments.text: Really love this concept Maria!!! Especially the connection between school and action component. I think it is a great insight about the value people in Singapore have about education and how the school can be at the center. I wonder if you have thought about what kind of activities would these "classes" cover?

Thank you, Nabil! I think it could be very simple activities, as long as they mean collaboration and communication. Simple home economics style classes where you learn the basics of cooking (together), basics about fixing things at home, how to use simple tools, building basic things, growing things etc.

Hi Maria. I happy that I could some how inspire you. Maybe you could add something about the pedagogic approach for these classes?Sometimes it is quite hard to engange younsters in something that is it in shock with their social pressures (being a good student, learn hard a lot and hard...)

Smashing idea Maria. It could be something that starts in schools but has perhaps an independent streak? That way kids can start to do things for the sake of it rather than to get ahead or for a reward. It's a bit disruptive but what change isn't?
I would be careful to add ANOTHER subject to the already very crowded national curriculum in schools. We should made this an optional area that children can participate in.

I completely agree, Jackson. I was actually thinking that some of the academic classes would be removed or cut down... I know this would be controversial with parents (to start with) but if the government feels it's important enough for the community I think it would be good if it was in the national curriculum, as (correct me if I'm wrong) not many parents would choose these classes over academic ones if they were optional.

starting_young.title: Starting young

pie_labthink_lab.description: Pie lab is a community out reach and classroom in Greensboro Alabama, where people can go to learn, talk about issues, and eat pie of course.
pie_labthink_lab.creator: 4ef60cfd9b07bf296125059302f337d1

comments.text: I like the idea of first having a place to talk - and eating something together is so simple but powerful to develop communities of belonging.

collective_roots_.description: Collective Roots seeks to educate and engage youth and communities in food system change through sustainable programs that impact health, education, and the environment. It brings people in communities together.
collective_roots_.creator: 4f8b3ea88d13faf1a2fe3d5dc729c8e3

comments.text: The idea of teaching kids in the community is great. Sometimes, when  you teach kids, they teach their parents. Plus, if you do kids activities, you can have the parents participate with them or do extra activities for the parents and create a community of people learning new things.

This is such a great idea! I wish someone would have taught me some basic gardening skill when I was a kid, I'd be using them right now! Another awesome side of this is the empowering feelings the kids must feel for getting to eat and enjoy the food they've helped to grow; what a great way to build their confidence.
Nice one, Svava! Loving the inspiration to tie up with schools  certainly a great way to engage communities in local action.

install_public_art_to_create_community_s.description: Install public murals and other public art to create a sense of place and add beauty to urban spaces, which leads to more interest in and conservation of the environment as a whole, including the natural environment.
install_public_art_to_create_community_s.creator: 1a4cf499f7bed372be887cb77b09991c

comments.text: I walked by the electric blue Konstantin Dimopoulos trees in Seattle a week ago. I was up there for a wedding and happened to walk by them. Creating a memorable sense of place connects individuals to their communities in a powerful way. As another example, traveling to Europe gives one a strong sense of connection to the past and to tradition. I am sure you have heard of the "Broken Window" theory? Behavior follows context...
Thanks Kirk, I agree. Sweden also has some great subway murals I'll have to share that are designed to accentuate the natural rock walls in the subway.

Hi Beth, interesting post! Any chance you could find an image to go along with it? Images help grab attention and tell a story with higher impact. You should be able to use the 'Update entry' button on the right of your post and follow the instructions to add images from there. We know occasionally people have issues uploading images so let us know by hitting the Support tab on the left hand side of most pages of our site if you face any problems. Looking forward to seeing more of your inspiring ideas on OpenIDEO.

I should also add that public art is also a symbol of trust in the community from government, since by placing it there local government trusts that people will respect it; it is important for community residents to feel respected and heard by their government, and will feel more compelled to participate in the community and environment if they feel they are being heard by their elected officials.

install_public_art_to_create_community_s.title: Install public art to create community, sense of place

the_pop_up_museums_of_singapore_s_commun.description: Small vacant spaces all around Singapore will temporarily serve as galleries of community building ‘art’ by the pop-up museums of Singapore’s communities.
the_pop_up_museums_of_singapore_s_commun.creator: 6fed0e6f1ba44f0520bc14fceee3663d

comments.text: Arjan, nice one -- another one of your concepts made it to the NEA Challenge Shortlist. We liked the way your concept provided an easy way to take in art and celebrate community. As we move into Refinement, think about the systems that might surround a Pop-Up museum. Who would get the word out, and how would it be distributed? How might the space be secured? Who would keep the momentum going? For more tips on how to iterate and prototype your idea during the Refinement phase, read here http://bit.ly/connect-refinetips and check this Lowdown: http://bit.ly/oi_refine

Tapping into active community members to help spread the word within their community is a cost-efficient means of spreading the cause and keeping it alive past 1 single event.  What incentive can be given to these early adopters encouraging them to bring their friends to events and help spread the word? Not living in Singapore, I struggle with this answer, but perhaps some form of "social cash" (recognition) at the events. In addition, if the events are taking place in areas where community members pass on a regular basis, would it be possible to leave something from the pop up events?  This way these events would literally leave a small mark on the community that continuously invites curious passer-bys to stop and maybe seek out more information.  If space is at a premium and smart phones are prominent in the area, this could literally be a bar code w/ a curious sign where a video or pic from the event is brought up when the bar code is scanned.  This will allow for a continuing stream so the community is creating a story thread through these events.

Arjan, Johan, Maria, Katrina & Meena - we're so sorry that we may have lost some of the updates to this concept over the last 72 hours - we lost the AWS server stack which included the backup and even after working through the night some updates escaped us.  We've extended the Refinement Phase to the 27th to give everyone extra time to re-upload their content and to push your concept even further - apologies again if you did lose any updates...

Great idea! Made me think of a few parallels with 'Renew Adelaide': http://www.renewadelaide.com.au I have experienced quite a few of their pop-up spaces (broader than just museums or exhibition spaces). I feel there could be some learnings from this existing business model.A short description from their website:'Renew Adelaide is a non-profit urban renewal project that works to revitalise under used and empty buildings and shop fronts with projects of benefit to the community. Our goal is to provide incubation space for young and emerging entrepreneurs, encourage foot traffic in urban areas and help create vibrant cities  both socially and economically.

Museum-on-a-stick could perhaps become developed into a "Museum-on-a-disc" (i.e DVD that works on regular TV sets with DVD player)At the evening of one pop-up-event, have a small library, which the residents in the building could borrow a DVD or two from, if they wish to bring it home to show it to their elderly parents or at the workplace.And when the pop-up-museum returns to their building after a couple of months, they could exchange this DVD for a new DVD with new content on it. recycling and sharingDVD's could perhaps be made to circulate between apartments in one building, deliver one with post to the top floor, with written instructions on the box : when all neighbours on that floor have watched it, one of them walk down one floor and hands it over to another, relay race(just my ideas on how to virally spread the rumour and initiate more interest by using "Offline", lowtech and IRL distribution from face to face)

Great stuff, Arjan! With Singapore's pressure on real estate, might be good to think about where the opportunities lie for communities to set these up? Could it be a centralised venture like: http://www.openideo.com/open/what-is-the-global-challenge-that-most-concerns-you-right-now-and-that-global-innovation-leaders-could-begin-to-solve/inspiration/micro-retail-start-ups-uk/ or something else? How might we lower the barriers for communities of finding cost-effective spaces to create pop-up museums in? Looking forward to thoughts from others  especially those on the ground in Singapore.

Thanks, Meena. I realise the pressure on real estate in Singapore is huge, but I think there's always some space that is temporarily vacant. Inititially I was thinking of places with a public function. Shops that have stopped, for example, and are empty waiting for a new shop to start.But I also intended this concept to be versatile. Your kiosks are awesome, I think something like that should definitely be added to the mix. And maybe something like the little free libraries (I thought there had been an inspiration about that, I couldn't find it, so: http://www.littlefreelibrary.org/). I would definitely like to hear more from people on the ground in Singapore to find out what works best there, but I like to have many different options in this concept.
Gotcha Arjan  so folks might like to think about what could incentivise real estate agents for vacant spaces to offer up their lots... excited to hear what y'all come up with!

Where I grew up, you would see outlets pop-up in temporarily vacant spaces. They would have lower/no rent to keep the space occupied and busy. I think it has to do with the fact that an empty storefront is not good for a shopping street/mall, and in some cases it could attract vandalism or at least carelessness. If that is something owners are faced with, allowing a pop-up museum in would be beneficial to them. But I like to hear the local insights.

There is an interesting concept in Singapore called the void deck. Basically, the ground floor of all HDB blocks (houses where majority Singaporeans live) are empty spaces that can be rented for weddings and funerals and where people can hang out outdoors but sheltered from sun and rain. I think these are super interesting because they are basically empty spaces and most of the time under utilised. They could not permanently be taken up (as they need to be available for weddings and funerals) but they seem made for temporary exhibitions!

Awesome! That's why we need local voices, I did not know about these void decks, but they seem perfect for this concept. I can see some small exhibitions travel from void deck to void deck, finding periods of some days, maybe even weeks, when there's no other event scheduled.
Such an excellent local insight, Maria  and great build, Arjan!

To accompany the pop-up displays, audio descriptions of the exhibits could be made available via podcasts or youtube. Similar to a traditional museum exhibit but more accessible and customizable, ie you can listen to just one exhibit and skip around, etc.

Brilliantly spotted, and what a lovely description of cool add-on-feature, that would connect seamlessly together with my concept proposal : Mp3-tours : http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/concepting/mp3-tourism/

Katrina, indeed a great idea. It could be a wonderful addition. Especially because the pop-up museums are great ways to collect stories to tell. I think Johan's concept could indeed be a good way of doing this, and they combine perfectly.

to have screenings on a white wall outside in a public place could tie together with some of my concepts, like Lazer graffiti or "Movies in the park" or LocalTV? just a portable projector and a computerand make a schedule to have screenings each weeknight in a new location, rotate frequently to cover all city districts
and of course the photos from the photo marathon could be displayed in such a temporary "pop-up-museum"
True! The photo marathon concept is already linked by you. I will try to add the LocalTV one .

wow, the museum on a usb-stick sounds amazing! Perhaps you could tie it together with some form of "underground-guerilla-type-association" : http://www.guerrilla-innovation.com/archives/2010/11/000770.php

the_pop_up_museums_of_singapore_s_commun.title: The pop-up museums of Singapore's communities

py/tuple: How easy would it be for citizens to get involved and take initiative for this idea?
Very easy; this would rely on ground-up participation from the beginning.
Somewhat easy; there are ways for citizens to get involved, but an outside organiser may be needed to sustain and grow this concept.
This concept needs to be led and maintained by the government or private business.
Can you build this concept on top of something that already exists, like an organisation, physical space, or system?
Yes. This could fold into, or extend from, something that already exists.
This concept taps existing networks for a few things, but also needs a lot of new processes, materials, relationships, etc.
This concept requires a new system to be built to support it.
After the initial launch and support, could this concept be sustained and cared for over time by the community it's designed to serve?
Absolutely! This concept is easy to keep going.
It depends. There are opportunities for growth, but it's not yet clear how the concept would thrive after launch.
Probably not. A lot of effort would be needed to keep this concept going.
Does this concept create community?
Yes. It naturally brings people together and inspires them to take care of one another.
There is potential to create a thriving community.
No. It doesn't galvanize people to come together for a common cause or interest.
Overall, how do you feel about this concept?
It rocked my world.
I liked it but preferred others.
It didn't get me overly excited.

connectmydistrict.description: #connectmydistrict is a live-streaming, local bulletin board that connects people who live in close proximity to one another. The concept uses coded Twitter hash tags to connect communities geographically, on a highly granular level.
connectmydistrict.creator: c21692874e7108cf3046ba29b139499d

comments.text: Simple yet powerful. To add on to the idea: there could also be regular meetups or rather 'tweetups' organised and facilitated by the district codes. Recently I participated in an offline version of this idea in Australia called 'Neighbour Day': http://www.neighbourday.org Hopefully there'll be some inspiration there!

This is a case where social media can truly catalyze and inspire change in a meaningful way, by helping neighbors find and learn about each other. I like the Tweetups; I'll add this. I was concerned about the adoption among elderly folks. However, the literature suggests that senior citizens are catching on quite well!

Hey Kirk, wonderfully simple indeed!Perhaps there is room for another layer of categorisation in each distritct.. here is an example from Joana of the theme 'help' (#help...) http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/concepting/interactive-map-plug-in-for-social-networks/Just add in categories in front of each district name/code to break down the tweets... like #rent, #service, #eco, #event, etc.. helping people futher filter what it is they are searching for.

This is a good thought. As long as the categories enable highly specific geographic groupings, the sky is the limit in terms of hash tagging. It is a flexible system with wide applicability.. Folks could put the respective geographic codes into their headlines without giving away their addresses. There is a valid concern regarding privacy and phone location tracking, which is circumvented here. Imagine how quickly you could get visitors to your yard sale...
Thank you James! I think we have a great idea here.. If we could put both together it could be powerful.. I need to join you both to my team!
#simplyawesome

thanks Meena! I wasn't sure if I should post the idea, but decided to anyway. :) We have already seen Twitter's  power in Arab Spring. The organization of highly precise geographic codes into an online platform could connect neighbors in a way that encourages active participation. At the very least, folks would be more aware of events taking place around their homes, and it would be easy for local initiatives to spread the word in a highly focused manner. This idea could and should combine with some of the other great concepts...

connectmydistrict.title: #connectmydistrict

creating_new_uses_for_forgotten_public_s.description: As the world evolves we are often left with legacy public infrastructure that is no longer useful to the community in the way it were original designed - e.g. public phone booths. How might we repurpose such spaces to better benefit the community?
creating_new_uses_for_forgotten_public_s.creator: 90d49506eaf4f6f4a811471ed35eb1d2

comments.text: Very interesting!
I love this inspiration! I'm a sucker for repurposing, especially in ways that benefit knowledge and community.
Great inspiration! I've seen old magazine/newspaper vending machines repurposed for books as well, but really like how phone booths can be converted into usable stations for the public.
Fab provocation, Philip  and we're loving having folks like you joining the challenge from on the ground in Singapore!

I also enjoyed reading further details on the NYT post: http://www.nytimes.com/2012/09/09/nyregion/ny-designer-puts-lending-libraries-into-pay-phone-kiosks.html?_r=0 Perhaps you might add that link directly to your post in case folks want to easily check out more? Tip: to activate links in your post, hit the Update Entry button up there on the right, then follow the instructions here: http://bit.ly/oi_link
Oh, that's a brilliant idea for old phone booths: a public library.Great idea to bring repurposing into this challenge this way.

creating_new_uses_for_forgotten_public_s.title: Creating new uses for forgotten public spaces

openideo_kick.creator: d910aa696a1fbe9d89fa0f5005c8650b

comments.text: Nice concept Amy. I am thinking out loud: how about getting private organisations to fund/donate to activities as part of their CSR? As such, you can probably approach private organisations before their budgeting cycle and having them place "OpenIDEO + Kick Starter" donations as part of their CSR plans.By rallying for causes as a brand name together with any other indivduals through "OpenIDEO + Kick Starter", these private organisations get a stronger engagement with consumers too. Win-win for both parties?

Hey Amy!I've added a similar one for funding community projects with ways of getting the Brands/Corporates involved. Here: http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/concepting/web-platform-for-community-projects-volunteer-and-fund-/Let's teamup and brainstorm better?

Hi Diana, thanks for your thoughts! Your points will definitely help with scaling the project so that it reaches out to more people and communities. Great concept, Kris! I appreciate you bringing this to my attention, we have a lot of overlapping elements! I would love to team up to brainstorm ways to bring together our ideas or see what other spinoffs/new additions we can think of.I've added both of you to my virtual team:)

i_like_books_and_beer_you_like_books_and.description:
I was reading about this cool gathering called BOOKS & BEER. 
Its a book swap event, where people who like books and/or beer can meet.
Who doesn't like books or beer... at least one of them or both!?
http://actuallymag.com/books-beer-3/
i_like_books_and_beer_you_like_books_and.creator: be3edc29417eb702652e6c6daa53d39d

comments.text: Can't agree more that engaging in the activities you enjoy with people who share the same interests is a great way to break the ice. I have a similar concept which I'll share in the concepting phase, on how sharing tasks encourages more interactions. We could build on that together!

I love it! That makes me wonder though: "How might we make it dramatically simpler for fun community events to spring up?"Meetup.com seems to be doing a surprisingly good job at this now: http://www.meetup.com
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Inspiration!

Nice one, Leon. I especially like this as it highlights how folks can connect over supposedly divergent interests. It's been noted elsewhere that the major pastimes for Singaporeans are shopping, food and internet surfing: http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/inspiration/eat-shop-surf-top-3-pastimes-for-singaporeans/ Your post points to the notion that these might act as stepping stones to engage people over a wider group of pastimes. Looking forward to what this might inspire in the upcoming Concepting phase!

Meena, thanks for the connection, I would love connecting with new folks over books and beer.  I was recently in Washington DC and saw an ad for a "beer and board games" bar....AWESOME idea....I will be in DC over the holidays and already have plans with friends to visit Board Room DC http://www.washingtoncitypaper.com/blogs/youngandhungry/2012/09/24/board-game-themed-bar-opens-in-dupont-tomorrow/

Leon, awesome post!  I've seen (in the USA) using beer and board games to connect people...books and beer would work for me!  http://www.washingtoncitypaper.com/blogs/youngandhungry/2012/09/24/board-game-themed-bar-opens-in-dupont-tomorrow/

creating_a_local_mythology.description: The mysterious Toynbee tiles and the Shepard Fairey's Obey Giant are images found embedded in urban streetscapes worldwide that provoke interest and engagement in the built environment.
creating_a_local_mythology.creator: cb42c8b86e894acb94aca255e7aba464

comments.text: Lovely! I am like you, I am always looking around for these types of stickers, installations. And have had thoughts along the lines of a scavenger hunt, or workshops to influence people designing their local and regional "brands". But how would it be considered by the law in Singapore? I have heard that it is strict when it comes to littering and such And how to connect with making environment better? Perhaps making people do something environmentally friendly, do you wish to collaborate on concepts along these lines, in the next segment of this Challenge? I am all for it! :)
Great provocation, Ashlie  and builds from you, Johan. Looking forward to what these might spark for the upcoming Concepting phase!

Thanks for your comments Johan and Meena!  Really good questions, especially about the laws.  I have heard that Singapore has really strict laws about littering, but hadn't thought about it until now. On that note, I think it's important for city government to provide opportunities for residents to customize their environment in a positive way.  I used street art as an example, but the same idea applies to community gardens, or citywide mural arts programs.  I think when people are allowed to have complete control over even a small element of their surroundings they begin to develop a personal connection and sense of ownership over the space.  That sense of ownership makes people want to maintain their environment, because now it's "their" space.  Ideally, the community works improve their city because of a sense of civic pride rather than fear of harsh punishment.  I'd be super excited to collaborate in the next segment to develop some ideas together!

creating_a_local_mythology.title: Creating a Local Mythology

Looking forward to what these posts will inspire from others & conversations they might spark.

neighbour_day_a_day_to_celebrate_and_get.description: Histories differ, but I think neighbourday originated in 1999 in the 17th arronidssement of Paris, France, aiming to bring neighbours closer together, and in some cases: introduce them to eachother.

comments.text: Simple and great! I really think this gets at one of the fundamental challenges of any size community. I know that the incentives would vary greatly neighborhood by neighborhood here in Oakland, CA, but it would be super interesting to see what kinds of food/music/etc would inspire neighbors to participate.

I think the power of this event is that the assignment is simple: organise something to meet your neighbours. In The Netherlands, the sponsors offer small subsidies for street parties, and it's advertised on TV etcetera quite often, showing all the different possibilities. It would be great to have Neighbour Day tours, to get a taste of what's going on in other neighbourhoods.
Great insights on centralised support, Arjan.
