Promote competitions and prizes for the towns, developments, blocks and individuals that contribute most.
singapore_smart_grid_games_sg_squared.creator: 7e7dcb823cb8bac78bee007e8041492e

comments.text: I am at present cooperating with Three Coins a start-up from Vienna that has very innovative ways of filling the gaps between "knowledge" and behavior in terms of personal finance management. In order to diminish the debt that in which 20% of youth seems to be (according to national stats in Europe), Three Coins uses interactive and creating education and technical assistance through virtual games. Playing such games is supposed to encourage an attitude change towards spending http://threecoins.org/about-us/ Maybe we can see how to integrate the "interactive virtual game" aspect into the Smart grid Games :)

Thanks Gaia, that sounds amazing! I am lucky enough to be sitting down with some fellow OpenIDEO-ers this weekend at a 'Make-a-thon' here in Singapore, where we are trying to move forward with some  prototyping for a variation of this concept. Keep an eye on the feed for some crowd-sourced collaboration, would be great to bring the virtual team online in real-time!

By the way It starts on Friday at 1330 Singapore time (GMT + 8 ... I think!) Sure OpenIDEO will be tweeting about it loads, and i'll hope to find a way for the team that is assmebled in person to be able to interact with any members of the virtual team who are still keen to be a part of it all and help push the idea along :)

Hey virtual team, I just stumbled across a great example of how this kind of idea is being implemented in europe. The basic technology and apps seem to be there already, but I still think that nobody has yet found a way to engage people over the long term in a playful way that encourages growth of the idea. Big opportunity waiting to be grabbed!Anyway here is the link with a couple of great 2 minute videos, enjoy!http://www.experientia.com/blog/telling-stories-experientia-designs-domestic-energy-consumption-monitors-videos/
Beautiful, this has such a potential for scalability and applicability in a variety of different contexts :) congratulations!!!!!
Congratulations James, I see even two concepts. Busy 2013!

Thanks Paul! Busy in a good way hopefully. With this one I feel there that it's mostly about connecting the dots and getting some high level support - not necessarily funding but audiences - if the right technology owners and business interests can be gathered around a table, i see no reason why it can't happen!
Congratulations James! Well deserved :-)
Thanks very much indeed! Keep the comments coming, this one I really want to try and realize, and will welcome any thoughts and support :)

As comments were lost, a repost; Great diagram, great you put in 'scale'. Are the HBD developments already equiped with meters to be read through the internet? Is the law saying in 202X a certain amount of houses need to have smart meters? I think you have a great case for a social enterprise here. Combining vouchers for discount with incentive to save. If vouchers can only be spend for discount in neighborhood store, everybody wins.

Hi Paul, thanks very much for re-posting. At the moment I am not sure very many (if any) HDBs are currently equipped with Smart Meters. This is perhaps the ideal opening for any Sponors out there (philips, siemens, IBM) to speak up!  In the short term, perhaps a more cost-effective methodology is to  talk to a company like Opower, who have the technology (and software) for these type of data collections, engage them with HDB, NEA and some game designers, and get the mobile platform up and running first.

BTW; Philips is experimenting with saving energy with lightning in buildings and different models of ownership when lights need to be replaced. Maybe they would in this 'light' be interested in blocks of flats.

Haha! Thanks. Had better start some conversations with some people and actually get this thing off the ground! Luckily through the day job I have had the pleasure of being given a tour of the Philips showroom and offices here, so will be able to dig up some business cards somewhere with any luck. Cheers!
Congratulations James! Well desrbv

James & Team - as per the comment on your other entry we're so sorry that we may have lost some of the updates to this concept over the last 72 hours - we lost the AWS server stack which included the backup and even after working through the night some updates escaped us.  We have put in place some measures to ensure that this won't happen again.We've extended the Refinement Phase to the 27th to give everyone extra time to re-upload their content and to push your concept even further - apologies again if you did lose any updates...

Great concept James! Another aspect you might not be aware of is that Singapore is doing a lot with water conservation.Connections with WaterHub might be a way to get the data necessary, engage local companies working on Smart Water and meet an existing  resource priority (water self-sufficiency by 2061). Check them out at: http://www.pub.gov.sg/waterhub/Pages/default.aspx

James--here are some thoughts I had that seem to have been lost with the server issue. I'm sure you are aware of IBM's smart cities initiative. Here is the smart water component: http://www.ibm.com/smarterplanet/us/en/water_management/ideas/index.htmlYou had posted a response with an example of using a sink full of warm water for dishes in the US compared to letting the water run down the drain in Singapore. I think this is a perfect example of how storytelling can be used to implement best practices that solve both energy and water waste.Finally, I was thinking it might be good to present each saving practice in a variety of metrics, depending on the end user. Some might be more motivated by dollars in energy bill saved  due to using a sink full of water while others might care more about reduced CO2 or how many gallons of water they were saving. A dashboard that provides a variety of comparisons for each best practice--or that could be tailored to each individual--might be more effective.

Great stuff, James! As you build this concept out over upcoming weeks, you might also want to check out this initiative to see if there might be relevant lessons: http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/inspiration/tidy-street-changing-neighbors-behaviors-through-voluntary-monitoring-and-public-infographics/
Thanks Meena, great Inspiration! Love the idea. You wouldn't catch me trying anything with Grafitti here in Singapore though... I'd get locked up, like the last guy who did!
:^)) wasn't so much suggesting you propose that part  just thought you'd find it interesting.

And indeed it is very interesting! Will give you the benefit of the doubt on trying to get me put behind bars for the time being. There were some other references on that thread regarding schemes in Paris and Berlin that have gamified energy-saving and recycling on a street/block scale... it would be great to find out more about them if you know where else I can look? Tks again :)

You would not really need to paint the actual graffiti on the walls permanently, you could do it high-tech, temporary art installations with projectors: http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/concepting/portable-projector/

Hey James, this is a fabulous idea! I was wondering how it might begin to incorporate other areas that people can focus on as well such as community connection through people helping others, perhaps community rating of cleanliness and social connections (perhaps through talking about what else is happening in the community). Suppose I'm wondering if it can be used as a tool to engage people to work together to achieve something as a community as a first stage and then allow it to scale to be something that goes beyond energy and environment to connection. Just a thought.

Hi David, thanks. You've really got me thinking. How best to link the notion of individual responsibility and reward with that of the community. It would be really amazing if the waiting list for HDB upgrading could be linked to energy saving, cleanliness and recycling. I feel that something this big could really focus collective attention and engender a sense of everybody being in it together.I think there are loads of other concepts that might be integrated into this as a means of saving energy and bringing communities together. Perhaps individual blocks could be encouraged to host 'Kampung Nights' in the void decks once a month. It could be a voluntary power-off and lights out for a couple of hours, when everybody comes downstairs from their flats and gathers under candle light to hear crazy uncles and aunties telling stories from 60-odd years ago.I like the thoughts you have added on going beyond energy and environment, and think it certainly has the potential. At the moment I still think perhaps the best chance of getting something off the ground for real is to keep it simple, use existing technologies and networks (Opower, Smart Bins), and find sponsors and media who could gain from being involved in promoting results and donating prizes. Will try and get a couple of mock-up app dashboards under way!

James, congratulations on making the NEA Challenge Shortlist! Your concept inspired us to think about how we might visually inspire people to save energy, and as a collective, make a big impact on total usage. In Refinement, we encourage you to think about how you might make the data meaningful to people, by translating the numbers into something tangible and compelling. Could you find a physical equivalent to represent energy saved? We once saw a sticker on a bike that said "54 mpb" (miles per burrito). Perhaps that will spark something!  For more tips on how to iterate and prototype your idea during the Refinement phase, read here http://bit.ly/connect-refinetips and check this Lowdown: http://bit.ly/oi_refine

Hi James, great concept. There was a student project in NL which was quite succesfull on making game mechanics work to motivate. http://www.fastcoexist.com/1679632/energy-battle-students-show-how-games-can-cut-electric-billsAs reading in other comments, it is great to reward with winning something, what I can also imagine is that for example you save 10 dollar on your electricity bill, 5 goes to a street/block bankaccount. Creating 3 incentives to play : To win, save money AND raise fund to improve the street/block.

Thanks so much for the link Paul. I found some other great examples on the same site. It seems that this company 'Opower' has already made progress in creating a means to access, compare, and gamify data. Presumably the same technology and software they use to bring the energy information from the utilities companies onto a live App feed can be replicated here in Singapore.http://www.fastcoexist.com/1678956/plugging-your-utility-bill-into-facebook-to-compete-with-friendsOpower seems to be doing ok, but I read in the article that similar ventures by Microsoft and Google have not been successful. I think the key is really engaging the participants in the gamification; to do this the prizes would really have to hit the right note, and the means of recognition/praise would have to be attractive. Special care on how, when, and through what media the winners are announced will have a huge impact on the cultural flavor of these Smart Games. Singapore would be a great place to launch something like this, with so many dense and earnest, positive communities, always taking pride in their competitive element. Would really love to hear how people think the prizes/recognition should be co-ordinated.

Just contact them to see, maybe happy to help, they did more : http://translate.google.com/translate?hl=en&sl=nl&tl=en&u=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.shifft.com%2Fprojecten%2F6.html  Also "Urban Heroes" more for kids : http://translate.googleusercontent.com/translate_c?depth=1&hl=en&rurl=translate.google.com&sl=nl&tl=en&twu=1&u=http://www.stadsehelden.nl/&usg=ALkJrhh90v5KBqXGJ5m3mu-LXQ0KyHswVwAny ideas indeed on the prizes/incentives/recognition? Would it be a good idea to collect in a (virtual) jar 50% money of what you saved in energy?
+1 for the concept!

James, I really like your concept. It has been my experience that the visualization of information sparks interest and conversations, particularly when the information relates to one's choices. My dad and brother used to have competitions on who could go the longest without using the heater in sub-zero winters. I think my dad won; the rivalry continues. I can easily see how the competitive aspect works! I am probably not the first to suggest that it may also make sense to have this data on an app, with the intent of providing further information regarding tips, fun facts, and competitions.

Agree totally Kirk. The app would help to gamify a competition between say a group of 3-4 units of the same extended family or all the households of a group of school children. Not sure if you've ever played Fantasy Football League (soccer in the UK!), but the idea there is that you can enter your 1 team into as many leagues as you like - from work colleagues to family and freinds etc, and monitor your progress, send group messages, award group prizes etc. Then the bus-stop features would try to help communities feel a sense of teamwork I hope, by publishing aggregated stats.Moving the converation on a little from this, I am now trying to think further on which public/private sector bodies/companies would stand the most to gain from this and how they might be incentivised into helping kick it off? Any thoughts on that would be hugely appreciated!

you need to think a little bit about the security/safety issue that could arise. Because I heard about some initative to put out online maps of suburbs where the electric company overlayed color codes on the individual houses of amount of power consumtion.It seemed like a couple of tech-savvy burglars used it to see which homes the owners had left for winter holiday. If no electrical consumption was showd, they chose that house to break into. It is perhaps totally different in SIngapore where there is apartment buildings and not a suburban area? or, what do you think? obstacle or possible to work around this "bug issue"?

I think that it is the Air condition units inapartments and offices/shops that are singapores largest source of carbon footprint. Perhaps you could tie together a scheme to have AC-service staff, go around all apartments in one whole building and clean filters for free, check that each unit is functioning optimally. (repair if needed, at a low cost)Measure and show power consumption of the whole building the week before the check up, and compare with the week afterwards :) small drops can become a large stream, since the most environmentally friendly kilowatthour is the one that is not used! #Negawatt! :)

Hey Johan.. thanks for keeping all the suggestions coming! You are right in that AC is the biggest power drain. I have to say though it's not so easy to live without it if you are not from these parts originally! But there is definitely room for optimizing its use in an office environment.. I have friends here who have to take a scarf to work to stay warm, while its 32 degrees outside, crazy! In fact this has given me an idea for a small new concept... thanks!

Using of the asphalt crayons in the "Tidy Streets"-project could be put to use, if you have workshops with art students or other volunteers, perhaps people interested in graffiti? stencil making and continously on a rotational schedule do new asphalt crayon info-graphics in each area. They could be visible from the apartment windows, I imagine? with a QR-code, or with a shortened URL with the service "bit.ly" or similar adress chalked out on the pavement!!!I also saw somewhere a brush-manufacturer was walking in busy street and painted with plain water on the asphalt and concrete pavementstones, he did paint haikus and advertising messages for his brushes, so he was a street vendor that sold his brushes at the same time as he did some art (that evaporated within minutes of course)
http://youtu.be/0EI15GW-IbM
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!

brilliant idea-!  this will definitely contribute to community 'bonding' and foster a sense of accountability + responsibility for environmental issues in Singapore. For most people here, being green stops at not littering and not spitting gum- which is a shame! This display of data will generate interest and hence educate more people about the green issue. It also grabs the opportunity to spark debate/conversation and discussion (perhaps because of the graphically interesting way it is presented and its interactive- ness) I love it how this can get more people to feel like their one action does count! So visually it gets more people to think about it and comment + apply yeah?> and that effect n itself could be an 'auto-pilot' idea-development strategy? way to go! Our bus stops could also do with less materialistic/consumer goods advertising - government money could be better spent ! fab idea, keep it coming ! *applause

I really like this idea, and the link from Meena is indeed a great connection.Maybe you can include tips and tricks from the last month's winners, in which they share what they did to improve their energy usage. WIth that, you create a nice library of ways to use energy smarter.

Thanks Arjan. Meena's link was a great inspiration. Agree whole-heartedly on the winners' tips segment. I have started talking with Johan on his Portable Projector concept thread, and your Pop-Up-Museum concept came up.. A proposal tying the three concepts would indeed be a great use of Void Decks - perhaps a short update on the SG Smart Grid Games latest scores could be inserted in between features.

I like combining functionality of concepts. It's great to show interconnected features, without losing the concepts themselves. I think the Smart Grid Games scores could be interesting to show in the museums, but maybe even better in my SgNal concept.As for the pop-up museums: the working of the Smart Grid Games could be a subject, explained with a fully working screen as exhibition object. And, of course, a workshop with some winners to share tips :).

Hello, if you have the time, could you take a look at some of my concept proposals. Because I think that some of them that are "conveyors of information" (visual and audio) could be perfect ways for this concept of yours to connect together with, in order for finding new methods to deliver info about your game to citizens. I mean primarily to avoid purchase of expensive LED-screens and place them on walls everywhere, that burn a lot of electricity 24/7 :)Let me know what you think? And please comment on my concepts if you have additional ideas or details that I still haven't figured out, yet. All your input is appreciated!

Hi Johan,Thanks very much for the links. I think both the portable projector and the lazer graffiti concpets would work perfectly with this concept. The next trick would be to find the optimum surface and timing schedules to maximise the exposure and 'stickiness' of the information. Perhaps each block could have it's daily consumption summarised on the side each night at a regular time.. or for 30-60 seconds on the hour each hour from 8-10pm. This would let observers see from the outside in, but there would have to be another way of letting residents inside their own block know.Regarding the LED screens, you have a point, it would be expensive. Perhaps there is another way, but the objective is to present the data at the beginning and end of the daily commute (where people have time to pause for reflection) in an interactive, live way. Would welcome any more suggestions!

you should take a look at my friend Arjans concept, Pop-Up-Museum, that aim to "borrow" empty spaces in ground floor of apartment buildings: http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/concepting/the-pop-up-museums-of-singapore-s-communities/People living in a house, would see the images, and be so curious that they walk outside to watch. And you could give them a printed piece of paper with web adress so that they can keep track of their results 24/7 online.There is high percentage of smart-phone-users in Singapore!

comments.text: Brilliant. What I love most about this idea is that it reverses the current model. Usually, communities apply for grants/ funding to make changes happen. It's all based on promises and potential. Whereas in your concept, first there's the action and then there's the reward. The focus is thus on taking initiative and actually making things happen!
Gamify this concepts with redeemable reward points, with corporate sponsorships like Starbucks etc?

Loving how this draws on neighbourhood pride while enabling positive developments across the city. And I wonder if there might be some way of conveying which areas are attracting the most GreenFund points to instil a bit of healthy competition while raising awareness about the initiative and celebrating its successes?

Hi Lindsey,Really cool idea to foster ownership withing neighborhoods. Perhaps to build on your idea would be to get the schools involved. Instill a sense of belonging in students from a young age to take action in starting clean up projects to take care of their country. Use their schools to score points for their neighborhoods. It could start a buzz!

Sounds great.. perhaps there is a role for a 'Challenge-Anneka' (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Challenge_Anneka) type guru in appealing to local businesses for contributions. Maybe we can do without the array of jumpsuits now though...
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!

comments.text: I don't live in Singapore but I think it would be great if someone from Singapore could try to chat with hawker centers stall owners, to see what do they think about the whole idea, if they can imagine participating in it, for sure they would have some valuable insights. So if anyone is interested!

Very nice idea!!! I think it could also allow a twist! from the inspiration phase of this projects, there was a lot of ideas of farming and growing local food in Singapore. "The meeting" could be a way to gather the community together to share cooking and food experiences, but why not if the hawker centre has a farm behind where they grow their own food, so the tour will include also this "Organic farm", putting the people more close to the nature and the raw ingredients the local food use. With this organic food concept, the Hawker centres in Singapore will gain a great value!

Klementyna, I'm a true-blue Singaporean and I can't tell you enough (in Singlish perhaps) about how much we love our hawker food - best thing in the world and the only thing I crave for when I'm out of the country!I think a quick and easy way to implement this into a community group is to have an app/community/facebook group for people to post and vote about hawkers they would love to learn more about - Singaporeans also love talking about food! We can even link up with popular food websites/blogs like HungryGoWhere.Perhaps we can reward create community buzz by getting people to vote for Singapore's favourite hawkers or newly established hawkers. The grand prize can be an exclusive food shopping tour across several of the best/most popular hawkers in a day.I think the community can learn a lot (food and non-food) from hawkers who have established a long-running popular stall particularly the younger generation like me, who are interested to know how they did it!

Hi Janice, great thoughts about the hawker topic! I also think it should be community/facebook/app based. I've never been to Singapore but after this challenge I crave for hawker food too:)If this concept has some continuation, there will be a lot of place for more ideas.

Klementyna & Team - we're so sorry that we may have lost some of the updates to this concept over the last 72 hours - we lost the AWS server stack which included the backup and even after working through the night some updates escaped us.  We've extended the Refinement Phase to the 27th to give everyone extra time to re-upload their content and to push your concept even further - apologies again if you did lose any updates...
I tried to update the things I remembered.

Nice work, Klementyna. Your concept made it to the NEA Challenge Shortlist. We loved the way your idea brings together people of different ages in an already-existing place that people visit regularly. As we move into Refinement, consider telling the story of what one of the interactions might look like from start to finish. Also, what would the system look like? Go into more detail about the way people would learn about events in both offline and online places. At the end, how would you allow for reflection and sharing of the experience: Would there be a place for them to thank the stall owners, or tell the story of their time? For more tips on how to iterate and prototype your idea during the Refinement phase, read here http://bit.ly/connect-refinetips and check this Lowdown: http://bit.ly/oi_refine
Great! I just updated the concept with some more specific user experience map. I will post more updates and a scenario of possible interactions soon.
User experience map is just awesome! Love it!
OMG  **amazing** refinement-moves! Not only visually stunning but also very clarifying + engaging.
Thank you guys! If you have some ideas about the concept feel free to post!

Great idea! In Singapore, food brings people together. It'll be great to bring people together to learn all the secret recipes, tips and tricks of great hawkers. I can easily imagine this as a TV show as well, haha.
thanks Angela. TV show sounds good, but I think in this concept the meeting between people is as important as the wisdom sharing.
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Concept!

Great concept. It reminds me of local-producer food and wine events I've attended and the stories I've learned from those producers. You could even add in a step at the front by setting up wet market tours beforehand, to give people a sense of the provenance of the ingredients and the process of getting food to the table.
Great idea, some of the meetings could be all about wet market tour and knowing the ingredients (how to choose the right ones etc.) and just end with a dinner.

Love this idea. It makes me want to go to a Singaporean hawker center right now, and talk to some of the stall owners.The logo is amazing, by the way.Would it be an idea to also do this more improv-style? Why not just start by convincing one guy to share stories and surprise the crowd. Maybe putting some flyers or info on the tables, with a hash tag and website, so that they can easily share if they like it. It would be great to have a mix of organised events, and also spontaneous ones. And if you can connect the sharing of these 'spontaneous' ones on social networks with the organised ones, it would increase attention.Sort of like those organised improve events T-Mobile did a while back. This one for example, and look how many people have their mobile phones out to record it. I bet they shared it on Facbeook and the likes: http://youtu.be/NB3NPNM4xgo

I like your ideas Arjan! It could work as a more spontaneous action, the hawker centers full of potential participants are there. It would be great for prototyping also.Btw, that's my first challenge and I'm not sure how this concepting phase works. Should we together redesign the concepts?

You're doing great. And what to do is also a bit of personal preference. What I do is update my concepts if I see something nice pop-up in the comments. You can use the update this entry button on top-right of your concept, just below your profile pic.Also, I like to use the new feature of creating virtual teams. If someone has contributed in the comments, and I use that in the concept, I add them to my team.If there's anything you like to discuss, you can come to the user forums (find the link in the black navigation bar on top of all pages). There's a special section for new users: https://openideo.zendesk.com/forums/20221621-new-users-we-re-here-to-help

Now for a more concept-oriented comment: I did not mean one or the other. I think orchestrated 'spontaneous' workshops can be a good addition. It might introduce the idea to people who hadn't heard about it, and then become regular visitors of scheduled ones.

Thanks for the tips!About the concept, that's actually how I understood it. That both ways can coexist, as hawker centers are always full of potential participants. It can be interesting to make it in general more open. Some people can sign up earlier, and some can join on the spot.
Bring on the collaboration, guys! K  I'm loving this concept so it'll be exciting to see it evolve.
thanks Meena!

the_amazing_singaporeans.title: The Meeting (The Amazing Singaporeans) [UPDATED]

py/tuple: How easy would it be for citizens to get involved and take initiative for this idea?
Very easy; this would rely on ground-up participation from the beginning.
Somewhat easy; there are ways for citizens to get involved, but an outside organiser may be needed to sustain and grow this concept.
This concept needs to be led and maintained by the government or private business.
Can you build this concept on top of something that already exists, like an organisation, physical space, or system?
Yes. This could fold into, or extend from, something that already exists.
This concept taps existing networks for a few things, but also needs a lot of new processes, materials, relationships, etc.
This concept requires a new system to be built to support it.
After the initial launch and support, could this concept be sustained and cared for over time by the community it's designed to serve?
Absolutely! This concept is easy to keep going.
It depends. There are opportunities for growth, but it's not yet clear how the concept would thrive after launch.
Probably not. A lot of effort would be needed to keep this concept going.
Does this concept create community?
Yes. It naturally brings people together and inspires them to take care of one another.
There is potential to create a thriving community.
No. It doesn't galvanize people to come together for a common cause or interest.
Overall, how do you feel about this concept?
It rocked my world.
I liked it but preferred others.
It didn't get me overly excited.

community_mural_painting_and_block_party.description: These would be essentially gatherings where members of the community could come together to paint murals, possibly in run-down or troubled neighborhoods. Anyone could participate!
community_mural_painting_and_block_party.creator: c9a0b3e0161fc4897b1f265b8ca4f205

comments.text: Some of my friends at Google are taking this to next level with the help of tech openspaces.co.id, bringing browser based painting to beautify the street walls -

This is definitely just the kind of community improvement that I had in mind! On the one hand these projects improve a neighborhood's physical appearance which in turn leads to a sense of community pride, while on the other they bring groups of people together to work towards a common goal which has the same effect.
So it's kinda like a creative artsy fun fair for everyone? Terrific!Unfortunately, we don't quite have as many of these here in SG. Got any stories to share about a few you've been to? ;)

Exactly! Basically the mural painting would take place during a local artisan and food fair, featuring the products of community members. In San Francisco, the Mission District hosts it's "Party of Block 18", which is just this. People in San Francisco come together to enjoy art, music, food and bond as a community. It is a great way to learn about things going on in your area and develop a sense of community pride. Here is the link to the event I attended this past summer: http://sf.funcheap.com/party-block-18-mission-dist/. As far as the mural painting itself, I came an organization based in Brooklyn that might serve as a good model. Artmakers Inc., run by local artists and a board of directors, is according to their website: "politically-oriented community mural organization that creates high quality public art relevant to the lives, work and concerns of people in their neighborhoods". They provide advice and guidance to community groups wanting to create murals, giving their time to groups that lack funding, providing on-site visits, design workshops, and production advice. There work within New York communities, which you can view at, http://www.artmakersnyc.org/, had been very successful.With this example as a launch point, for our purposes the message of the mural would not necessarily have to be political. Similarly, the extent of planning for the mural's design and the involvement of professional artists should be left to the community or maybe a board of directors. Above all else, the goal should be to increase community involvement and boost neighborhood pride.

community_mural_painting_and_block_party.title: Community Mural Painting and Block Party

comments.text: I really like this idea and love the video! It really complements what I was thinking when I first saw this challenge--the importance of skill/knowledge sharing in generating community harmony. This has the potential for lasting, meaningful impact--particularly intergenerationally. What I think would really be awesome is to combine this idea with the other inspirations related to markets. This is what I'm thinking--where I live in Taipei, Taiwan, the culture of night markets is embedded in society. It's a wonderful avenue for people to unwind in the evenings, get something to eat, and interact with each other on the weekend or even on the weekday after work (after nightfall). A wide variety of food is sold along with goods--and the vendors and traditional food sold sometimes vary depending on what night market you attend. What if skill/knowledge sharing was integrated into some variation of a night market concept and institutionalized in the same way?--for instance, night markets would exist in which people would set up kiosks (neighborhood mentors or neighborhood gurus vs. helpers) and people could come to learn a new skill or arts and crafts or discuss a particular topic--along with chowing down on some local grub. To help launch the process, people could use some sort of online community portal to vote for what skills they want to learn or what topics they want to learn about, then local mentors/gurus could be identified and matched and rotate time volunteering at the market (if sponsorship could be obtained, mentors/gurus could be given some sort of gift or bonus for sharing their services/knowledge)...and the skill/knowledge areas could vary by market as the concept got bigger!Sorry so long, but you got me going. Lots of luck going forward!!
Love this. Really wish it was something that libraries would take on. My granma would be soooo happy!
Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Inspiration!

Fabulous inspiration, Matt! I especially like how it highlights the theme of reciprocity which is quickly emerging on this challenge a sa key motivator to nurturing community connections. We're excited to see what this will spark in our upcoming Concepting phase!
Brilliant. Great example of enabling people to help eachother.

upcycling.description: There is a trend of taking materials and used furniture/clothes and leftover material from industrial processes and remake into brand new "design products". I propose to start a shop and hold workshops for creative handicrafters!
upcycling.creator: 656863f55543ea22d1dbce290f237277

comments.text: I like your concept.. it is very adequate for urban communities (and also possibly young/creative ones, perhaps good for a university based city). The 1st educational part is, in my opinion, also useful for clients, because mostly those who upclycle are already aware of the impact, but clients/future creators need to be educated to the upcycling culture ands its advntages (both economic and social).

thank you. I agree totally on what you say about clients/business people. A big bonus is that you can with the shop show them plenty of existing products/items/examples, and that it is viable to think about value in salvaging raw materials. Use the existing resources for profit instead of paying for the cost to transport it to landfill or burn it up

I understand that the nordic cities adapt well to the shops (somehow connected to a more merchant/liberal perspective), in Portugal the communities of creators are organising regular street markets, which has two advantages (in my opinion): reducing the running costs of the place and create animation to public areas (gardens, neighberhoods, ...) check this market: http://www.openideo.com/profiles/100000217699149/
sorry .. wrong llink: http://crafts-design-no-jardim-da-estrela.blogspot.pt/
Thank you! In fact the nordic cities are sometime organizing outdoor markets, a couple of weekends each summer. The climate makes it almost impossible to gather customers in winter season.

I think it is a great idea. I'm more curious to know how we can mass-customized it to improve efficiency and lower cost, meaning how to build up a chain to uncycle/recycle more used items. Any thoughts?

Yes, my thoughts are to attract thousands of designers/remakers. That will cause a big flow of new products/items and reduce the trash.Using web shops such as Etsy, could make all the world a market place for the items mass-market at minimum cost.Remember that this will mostly be unique, one-off-items, and therefor the client will cherish the refined and remade objects more then the mass-manufactured items.

Hey Johan-- I really like your concept! The revenue model based on commission seems like a good way to reduce the initial investment capital needed (as long as the rent is covered by other means). Also, I liked your idea to leverage the ETSY network for scaling up!Thought you might also be interested in this post: http://www.good.is/posts/salvaging-by-design-upcycling-fashion-industry-scraps?utm_campaign=goodtweet&utm_source=twitter&utm_medium=socialCheers!

Thank you! And I speak from experience, I was a member of such a "design-shop-association" for several years. So I know that it is possible to find cheap temporary shop space, you just need to be creative and you could start without the need for initial investments.

I think this concept would work really well in Singapore. There are quite a few little shops around with vintage clothing and unique bits and pieces. The workshops, I think, would do really well! I even imagine that there would be a space (in the community centre, maybe?) where the workshop is held and materials will be available. There could be tools and sewing machines and whatever else is needed for making new things out of old things.

Johan, awesome idea!I was in Taipei last week and meet with people from YStudio, a startup working on upcycling.  The company founders are artists whose goal is not only to develop beautiful products from "trash" but also to educate the public on the origins of the "trash".  Their "trash" consist of historical treasures from Taiwan.  For example, they took old-school Taiwanese wall outlets (made from handcrafted material and beautifully decorated) and updated them with new wires in order to convert them to power strips.  Very beautiful power strips when compared to today's cheap plastic ones.  They also converted old cameras to lamps.  http://www.ystudio-style.com/  To add to your idea, it would be great to have shelves/space dedicated to new products that were converted from "Singaporean" treasures, e.g. "trash" that has some history or significance to Singaporeans.  Information on the history/significance of the recycled raw product should be included with the purchase.  Great way to educate folks on Singaporean history!

upcycling.title: Upcycling — independent Design Shop/Markets

_walking_distance_democratic_problem_sol.description: What if local leaders and activists could browse a directory of local businesses willing to host fundraisers to solve specific problems in their neighborhood?  (e.g.: Sophia's Cafe offers 25% of one day's profit toward Jim improving a local park)
_walking_distance_democratic_problem_sol.creator: f92cd9612ad5db7f2072da94282c3214

comments.text: Great concept Jay. It's a really great idea. I do work with a charity organisation with a good name and standing, but still it is hard work to convince people/businesses to help out. Imagine if you just want to do something as an individual. This would really help in getting action started.Have you seen the inspirations of the Sidewalk Gallery Cafe - http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/inspiration/the-sidewalk-gallery-cafe-social-entrepreneurship-in-singapore/and the Pigeon Hole Cafe: http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/inspiration/spaces-that-bring-communities-togetherThese seem to me like great venues/businesses to involve in the pilot of this concept. I really think there should be one. I like how it also makes people more connected, and how you seek to give the argument of mutual benefit (new customers, fundraising etcetera).

Thanks for the comment Arjan.  I will add those inspirations to the concept!Getting businesses involved is always the hard part.  But with franchises and international brands coming into small neighborhoods, I feel like local businesses will have a serious motivation to get their neighbors into their establishments.

unrelated thoughts, while thinking about your 25%, 50% 10% discounts and so on. I don't know if this might lead to anything, but have you seen that a few smart companies, are sometimes having offer to make customers bring in any discount coupons (that are from other stores and multinational supermarket chains) and let the customer benefit of some type of % discount at the little local store, even though the coupon is for a totally different item, product, price. ???The last time I saw of it, there was a shop that said, if you bring 1 coupon you will get 10% on purchases between 100 and 200$. if you have 2 coupons you will get 20% on purchases over 200$. (and it didn't matter if the % printed on the coupon was 5% or 50%, or whatever company it was from)How do you feel about this? appropriate to fit into "WalkingDistance" or should I add it as a standalone concept? I mean there are quite a few innovative directions I think one can take coupons. Perhaps the customer with a coupon can get 10% discount, and the customer uses 10% on some measures to reduce carbon emissions, energy use, reduce amount of unneccessary packaging/transports and so on???

Coupons are an interesting direction for sure.  I think the problem with what you're saying is that you somehow expect the 10% being saved to be used on positive measures like carbon emissions, energy use, etc.The idea with the 25% at Sophia's Cafe is that patrons would pay the same price, but a portion of the proceeds go to a local cause.  Further, I really submitted this concept because I liked the idea of using this platform to bring a very local community together in an almost political way.Having a platform for those who champion a cause to get hooked up with a local business changes the patron's experience from "25% goes to some non-descript carbon emission reduction" to the experience of actually meeting Jim at the store, and contributing to this neighbor's cause of fixing up the park around the corner.Is there some way coupons can be integrated into this hyper-local aspect of the concept?

I understand you, i think. But I just wanted to play around with the discount and idea of "convincing" small shop owners to do something actively as a "promise" to keep to the customer. Do you think I should write a "Coupon Concept"? and I can add you there, if you wish to continue the discussion around its potential and variations?
Sure!  Looking forward to it.

And I am all for the "think global act local" as one of the ways of going little bit "greener". So in that way you could say a discount coupon for McDonalds could be very beneficial for local economy if that coupon is used to buy a meal at a street vendor or restaurant with local cuisine. Don't you think?
http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/concepting/crazy-coupons/ All others are also welcome to add their ideas and input and "crazy comments" :)

Hello, this concept proposal sounds a little bit like Carrot Mob. Have you heard about it? Maybe you could read in the "inspiration" that I wrote, and maybe you would like to link to it, in your concept here? So that other people can read and understand how it connects with customers small business owners : http://www.openideo.com/open/connected/inspiration/carrotmob-consumer-collaborations/Perhaps you will get additional ideas for your concept when you have read and watched the video there? :) best of luck!

Thank for the comment Johan - definitely very related!  I think the idea is slightly different, as this concept STARTS with the business, allowing them to use this platform to attract a local audience.There's definitely something here, I will look into Carrot Mob and see if it inspires any new developments to "WalkingDistance"... let me know if you have any ideas.

sure, feel free to use any of my ideas, or choose to use none of them :) But I just felt hesitant, because it could be a slight feel of "just being a promotion campaign", if it is up to the company to decide themselves on the deal, terms and how large the offered discount. Don't you think? I would not automatically go to a business that does like that, and naively trust that they use the money in the way that they say.I mean some element of transparency, so that customers could see clearer result? Similar to the CarrotMob, when actually the customer group go around the whole area and let the businesses "compete" and "haggle" in order to obtain the whole customer groups purchases.or maybe you can come up with a completely different version, so that you eliminate the risk of it feeling just like another marketing stunt in order to earn profit.
Interesting point.  You're inspiring me to think more about how to get the local leader/activist role to play more of the leadership role here - it would make sense :)

comments.text: I love this idea...I love that it is win-win and that you can so easily show consumers how their choices are making the world a better place not to mention the potential for community building that is inherent in the design of this.

yes, the shop owner will get more understanding about what customers want/wish, it could improve their selection of healthier/environmentally-friendly products. And also customers will be getting insight in how the small local shop owners struggle against the multinational Supermarket chains They will mutually benefit eachother, if they respect eachother. (and this type of design solution does not cost any money)

I just want to add the app for special deals. Combined with the environmental and social instead of social deals this Inspiration is really interesting. The ad is in Swedish - but you get the idea after 10 sec. - think that you see all the shops that have certified for a special standard......let's develop in the concept phase ...:)
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gNV58jSLR_g

generally I am not too keen on App's, because lots of people don't have 3G-4G-phones. I am one of them. But if it is the most costeffective solution to solve a problem or create a good enough function for lots of users, then I could be on board :)

Johan, great to see you back in a challenge again! And great inspiration. Would have been a good one for the business impact challenge that's also running now, but already in concepting phase. Maybe there's a concept hiding in it for that challenge as well.

Brilliant Idea!

food_building_healthy_communities.description: How can food be a central strategy to building healthy communities? Rather than focus on adults, create a language of community and sustainability though youth programs like The Edible Schoolyard Project.
food_building_healthy_communities.creator: 4365a47f03df4395adf00d2f39e5516c

comments.text: Brendan, thanks for sharing.  Food is a key part of Singaporean living, specifically "eating out" is listed as one of Singaporean's top pastimes. Thus I like the idea of using food/eating as a centerpiece for the challenge.   http://www.channelnewsasia.com/stories/singaporelocalnews/view/1173530/1/.html   I would be interested to understand how much "local" food is available in Singapore since the country has limited land.

Hao, thank you for your response and question. I agree - when I was in Singapore earlier this year, I was treated to wonderful food - with fresh fruits, seafood, meats and vegetables. There is definitely an eating out culture - with great options. The thought on urban agriculture or locally sourced food is that it is one tool to help build healthy communities - from bee keeping to small community gardens. There are many examples of communities with limited land using balconies or small plots 3 meters square. These will not be the main source of food for a community, but can supplement the diet and have great educational and community-building value. One of the underlying philosophies of the local food movement is to teach children about food and where it comes from.  Imagine if twice a year, a restaurant became a classroom and taught children and their families about the food they serve. Small ideas that connect us.
Nice reflections Brendan, especially about assumptions we might bring to our challenge efforts. The Edible Schoolyard is absolutely a relevant and valuable inspiration to share!

I like the idea of bringing purpose to regular activities done in a neighborhood -- in this case, challenging the status quo around food shopping while fulfilling the basic task of grocery shopping. I wonder how we might create more galvanizing, thought-provoking moments in day-to-day neighborhood living?

I like the idea of galvanising moments very much! Like street festivals are galvanising moments, like picking up your neighbour's cars, like coming together for the occasion of tea and cakes while doing the gardening (or the other way round). How might we create relevant and galvanising moments to bring a community together is a good question. And what makes those moments relevant and galvanising would be an interesting aspect to explore.

the_amazings.description: The Amazings is a platform connecting between older people who wants to share their wisdom, skills and life experience, and younger ones, who would like to learn from them.
the_amazings.creator: 0aab8ed8e94e13d9acfd932ff356f623

comments.text: Congrats on this post being today's onsite Featured Inspiration!

Great post Klementyna. I really love how platforms such as The Amazings are helping to foster intergenerational communities. For too long there has been a notion that seniors have little to contribute to society and to the economy, and thus not a valued part of the community, leading them to be ostracised or pushed away. This is just plain wrong. It just that we have failed to figured out what and where the opportunities lie to which retirees could apply their vast experiences, skills, capabilities and flexibility of time and schedules.Many highly urbanised countries, such as Singapore, are facing a rapidly ageing population and there is a fear that there will not be enough young workers to support the aged. The reaction has been to focus attention of raising birth rates and/or immigration policies. But another approach might be to look at new models and platforms such as The Amazings, that enable older people to keep on being value creating members of their communities.

Hear, hear! I was struck by the awesomeness of The Amazings when they launched and started following them on Facebook. It's great to get updates on the intergenerational connections they are making and the incredible community value they create.
I see they started making also on-line meetings with the Amazings using Google Hangouts.

I think this is definitely something to keep in mind for Singapore! Maybe it could be applied on a larger scale: the hawker centres, loved by old and young and keepers of some of the most sacred of Singapore's food secrets, are in the hands of the older generation. What will happen to traditional recipes and how will customs and habits of the new Singaporeans be affected when nobody is interested in taking over the family's food stall? Maybe this could even be a way to secure the future of the hawker centre?
Great thoughts Maria! We're looking forward to how folks mint build upon this inspiration for the upcoming Concepting phase, with the context of Singapore in mind.

Hi everyone, I just wanted to comment to say thank you for all the kind words about The Amazings. I work at The Amazings and it's great to hear that there's so much support for what we're doing in the UK and around the world. Hopefully it inspires similar action in Singapore and beyond!ThanksJen

Hi Maria, this is really interesting what you write about the hawker centers. I checked it in Wikipedia and found out that actually NEA (the sponsor of the challenge!) manages all of the centers. They even launched a website http://myhawkers.sg/ to promote them. Maybe it could be possible to build a new service upon this existing website? There is a section there called "learn", but it seems to be more encyclopedia style than "the Amazings" style of learning.

Hi Jen,"The Amazings" is such a great idea and inspiration! Well done!I was wondering what happens after the Amazing has their workshop/lesson. Do participants and tutors stay in touch? Does it happen that participants want to have more workshops with the same tutor or is it rather a one time thing? It could be interesting to hear what impact such classes have on the local community.

Just a quick build on the intersection between The Amazings and the iconic Singaporean hawker center. Ageing hawkers are hesitant to pass on all their secrets as they are their family's livelihood. But if the next generation is not interested in taking over, could the government 'heritage council' step in and offer to buy & perserve their recipes as part of Singapore's cultural heritage, given that food is such an important part of the national culture, conversation and identity? By rewarded hawkers for sharing their precious IP and passing on their secrets to the general public on how to make a treasured national dish, it's a win win.

the_amazings.title: The Amazings

Similar to http://www.saturdaymarketlive.com - as discussed it feels like this idea needs a main market driver + it would be great if it was repeated (same bat time / same bat channel) or in rotating car parks throughout the city or in multiple car parks with multiple themes? I'd focus on the one main driver. The issue with car parks is that they can be cold and drafty - look for locations with adequate sunshine. I look forward to seeing how this is refined.

Would you encourage businesses to share the news? Place ads on public transport? Should the message be distributed by the community, for the community, or include other nearby locations as well? No problem! I understand tech glitches happen - no one's fault! Thanks for giving us more time to re-update our entries. Looking forward to getting Open Road back into shape.

It such a good idea. we have roads close off in singapore in places e.g. holland village, where alot of restaurants are along the side of the roads. This work really well to attract crowds and it is already a popular place. Sometimes we close off roads for big walks or runs. so if we extend this idea to where people stay,How about if we extend this idea to close off car parks? Currently, main roads in Singapore along residential areas may be difficult to close off due to traffic issues. Also, what if we could encourage residents to own the space or the stalls along the close off areas? Looking forward to hear your comments

I love the idea of transforming Car Parks! When a lot isn't busy, or the stores surrounding it are closed, the lot space is so wasted. Just a concrete plain void of life. Imagine flooding this underutilized area with families, games, chatter, food, drink, music, sports... It's terrific that streets are already closed at times for races. The great part about Open Road is it encourages a wide range of diverse activities at one time, so that even more members of the community can get involved. You don't have to love running or racing. You just have to appreciate fresh air, peaceful games, satisfying snacks and the wonderful energy of your neighbors. These are really inspiring thoughts, Debbie! Thank you for your input!

Very similar to San Francisco's city streets.  Would be cool to add programming to support environmentally friendly behavior changes at these events.  For example, bike riding lessons, urban gardening classes, energy efficiency awareness through home retrofit demonstrations, and recycling and repurposing stations.  In Nantucket they have something called "Take it or Leave it" where people have a way to give something away, but not throw it away.

py/tuple: How easy would it be for citizens to get involved and take initiative for this idea?
Very easy; this would rely on ground-up participation from the beginning.
Somewhat easy; there are ways for citizens to get involved, but an outside organiser may be needed to sustain and grow this concept.
This concept needs to be led and maintained by the government or private business.
Can you build this concept on top of something that already exists, like an organisation, physical space, or system?
Yes. This could fold into, or extend from, something that already exists.
This concept taps existing networks for a few things, but also needs a lot of new processes, materials, relationships, etc.
This concept requires a new system to be built to support it.
After the initial launch and support, could this concept be sustained and cared for over time by the community it's designed to serve?
Absolutely! This concept is easy to keep going.
It depends. There are opportunities for growth, but it's not yet clear how the concept would thrive after launch.
Probably not. A lot of effort would be needed to keep this concept going.
Does this concept create community?
Yes. It naturally brings people together and inspires them to take care of one another.
There is potential to create a thriving community.
No. It doesn't galvanize people to come together for a common cause or interest.
Overall, how do you feel about this concept?
It rocked my world.
I liked it but preferred others.
It didn't get me overly excited.

comments.text: Diana,Awesome idea! being enable to "sign up" for 15 min intervals does adds flexibility to people's business schedules.  More importantly I like the option of "on the fly" registering for events.  This would be great for visitors or people who want to pass time by!Additional scenarios:- Fly into Changi Singapore Airport with a 8 hr lay over.  Currently you have the option of leaving the airport to "tour and shop".  With the "15 min" option, you can now look up purpose-driven events to attend.- Wake up during the weekend and feel like "doing some good", logon to "15 min" app and register for an event!

Thanks, Hao Dinh! Appreciate the new scenarios. That's my hope for this sort of idea, to allow for a multitude of possibilities that adapt to different people's lifestyles and needs. That flexibility will also be crucial when scaling up beyond Singapore. Other scenarios I can imagine: - While waiting for your friends/a date, if you find out you get to the location way too early because traffic wasn't as bad, or vice versa, the person you're meeting is stuck at work or wherever -- might as well spend that extra time productively rather than standing around playing on your phone-In between errands or appointments taking place in the same area, but have some time to kill before your next appointment

comments.text: I like the idea; empower communities to define their own direction.A hybrid idea would be a platform for governments to propose a number of potential community-oriented projects. The community could vote on the proposed projects (and suggest alterations to scope/focus) without having to commit capital. The government would then invest in the most popular initiatives until their ring-fenced budget is exhausted. It would be very interesting to tie the proposed projects list to elected politicians' manifestos. Such an initiative could have the added benefit of increasing engagement in elections, local politics etc.(To avoid this becoming a popularity contest, the proposed projects would have to be "discretionary" in nature. Critical and enabling projects would not be subject to voting.)
